IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Cleft lip is the 4th most common birth defect in the U.S. and is known to affect annually one in 800 babies worldwide. The Kids First program aims to uncover the etiology of these diseases and foster data sharing within the pediatric research community. We propose to analyze the Structural Variation of the Kids First Orofacial Cleft: African and Asian Ancestry (244 family triads) cohort currently available from the Kids First data portal to improve diagnostic capabilities and therapies for children and their families affected by these conditions. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormalities in sensory perception are commonly reported alongside with social deficits in a wide range of mental illnesses, most prominently in individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASD). In this proposal, we will investigate oxytocin signaling as a common neurobiological mechanism that underlies the development of sensory perception and social cognition. The outcome of this proposal will reveal important basic rules for brain circuit development, and will identify early diagnostic markers associated with ASD that can guide novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (ME/CFS) is a complex disorder of unknown etiology and there are currently no biomarkers available to identify individuals with ME/CFS or to distinguish various subgroups of patients with ME/CFS. Our studies have demonstrated in a subgroup of patients with ME/CFS that the deoxyuridine triphosphate nucleotidohydrolase (dUTPase) proteins encoded by the human herpesviruses (Epstein-Barr virus & human herpesvirus-6) exert their novel biological effects by acting as a pathogen associated molecular pattern (PAMP) triggering the activation of TLR2 or TLR2/1, which are expressed on numerous cell types, inducing signaling cascades that result in the modulation of pathways involved in immunity, energy production and neuronal function. This multidisciplinary research grant will provide new information on the mechanisms by which the herpesviruses -dUTPases may induce immune dysregulation, post-exertional fatigue and cognitive dysfunction as it relates to ME/CFS, provide potential biomarkers and identify targets that may be used for the development of dUTPase-specific therapeutic agents for a subgroup of patients with ME/CFS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance Sex hormone altering medications are prescribed to over 40% of American adults, and yet the mental health consequences of sex hormones are still poorly understood. This project will be the largest ever investigation of sex hormone effects on post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression, and anxiety disorders, and the results of this powerful study design will provide much-needed information relevant to the development of new treatment and prevention strategies. The precision medicine approach used here relies on biomarkers and results will be tailored to individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Stress hormones are produced by the adrenal gland and promote systemic inflammation that contribute to cardiovascular and metabolic disease, which are two of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide. We will address sexual dimorphisms associated with adrenal macrophage development and their contribution to regulating the stress response following acute and chronic challenge models, and predict resident macrophages play a direct role in regulating this response. This study will provide definitive answers to adrenal macrophage ontogeny, onset of sexual dimorphism, heterogeneity, and responses to both acute and chronic stressors, knowledge that is essential for the development of therapeutic approaches to combat features of chronic stress that underlie high risk cardiovascular disease patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Virus infections are tightly linked to the development and exacerbation of allergic diseases, including asthma, allergic rhinitis, and atopic dermatitis. The immune response to virus infections are altered in allergic inflammation, however, little is known about the specific cellular pathways involved. The proposed research investigates how the allergic signals modulate critical antiviral cellular responses, providing potential targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Racial disparities persist between blacks and whites for colorectal cancer. Recent evidence suggests that the interaction of the gut microbiota and diet may contribute to disease risk. This study will investigate how the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet affects the gut microbiota across racial groups, which has the potential provide preliminary evidence for the DASH diet as a viable means for improving the gut microbial environment, thereby lowering CRC risk, across racially diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the most common causes of disability during aging is vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID), triggered by cerebral microbleed formation and other microvascular pathologies. The underlying mechanism includes age-related IGF-1 deficiency, which leads to vascular smooth muscle cell dysfunction, increased blood vessel fragility and development of cerebral microhemorrhages (CMH) in the aging brain. CMH can trigger neuroinflammation and consequent neuronal dysfunction, culminating in cognitive impairment and gait disorders, and understanding this sequence of events is critical for the development of effective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is the leading cause of more than 36,000 cases of cervical, ano-genital, and oropharyngeal cancers in the United States annually. While multi-valent vaccinations to prevent HPV infections have been available since 2006, uptake of the vaccine is well below national Healthy People 2030 targets; HPV vaccination rates are especially low in rural areas (about 11% lower than in urban areas). PREVENT is a randomized controlled trial of adapted HPV vaccination reminders to address the needs of diverse rural populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC RELEVANCE STATEMENT This training program builds on a long-standing and successful history of training scientists for careers in toxicology and environmental health at Texas A&M University. We aim to keep our training and research base strong and also provide unique focus on regulatory science, a scientific discipline consisting of the development and application of scientific methods, tools, and approaches that are used to support regulatory and other policy objectives. As the fields of toxicology and environmental health acquire new tools to better detect and characterize human health hazards, our trainees receive a strong, broad background in basic science with opportunities to specialize in research and/or decision-making for protection of public health and the environment.

PROJECT_TITLE: Regulatory Science in Environmental Health and Toxicology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Middle to older aged adults with overweight or obesity and cardiometabolic comorbidities, especially minorities, appear most vulnerable to secondary health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. To confront this public health crisis, the current Project on EHR-Integrated Lifestyle Interventions for Adults Aged Fifty and Older (PIVOT) aims to expand access to simple, effective lifestyle interventions for weight loss and behavior change using electronic health record systems and wearable devices. This study can enable accelerated deployment of effective digital behavioral health interventions at scale to reduce disease burden in aging adults with lifestyle- related multiple chronic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Conflict over an organism’s phenotype, particularly with respect to growth and behavior, can arise between different genes due to differences in genes’ relatedness to maternal and paternal relatives, conflicts that are predicted to be particularly intense on the X chromosome. Consequent antagonistic regulatory relationships between genes is expected to reduce robustness of regulatory networks. The proposed work will lay the foundations for understanding the health consequences of intragenomic conflict by identifying the consequences of intragenomic conflict for the X chromosome at the level of regulatory networks, X-linked gene transcription, transcriptome and cell type distribution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), the most common cause of chronic liver disease, and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), the most common type of primary liver cancer, are increasing in incidence worldwide. Evidence suggests that exposure to fine particulate matter less than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM2.5), a ubiquitous air pollutant, may impact the risk of developing NAFLD and HCC, especially among particular subgroups defined by race/ethnicity, geography, and sex. We propose to investigate the associations between ambient PM2.5 exposure and NAFLD and HCC risk, and the contribution of PM2.5 to NAFLD and HCC incidence disparities, in veterans across the United States, which will help identify individuals at high risk for NAFLD and HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal describes the need for and outline of an RM1 BTDD Center on Macromolecular Dynamics by NMR Spectroscopy (CoMD/NMR) situated at the New York Structural Biology Center. The focus of CoMD/NMR is to facilitate access to and adoption of cutting-edge technologies of NMR spin relaxation and associated methods for characterizing protein and nucleic acid conformational dynamics in biological processes, emphasizing functional aspects of oligomerization or assembly and of ligand recognition. The objectives of this proposal impact a diverse range of biological research with human health relevance, including cell signaling (in cancer and cell death pathways), degenerative diseases, metabolic disorders, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This application builds on the Duke MSTP's long history of training successful physician- scientists by incorporating a number of major changes and improvements, including: 1) Incorporation of improved medical school and graduate school assessment tools to track and evaluate students' progress throughout their training; 2) Development and incorporation of enhanced opportunities for trainees to influence their own career development; 3) Improvement of the admissions process to ensure holistic review and selection of candidates from diverse backgrounds, including enhanced outreach efforts to candidates from historically underrepresented backgrounds; 4) Enhanced trainee oversight at multiple stages of the program, including an emphasis on identification of roadblocks during annual Individual Development Plan meetings between leadership and students; 5) Broadening of the participating faculty to ensure input from a range of outstanding and diverse faculty at all levels; 6) Creation of additional program activities with guidance from the program's trainees and steering committee to ensure adequate program-wide training opportunities that foster program unity, including enhanced vertical integration through Duke's institution-wide Office of Physician- Scientist Development; and 7) Creation of a Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion committee to enhance program initiatives through which all can experience a true sense of belonging regardless of ethnicity, gender, age, national origin, sexual orientation, religious beliefs, or socioeconomic, veteran, or ability status. Collectively, these new program initiatives will continue the Duke MSTP's longstanding tradition of excellence in MD-PhD training and substantially improve outcomes for the approximately 85-90 students in the program each year.

PROJECT_TITLE: Medical Scientist Training Program Training Grant
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - A[TWD-A]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Excessive impulsivity, a hallmark of chronic drug abuse, promotes selection of short-term gains at the expense of long-term goals, like abstaining from drug use or seeking treatment. Developing new solutions to ameliorate drug relapse, therefore, will require a more complete understanding of the brain processes behind impulsive decision making. Here, we will use innovative cell-targeted strategies to uncover the unique roles of cholinergic interneuron D2 dopamine receptors in shaping neuronal signaling and impulsive behavior both in health and after chronic cocaine exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial diseases, including Leigh Syndrome, affect 1 in 5000 live births. These studies will determine if the bioenergetic deficit due to impaired mitochondrial Complex I function is exacerbated by defective function of the citric acid cycle. We will determine if alternative metabolite generation facilitates the neuropathological decline. We will also investigate site-specific therapeutic strategies that may be rapidly translatable for humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  A wealth of neuroimaging work indicates cortical-amygdala activity across different networks can provide 'fingerprints' of specific psychiatric disease. Yet understanding of the 'hardwiring' of cortical amygdala microcircuits that underlie these functional data has lagged. We interrogate how cortical nodes frequently implicated in psychiatric disease specifically interface in the amygdala, with the goal of finding specific cellular correlates that may be altered in disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The genomics era was anticipated to bring with it the capacity to use molecular biology tools to identify specific cancer-causing mutations and translate that information into better therapy. This problem has not been realized for most children with cancer, especially diseases like fusion-positive rhabdomyosarcoma (FP-RMS) that harbors few highly recurrent mutations. Our project will develop two new tools – a Bayesian-based, integrative analyses of genomic and epigenetic features of FP-RMS, and FP-RMS PDX models and cell lines where the oncogenic fusion protein can be rapidly and reversibly switched “on” and “off” – which will reveal cancer drivers and tumor suppressors, and how they can be influenced by the fusion protein and, potentially, targeted.

PHR: Project Narrative The NIGMS predoctoral biotechnology training program in Biomolecular and Tissue Engineering at Duke University provides trainees with enhanced classroom, laboratory, and research training in the design, manipulation and quantitative characterization of biomolecules, cells, and tissues with special emphasis on the translation of these technologies and their advancement within the biotechnology industry. Training activities are focused on enhancing and diversifying our biotechnology work force and preparing the next generation of leaders who will pioneer burgeoning new fields such as biologic drug development, tissue engineering, and gene and cell therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efficient separation, isolation, and enrichment of specific molecules and cells are critical research steps in biol- ogy, biotechnology, and medicine, with each playing an important role in advancing biomedical research. Micro- fluidic devices offer promising solutions that can achieve these steps with precise control, but these technologies are currently limited to small amounts of sample, restricting the amount or rate of processing. In the proposed project, these obstacles are overcome by a new technology platform, based on highly configurable arrays of microfabricated features, that uses sound to move and trap small particles and cells for a wide variety of research applications involving enrichment, isolation, and separation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Hypertension and chronic kidney disease are long-term consequences following recovery from renal ischemic acute kidney injury and unilateral obstructive uropathy. We will determine the contribution of a novel class of arachidonic acid metabolites, EETs, to the chronic changes in renal hemodynamics, endothelial function, and blood pressure regulation following ischemia reperfusion and ureter obstruction kidney injury. Our expected outcome is that the findings of our project will not only enhance our understanding of the pathophysiological mechanisms whereby renal ischemic injury and ureter obstruction leads to salt-sensitive hypertension and chronic kidney disease but have the potential to lead to new therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody glomerulonephritis (ANCA GN) is a life-threatening disease that results from a “confused” immune system attacking one’s own body. Our current treatment, while successful, suppresses the immune system in a non-specific way leaving patients at risk for serious infections and other complications. Our proposal seeks to develop therapies against specific immune targets halting the disease but leaving protective functions intact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ensuring the safety of living kidney donors must remain of primary concern to both individual transplant programs and society, in general. The identification of the APOL1 allele and its impact on the development of kidney disease necessitates the development of additional safeguards for potential donors. This application proposes the formative work needed to develop a decisional support tool for African Americans considering genetic testing for the APOL1 allele in the context of living kidney donation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Managing multiple chronic illness is difficult task for everyone and often one size does not fit well. Given the rapid social and technological changes, a comprehensive, structured transdisciplinary approach to research training is becoming particularly important for preparing the next generation of nurse scientists. We propose to create a national model for training nurse scientists who will lead developing personalized intervention for people suffering multiple chronic conditions.
PROJECT_TERMS: Intervention;Methodology;multiple chronic conditions;Precision Health;Self Management;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Precision Health Intervention Methodology Training in Self-Management of Multiple Chronic Conditions

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Environmental factors are increasingly recognized as having significant contributions to the health of human populations. Given the breadth of environmental factors and the complexity of this field, it is imperative that we continue to train the next generation of toxicologists/environmental health science (EHS) researchers with the technical, operational and professional skills necessary to conduct high impact EHS research, communicate effectively to a wide variety of audiences, and work as part of multidisciplinary teams to understand how human health is impacted by environmental factors.
PROJECT_TERMS: Molecular;Pathogenesis;Pathway interactions;Toxicology
PROJECT_TITLE: Molecular Pathways to Pathogenesis in Toxicology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The “glymphatic system” is a network of perivascular spaces that function as a waste clearance system, analogous to the peripheral lymphatic system. Reduced glymphatic function has been a hallmark observation in models of age, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes, hypertension, traumatic brain injury, chronic high ethanol intake, chronic unpredictable stress, and, preliminarily, pain. This application aims to define whether glymphatic activity may serve as a target for complementary therapeutic approaches and also as a biomarker establishing the efficacy of alternative medical treatments in a murine model of chronic neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Compromised olfactory function is associated with the aging process, as well as a number of human diseases including Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s and COVID19. Our incomplete understanding of the brain makes it challenging to comprehend the mechanisms that underlie these sensory and motor deficits or brain disorders. By studying how sensory information is encoded and transformed by processing in the brain, we seek to define these mechanisms, which we hope will lead to strategies to protect against such failures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Oral candidiasis, also known as oral thrush, is an AIDS-defining fungal infection of the oral mucosa. This disease also afflicts individuals on chemotherapy, transplant patients taking immunosuppressive drugs, asthma patients using inhaled corticosteroid drugs or others with compromised immune function such as infants and the elderly. The objective of this project is to understand interactions between commensal Candida albicans and the host immune system while the long-term goal of this research is to develop better therapies or vaccines for mucosal disease of the oral cavity, and to understand the consequences of therapies that suppress specific immune events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of the proposed research is to develop a new MRI technology for imaging oxidative stress: hyperpolarized dehydroascorbate (HP DHA) MRI. Oxidative stress is implicated in the pathogenesis of many diseases, including neurodegeneration and brain tumors, and there is an urgent need to develop more sensitive and specific imaging approaches to characterize it. We aim to develop HP DHA MRI and apply it to preclinical models of oxidative stress in the brain and brain tumors as well as optimize it for translation into humans. This work will facilitate future patient-specific treatment planning, as well as earlier assessment of response to therapy and the development of novel experimental strategies for cancer treatment.

Our overarching goal is to create a diverse community of like-minded peers who are confident, academically strong, and have advanced research skills. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic brain injury (TBI), a leading cause of mortality and long-term disability worldwide, is a significant public health issue, debilitating or killing more individuals that breast cancer, AIDS, multiple sclerosis, and spinal cord injury combined. In this project, we will implicate the modulation of MAGL-CB2R-TLR4 axis in myeloid cells in the attenuation of the secondary neurovascular injury after TBI. Our conceptually and technically innovative studies will establish a mechanistic framework for the development of novel therapeutic approaches and will identify a potential biomarker to prospectively identify patients at high risk for neurological deterioration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorder continues to be a major public health problem with an economic annual cost of over $700 billion in the United States alone and dramatic increases in overdose deaths to heroin, prescription opioids, and cocaine over the last few years. We propose that the development of effective treatments have been slowed, in part, by our lack of mechanistic understanding of circadian rhythms associated with drug craving, seeking, and relapse in substance use disorder. This research will discover how cue-induced cocaine seeking varies across the day and the extent to which this variation is driven by diurnal rhythms in the function of neural substrates (dopamine and acetylcholine systems) that underlie drug seeking, craving, and relapse.

PHR: Microbial and host genetic factors contribute to the progression of intestinal diseases affecting millions in the USA growing body of evidence indicates that gut microbes influence intestinal stem cell activity, and thus play important roles in maintaining healthy gut function. PHR: Emerging data suggest that a woman’s vaginal microbiome can protect her from acquisition of sexually transmitted infections, pelvic inflammatory disease, and risk of pre-term delivery. This proposal will provide career development for the PI in clinical research, biostatistics, and epidemiology, and is relevant to the NIH’s mission to reduce infections and promote women’s health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adjuvants incorporated into vaccine formulations have a major impact on vaccine efficacy via modulating and prolonging host immune responses; however, our understanding of their underlying mechanism(s) of action in driving specific immune parameters is incomplete. Thus, defining the mechanisms of action of combination adjuvants that generate potent trained immunity and protective Th1/Th17 responses are the overall goals of this proposal. Dissecting the mechanisms of combination adjuvants-mediated immunity as described in this proposal, will have a broad impact on development of vaccines for many infectious diseases, including tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Cryptococcosis, due to infection by the encapsulated yeasts C. neoformans and C. gattii, is the most common etiological agent of culture-positive meningitis. Nearly 200,000 people, most of whom are HIV-infected, die from this disease annually. The proposed research addresses a global public health need for a cryptococcal vaccine by using carefully designed mouse and human studies to develop a subunit multiantigen vaccine suitable for eventual human testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Accurate and scalable interpretation of genomic variation is a critical component to realize the full potential of high-throughput sequencing in human genetics and genomic medicine. My lab is focused on developing new computational methods to predict functional impact of genomic variation and to integrate multi-modal genomic data sets in genetic analysis by machine learning. These methods will improve the utility of genome sequencing and functional genomics data and enable new discoveries in genetic studies of human diseases and clinical diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative. Cells (including our own) sense and respond to changes in their environment via a variety of cell-surface receptors, which are the target of a majority of pharmaceuticals. Understanding how these receptors function — in the context of their native cellular membranes — is both fundamental and of use for improved pharmaceutical design. The proposed work combines computer simulations and experimental measurements to study how the membrane influences signaling of a broad and important class of cell surface receptors called G-protein coupled receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metal–protein interactions are essential for the function of at least one-third to one-half of all proteins in cells. The incorrect binding of a metal to a protein, however, can lead to harmful effects on the cell, including toxicity. The research proposed here is designed to identify the protein targets of metal stress and elucidate molecular mechanisms that lead to toxicity. The outcomes will advance our understanding of how proteins across the proteome respond to exposure to excess levels of biologically relevant Zn and Cu, with important implications for developing pharmacological agents to leverage metal stress against microbial pathogens and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Microbes employ hundreds of diverse defense systems to provide protection from mobile genetic elements such as viruses, and studying these systems is important for understanding immune system evolution, the implications of phage therapy, and the discovery of new molecular tools such as restriction enzymes and CRISPR-Cas systems. We propose several goals to address critical knowledge gaps in CRISPR-Cas biology and its newfound relationship with cell membrane function. Our goals will help us understand how RNA-targeting containing CRISPR-Cas systems and their membrane-associated proteins function together to enhance viral defense with an eye towards the discovery of new molecular tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. New small molecule probes are critical to illuminating biology in ways that can be harnessed for the treatment of human disease. Our group is developing natural product-inspired chemical biology platforms that integrate chemical synthesis with sophisticated biological investigations to discover new phenomena relevant to priority disease areas (e.g., antibiotic-tolerant biofilm infections, cancer, opioid addiction). During this award, we will (1) expand our tryptoline ring distortion platform to generate new complex and diverse compounds, and perform an array of biological studies to explore their re-engineered activities, and (2) develop robust strategies to expand the spectrum of activity for halogenated phenazine biofilm-eradicating agents to address the underlying cause of chronic and recurring bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is focused on studying molecular interactions regulating the calcium- activated chloride channel TMEM16A, which mediates diverse processes in humans ranging from regulating blood flow through the cardiovascular system to the excitability of neurons. The goal of this research is to uncover the mechanisms of how lipids created in the cell and acquired through diet, and physiologic processes regulate channel activity. It is relevant to public health because understanding how these molecular interactions are disrupted in disease will enable better therapeutic design for the wide array of pathologies associated with TMEM16A channels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative In animal development the single-celled zygote divides, and its progeny differentiate to produce an incredible diversity of cell types, but we still have much to learn about the molecular changes that occur in cells as they divide and differentiate. This project uses cutting-edge microscopy and genomics tools to study this process in the embryo of the nematode C. elegans, which uses many of the same genes as humans to specify its cell types and allows for rapid experimentation. We will focus on how regulatory genes work in different combinations to allow cells to make different decisions during development, how errors in these decisions are avoided, and how the timing of developmental events is controlled.

PHR: Project Narrative General anesthetics are commonly used to induce unconsciousness during surgery, but they have been reported to cause neuronal cell death and cognitive dysfunction. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine, 5-HT) mediates human physiology as diverse as cognition, gut motility, and endocrine function, and 5-HT receptors and transporters are thus targeted by both illicit and therapeutic drugs. While structural work has provided limited mechanistic insight into the function of this complex system, the precise signaling mechanisms of serotonin receptors via different transducers are poorly understood and off- target effects of serotonergic drugs at understudied serotonin transporters have not been systemically characterized. Combining cryo-EM, molecular pharmacology, and structure-aided drug discovery, we will thus elucidate fundamental mechanisms of serotonin signaling and transport, and generate novel chemical probes towards exploring the therapeutic potential of distinct signaling pathways and modulation of understudied transporters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is focused on the development and application of novel computational methods to map the free energy and fitness landscapes of proteins, with a focus on protein kinases (PKs) which are involved in many cellular signaling pathways. Our goal is to construct an atlas representing key features of the conformational landscapes of PKs using sequence co-variation models and molecular dynamics simulations in an integrated way. This information provides a foundation for understanding the molecular basis for their biological function, how and why mutations cause disease states, and provides insights into the design of therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The 3D spatial organization of the human genome inside the nucleus plays a role in gene regulation, DNA replication, and repair, and is often disrupted in disease, but less is known about how this structure interacts with physical disruptions to the cell. This research program will examine how different stressors, such as constricted cell migration, nuclear lamin mutation, and DNA damage affect chromosome structure and gene expression, and how changes in chromosome structure relate to changes in cellular function. Our results will help build a framework in which we can understand, and eventually predict, the impact of certain treatments or conditions on human cells based on their genome structure, opening avenues for future chromosome structure-based disease diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Bioactive immune-modulating nanodrug for sepsis treatment Project Narrative Sepsis, commonly caused by severe trauma and infection, results in dysregulated inflammation leading to tissue damage/organ failure, which unfortunately lacks effective pharmacological interventions in the clinic to improve patient survival. In recent years, my lab has developed a novel unique telodendrimer nanoplatform for both therapeutic delivery and versatile active immune modulation. In the next five years, my research program will focus on the development of the next generation of TD nanodrug for (1) active fine-tuned inflammation control against a broad spectrum of immune stimuli via pleiotropic mechanisms; (2) control of both hyperinflammation and immune suppression in sepsis by blocking cytokine storm and pyroptosis; and (3) delivery of vital antibiotics for simultaneous control of MDR infection and inflammation in sepsis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the important role they play in shaping the transcriptome and proteome of cells, the mechanisms that dictate the ability of RNA binding proteins (RBPs) to perform different jobs in specialized cell types and respond to environmental stimuli remain unclear. My lab investigates how sensing of microbial components functionalizes RBPs to participate in the macrophage innate immune gene expression program. By illuminating the molecular mechanisms through which RBPs regulate the macrophage transcriptome, this work supports the mission of the NIGMS to understand the fundamental principles of living cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many human infectious and genetic diseases disrupt G protein pathways, which constitute a conserved eukaryotic signaling mechanism. The proposed research will employ a highly tractable system to provide a comprehensive understanding of the regulation of heterotrimeric G protein biochemistry and signaling by subunit phosphorylation and natural variation in G protein sequence, and will thus identify specific regulatory paradigms that strengthen or impair the G protein cycle, heterotrimer interactions, subcellular localization, and coupling with other proteins. Results obtained will identify new G protein conformations for therapeutics, and will distinguish disruptive and benign natural variants, thereby identifying conditions and opportunities wherein targeted interventions should and can be prioritized to repair dysregulated aspects of G protein signaling while simultaneously avoiding impairment of other G protein functions and phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Enzymes called protein kinases are important regulators of cellular responses to environmental cues, and their deregulation is a hallmark of multiple human diseases. We will study how a group of protein kinases called MAP kinases are themselves regulated, and how they effect changes in cell physiology. This research will help explain both beneficial and undesired effects of drugs targeting MAP kinases and may lead to improved strategies to treat disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diversity in the biomedical research workforce produces higher quality and more impactful science. Yet, there remains an unmet need to identify evidence-based interventions to improve the diversity of the biomedical research enterprise. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: All healthy cells depend on a balanced cycle of making and turning over proteins. Our goal is to determine the mechanistic basis of how molecular machines involved in protein synthesis, folding, and unfolding work to perform their protein quality control functions. Our biochemical and structural studies will provide a structural framework that advances understanding of protein quality control machinery in the context of health and disease.

ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal investigates mechanisms that control organ growth and shape, focusing on how mechanical forces experienced by cells influence developmental processes. Inappropriate growth during development results in organs that are incorrectly sized or shaped, causing birth defects. Controlling organ growth is also important for understanding how stem cells can be used to repair or replace damaged organs, and the inability to limit growth in mature organisms results in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Ion channels pass electrical currents in the form of charged ions and are essential for processes as diverse as the heartbeat, thought, and movement. This project will define new paradigms in ion channel function involving regulation of ion channels by solute transporters (and vice versa) and small molecules and uncover new roles for ion channels in health and disease. These studies will ultimately help produce better therapeutic approaches to treat disorders including epilepsy, pain, inflammation, ataxia, and hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic variation influences genome function and organismal phenotypes, while providing the fundamental substrate for natural selection. Understanding the mechanisms that link these layers of variation and drive phenotypic evolution within natural populations is a major goal at the intersection of evolutionary biology and quantitative genetics. Using humans as a model, we propose to develop and apply computational and statistical methods for analyzing large-scale DNA sequence and functional genomic data, toward a more complete understanding of genetic diversity and evolution shaping genome function, reproduction, and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Normal cellular function requires that proteins responsible for sending and receiving signals be transported from the place in the cell where they are produced to the places in the cell where they are needed. It is known that a group of specialized proteins called kinesins is responsible for transporting proteins to the correct location, but the current understanding of how the right kinesin is paired with a particular protein and how they are directed to the right location is largely unknown. This project is designed to answer these questions, with the long-term goal of informing additional research on the roles of these proteins in preserving human health or contributing to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Large toxic particles that accumulate in the cytoplasm of mammalian cells such as viruses or protein aggregates drive disease ranging from infection to neurodegeneration to cancer. To respond to these insults, cells begin producing tens to hundreds of new organelles called autophagosomes, that encapsulate each cytoplasmic challenge and deliver them to lysosomes for destruction. How the cell martials the millions of lipids needed to grow these organelles is poorly described, but recent work from our lab has described the components of a novel lipid-scrambling and lipid-transporting complex potentially sufficient to drive this essential disease response pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell migration is critical for many physiological processes, such as wound healing and immune cell response, and also plays an important role in cancer metastasis, i.e. the spreading of tumor cells to distant sites in the body. As cells migrate through the body, they must frequently pass through tight spaces within tissues, placing substantial physical stress on the nucleus, which can result in DNA damage and changes in chromatin organization. The studies proposed in this application will (1) determine how cells move their large and relatively rigid nucleus through tight spaces, (2) elucidate the molecular mechanisms responsible for the changes in chromatin organization, and (3) identify the consequences of such confined migration on cellular fate and function, with the goal to obtain a better understanding of how migration through confined environments can modulate the function of normal cells but may also promote cancer progression and resistance to therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human introns contain a significant number of pseudo splice sites that can result in cryptic splicing, leading to the incorrect insertion of intronic elements into mRNA. We propose to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying the repression of cryptic splicing and its downstream consequences on cellular function. As cryptic splicing is associated with neuronal degeneration and cancer, knowledge gained from this research could help identify novel therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Decades of research in epidemiology, mathematical modeling, and public health have generated critical tools for epidemic monitoring and management, and these tools played a vital role during the COVID-19 pandemic to augment situational awareness and inform public health decisions. Now is the time we must enhance this toolkit with new data collection and modeling methods to enable improved management of COVID-19 and enhance preparedness for future emerging pathogens. The work will leverage mathematical modeling and large datasets to address key public health challenges: producing timely and accurate estimates of infection incidence and severity, quantifying the effectiveness of behavioral interventions, predicting seasonality, and addressing public health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Chromatin, the DNA and its associated proteins, underlies the genetic blueprint of the cell, but can also serve in a non-genetic capacity as a material that impinges on the mechanical properties of the nucleus in which it is housed. This proposal seeks to define the mechanisms by which modulation of chromatin state influences nuclear mechanics, establish the extent to which forces exerted on chromatin are propagated along the chromatin polymer, and identify biologically-relevant, force-modulated genes for mechanistic study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This research program will rationally expand the chemical space of terpenes and terpenoids using mechanistic insights obtained from computaional chemistry experiments, thereby providing new input for the testing and development of terpene-like compounds with potential biological activities relevant to human health. Known members of the terpene/terpenoid class of natural products have anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, analgesic, anti-convulsive, anti-depressant, neuroprotective, anti-allergic, antibiotic, and other activities, and we endeavor to provide compounds with improved and/or altogether new activities that result from their new, previously inaccessible, structures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The conversion of skin cells into therapeutically useful cell types promises new treatments for many diseases. However, most lineage reprogramming protocols are inefficient, and the cells produced often do not fully recapitulate the properties of the target cell type. Here, we propose to investigate mechanisms of cell fate reprogramming using novel experimental and computational genomic technologies. Our work aims to reveal fundamental mechanisms governing cell identity regulation and reprogramming that will be translatable to any cell or tissue type and thus broadly applicable to stem cell biology and regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microbes are a constant presence in our environment and impact humanity in diverse ways, yet we incompletely understand the many ways that our immune system has evolved to defends against pathogens, and the ways that pathogens evolve to avoid or defeat our defenses. This project takes an evolution-guided approach to discover new critical mechanisms that underlie host susceptibility to viral infection by identifying and characterizing human genes that have repeatedly evolved to contend with pathogen infections in the past. Such an unbiased approach will allow us to discover new players in the ongoing conflict between hosts and viruses, and leverage the diversity that is already found in nature to develop ways to diagnose, prevent and treat infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain is a highly-guarded organ with physiological barriers, in particular, the blood–brain barrier (BBB) and the blood–cerebrospinal fluid barrier, limiting access of most drugs. Interestingly, a bug – Cryptococcus neoformans (CN) has adapted special mechanisms to bypass the BBB. Herein, we seek to understand the underlying mechanisms of innate immune cell vomocytosis of CN through combinatorial engineering and biological tools. Therefore, the proposed program is highly relevant to the mission of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS), which pertains to supporting research that increases understanding of biological processes and lays the foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention.

PHR: Project Narrative Loss of gene expression control is a fundamental component of many diseases. My lab uses the model organism Caenorhabditis elegans to study how microRNA-mediated gene repression is regulated in the complex context of a developing organism. The proposed research will advance our fundamental understanding of gene regulation in development and will help address how it goes awry in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  In our cells, our DNA genetic information is packaged with histone proteins into chromatin. Recent studies have shown that histone proteins can be decorated by histone modification enzymes with small molecules or proteins, and these decorations can be recognized by reader proteins to regulate gene expression in normal and diseased cells. Our studies will visualize how different histone modification enzymes and reader proteins associated with stem cells and cancer perform their functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE Asymmetric cell division (ACD) generates diverse cell types and is universally required for development and morphogenesis in multicellular organisms. One fundamental mechanism that controls ACD is cell polarization, which involves the asymmetric distribution of molecules, structures, and functions within a cell. This project aims to establish the molecular and cellular paradigms governing cell polarization, cell division, and cell-fate differentiation during stomatal ACD in Arabidopsis, a system highly amenable to genetic analysis and cell biological examination.

PHR: NARRATIVE Progression through the cell cycle is tightly controlled by changes in the abundance of hundreds of cellular proteins. Cells control protein abundance by regulating their degradation, and mis-regulation of this process causes human diseases, including cancer and neurological disorders. This proposal will address the enzymes and substrates involved, and their collective influence on proliferation and the integrity of our genetic material.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Regulation of gene expression is a critical aspect of many biological phenomena (e.g. cell growth, development of multicellular organisms, the response to environmental conditions, and evolution), and alteration of normal gene regulation can lead to human disease. This proposal investigates fundamental molecular mechanisms of gene regulation at several levels including the relationships between transcriptional elongation, cleavage/polyadenylation (3' end formation), and mRNA stability. The results will continue to shed new light on fundamental issues in gene regulation and will have a significant impact on our understanding of human biology and disease.

The overarching goal is to enable the discovery of new medicines by enabling access to new molecules.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extrachromosomal DNAs have emerged as a key contributor to cancer development and progression but have also been identified in healthy cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project is focused on the molecular-genetic mechanisms associated with the evolution of genetic variation, diversification of phenotypes, and the consequences for organismal fitness. The research will: 1) generate a comprehensive understanding of the rates at which cellular errors arise at the DNA, RNA, and protein levels across the Tree of Life and develop theory to explain the patterns; 2) further establish the Daphnia model system to help understand the evolutionary features of genes involved in key functions such as translation, bioenergetics, environmental sensing, and lifespan determination; and 3) develop theory to explain scaling patterns in the emerging field of evolutionary cell biology and the mechanisms by which cells evolve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proteasome is a central effector of protein degradation, and its malfunction has been connected with numerous cancers and other pathologies, such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s syndromes. The proposed research seeks to reveal how cells generate the proteasome—one of the most complex molecular machines—using rigorous quality control during its assembly. This study contributes to public health by paving the way for exploiting the proteasome, a proven therapeutic target, to develop more directed and specific strategies to combat human diseases with protein clearance problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Bone Morphogenetic Protein (BMP) signaling acts in multiple biological contexts to establish the basic body plan, tissues, and organ systems of vertebrates, including humans, whereas aberrant BMP signaling can cause congenital defects, heterotopic ossification, and cancer. Thus, understanding the BMP signaling mechanism and signaling regulation has direct implications in disease, as well as the use of BMP signaling components in orthopedics, endodontics, tissue engineering, and bone repair. Cell polarity is essential to the normal function of all epithelial tissues and organ systems, and loss of cell polarity underlies cancer metastasis, thus understanding mechanisms of cell polarity establishment, as studied here, is of great significance to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Clinicians and researchers have established clear qualitative correlations between the gastrointestinal (GI) microbiome composition and various aspects of human health. Human microbial ecosystems are tremendously complex and – not surprisingly – are difficult to study at a quantitative level and harder still to manipulate in a prescriptive way. This project will use novel molecular (synthetic) biology tools that will allow us to unravel the detailed interactions and processes that drive the establishment of gut microbiota compositions and their impact on human physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Just as a person’s behavior can be influenced by their surroundings, so too can the functions of individual cells be influenced by the cell’s microenvironment. When cells attach to & ‘sample’ this environment – called the extracellular matrix – they form specialized structures called focal adhesions that not only help the cells attach but also report and control the status of that attachment. This project focuses on a powerful ‘reporting’ or signaling protein, called Protein Kinase A (PKA, for short), that we have recently found is active within focal adhesions, and proposes to investigate what keeps it there, what it’s controlling, and what it’s reporting – all with the hope that by learning more about this particular reporter, we will learn more about how cells are influenced by their surroundings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative RNA can fold into three-dimensional structures that are essential for function and thus play critical roles in cellular biology and disease. Despite their profound therapeutic potential, structured RNAs remain underutilized targets for drug development due to difficulties associated with targeting RNA in a structure- specific manner. To overcome this challenge, the proposed research provides an innovative approach for developing structure-specific RNA-binding reagents, the results of which may lead to novel RNA-targeted therapeutics and new research tools to study RNA biology.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our genomes are packaged inside cells by wrapping around histone proteins to form chromatin. The histone proteins display chemical modifications that regulate genome processes, including gene expression. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this project is to develop new, robust, and versatile mass spectrometry- based tools capable of characterizing complex biomolecular systems and provide structural information, not accessible using traditional tools. The new technologies will be applied to model systems associated with several fundamental biological processes, including gene regulation, DNA repair, replication, transcription, translation, and recombination. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative New mutations often drive evolution of drug resistance in many bacterial pathogens and cancers or are responsible for host-range expansion in viruses, but our ability to predict such harmful evolution is limited because we do not have a fundamental theory of how new mutations affect important microbial pheno- types and fitness. The central goal of this proposal is to develop such a theory. To do so, my lab will construct mathematical models, measure the effects of mutations on intracellular phenotypes in experi- mentally tractable microbes and empirically observe how microbes evolve and adapt in both laboratory and semi-natural environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Project Narrative The coordinated activity of the large families of Protein Tyrosine Kinases (PTKs) and Protein Tyrosine Phosphatases (PTPs) regulates the function of proteins involved in a plethora of cellular processes, and the disruption of this PTK-PTP balance has been linked to the etiology of several diseases. The oxidation and reduction mechanisms that regulate the catalytic activity of members of the PTP family are far more complex than anticipated, and we now have important insights into new modes of PTP regulation by redox molecules that can potentially be leveraged for novel therapeutic approaches that activate phosphatases in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The folding of a genome into specific 3D structures is essential for organizing functional interactions between gene promoters and distant enhancers, but the elements and features that regulate these interactions are poorly characterized. We will develop a series of complementary approaches to functionally identify the genetic determinants of this largely uncharted level of regulation of gene expression, determine how genetic variants within these elements may affect their activity, and ultimately design new ways to manipulate enhancer-promoter interactions. By better understanding the nature and the determinants of the activity of these elements, we will be able to assess the impact of genomic alterations better and predict the physiological consequences of structural variants found in patients.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Using active electronic health records (EHR), the parent grant will develop a Passive Digital Marker for the Prediction of Childhood Asthma Treatment Response to reduce errors in identifying at-risk children and can enable clinicians to scale up treatment decisions that are cost-effective, feasible, and timely. The proposed project will focus on one aspect of the parent project, i.e., adding hematologic markers, an important component of child nutrition and asthma care that may modify treatment response. The proposed project will use existing EHR data on hematologic tests and ML decision-rules- based algorithm from the parent study to assess the role of iron status on asthma treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The bacterial type IV secretion systems are widely used by many medically important pathogens for transfer of mobile genetic elements that harbor genes for antibiotic resistance and for formation of antibiotic-resistant biofilms. These systems also are deployed by many pathogens to deliver virulence factors into the human host to aid in infection processes. The type IV secretion systems are relevant for public health as they represent novel targets for therapeutics directed to blocking antibiotic resistance spread, production of robust biofilms, and disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The past decade has witnessed significant interest in the isolation of “naïve” human pluripotent stem cells that more closely resemble pluripotent cells found in the human blastocyst in vivo. However, naïve human pluripotent stem cells generated with currently available methods display irreversible erasure of parent- specific imprinting, retain an epigenetic memory of the inactive X chromosome in female cells, and are not directly responsive to embryonic lineage cues. This proposal will design rational strategies to resolve this epigenetic instability and establish a robust in vitro platform to model early human development and X- linked disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative: Our research will generate fundamental knowledge on how cells divide, how microtubules are organized and protected from chemical damage, and how neurons maintain viability over decades. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop fundamental chemical insight into the mechanisms of radical initiation and control in radical SAM enzyme reactions. Radical SAM enzymes are remarkable biological catalysts that carry out difficult and unusual chemical reactions; their presence in humans as well as in both beneficial and pathogenic microbes lends high significance to understanding their fundamental properties and mechanisms. With better understanding of radical SAM reactions and mechanisms, these enzymes could serve as pharmaceutical targets to treat infections and/or disease, and as tools to synthesize new bio-derived therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The slow pace of drug discovery is often defined by a limited pool of chemical compounds used to detect drug candidates, and inefficient try-and error approaches to designing and optimizing new ligands. Computational technologies being developed by our group, including V-SYNTHES Giga- and Terra-scale screening and structure based design of ligands with new functional properties, will enable rapid discovery of chemical probes and streamline early drug discovery efforts for challenging targets in key human conditions like pain, drug abuse, Alheimer, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Signaling lipids, such as steroids, terpenoids, and eicosanoids, are critical regulators of animal physiology. However, in contrast to proteinaceous signaling molecules such as peptide hormones and cytokines, modern molecular genetic tools have not been fully utilized for studying signaling lipids. This project aims to fill existing knowledge gaps regarding modes of action of signaling lipids, particularly concerning their transmembrane transport mechanisms, using fruit fly genetics.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding Mass Spectrometry (MS) based omics can allow systematic analysis of thousands of proteins with the promise of discovering new proteins, and biomarkers for various disease conditions and better understanding of human systems biology. Artificial intelligence and machine- learning tools are needed to explain the high-dimensional MS data and such accurate tools will be instrumental in elucidating the microbiome and cell function which affects virtually all aspects of human health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The transfer of protein coding information from our genome to the protein synthesis machinery occurs through a messenger RNA (mRNA) intermediate. Defective mRNA processing contributes to many human diseases including cancer, spinal muscular atrophy, cystic fibrosis and diabetes in complex ways that are poorly understood. This project will improve human health through the identification of regulatory sequences and mechanisms controlling two of the most important aspects of RNA processing, alternative pre-mRNA splicing and mRNA translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Our proposal addresses American Indian/Alaska Native (AIAN) youth suicide, an urgent health inequity that is difficult to address in underserved rural and remote AIAN communities. We test a promising translational intervention that leverages strong social networks in rural AN communities to increase uptake of evidence-based and culturally responsive suicide prevention strategies, with a goal of reducing the risk of suicide and promoting safety and mental health of young people in AIAN communities. This kind of evidence-informed, community-led intervention has potential to scale to other AIAN and underserved communities to address the growing crisis of youth suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cells assemble functionally diverse actin cytoskeleton networks to facilitate a wide range of fundamental processes such as cytokinesis, motility, and polarization. We are investigating how cells simultaneously self-organize multiple actin filament networks at the correct time and place from a common pool of actin monomers and actin regulatory proteins. Understanding the underlying molecular mechanisms that govern actin cytoskeleton self-organization will help elucidate the general rules by which cells assemble and maintain large, macromolecular structures and organelles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability of thousands of cells to coordinate their behaviors is a critical part of healing and regeneration, organ assembly, and even invasive disease. This MIRA takes a ‘rules and tools’ approach to such collective cell behaviors, working to improve both our understanding of these phenomena as well as our ability to control how large groups of cells behave. This work is firmly motivated by biomedical needs, and progress here may help to accelerate injury healing, delay invasive disease progression, and better grow organs for regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The research proposed here uses Drosophila as a model system to investigate the consequences of variation in genome structure by employing state-of-the-art genomics techniques to discover genetic variation previously overlooked by older techniques. Such mutations are often in repetitive regions of the genome and, in humans, are often associated with traits important for human health and well-being, including disease causing mutations (like those often found in cancer or genetic diseases like Huntington's disease) as well as mutations common in disease vectors (like those that confer insecticide resistance in mosquitoes). This research will lead to a greater understanding of how genome structural changes impact evolution and the development tools to enhance discovery of such mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: NARRATIVE Although females have two X chromosomes, each cell keeps only one X active, while the other is inactivated, but some genes are expressed from both X chromosomes in females. Some of these genes are also present on the Y in XY males, who therefore also express two copies, and this group of genes is thought to be lacking in dosage when one of the sex chromosomes is missing (karyotype 45,X), typically resulting in miscarriage. This research program aims to understand why development requires two copies of these genes, and elucidate the mechanisms that enable these genes to remain active on an otherwise inactive X, which is also relevant to other X-linked diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The atomic-level details of lipid/enzyme interactions and the determinants of their specificity remain poorly understood, despite their importance in biosynthesis and modification of cellular membranes, and in the assembly and use of lipid conjugates for essential cellular functions such as glycosylation. By applying a structural biology-based integrated approach to enzymes that are involved in assembly of the peptidoglycan layer and modification of the lipopolysaccharide component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, biosynthesis of the mycobacterial cell well and processes of protein glycosylation, we will gain testable hypotheses on the basic principles of substrate recognition, and on how membrane, membrane enzymes, and lipidic substrates interact to facilitate these reactions. These data should also provide pathways toward new classes of therapeutics targeting lipid/enzyme active sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In the past, humans interbred with archaic humans like Neanderthals and Denisovans, and these events introduced new genetic variation into modern human populations that survives in present-day human populations. The genetic variation that exists in present-day genomes can be studied to characterize whether admixing with archaic humans or with other populations helped humans adapt to different environments. The goal of these research projects is to develop new methods and empirical analysis to boost our ability to address how admixture events in the past have helped humans survive throughout their history.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our research aims to investigate the role of transmembrane receptors, which play crucial roles in essential processes like heart and muscle function, kidney function, and blood pressure regulation. By studying these receptors, we aim to improve our understanding of their function and regulation, focusing on understanding how small molecules, lipids, and protein regulators interact with these proteins and alter their function. This knowledge not only enhances our understanding of cell signaling but also has broader implications for developing drugs to treat various diseases associated with dysfunction in transmembrane receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will result in mechanistic understanding and predictive models of the impact of lipids in drug delivery systems and food on absorption of orally ingested compounds (e.g., drugs, nutrients, toxins). Ingested lipids and food can result in almost ten-fold positive or negative changes in compound absorption, but these effects are currently poorly understood and not possible to predict. The experimental framework and predictive model developed in this project will be useful in streamlining the drug development process, enabling efficient design of oral delivery systems to mitigate a potentially dangerous “food effect” on absorption, or, alternatively, exploitation of the “food effect” to enable oral delivery of compounds that may otherwise require injection, and ultimately replacement of some clinical food effect studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria are home to a wide array of metabolic process and their dysfunction is implicated in many rare and common human disease. However, the nature and cause of mitochondrial dysfunction is often unclear in large part due to the fact that hundreds of mitochondrial proteins have unclear functions. The long-term goal of this proposal is to achieve a more comprehensive understanding of mitochondrial biology and pathophysiology by systematically defining the functions of orphan mitochondrial proteins and their roles within disease-related processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 10% of the 16 million patients >60 years of age undergoing surgery in the United States annually suffer from postoperative neurocognitive disorder (poNCD), which is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. We propose to study molecular and cellular mechanisms and the involvement of specific neuronal and non-neuronal cell types underlying the development of poNCD in aged individuals, and its reversal by increasing the availability of 5-containing GABAA receptors on cell surface membranes and by positive allosteric modulation of 5-containing GABAA receptors using a multidisciplinary approach involving genetically modified animals, viral transduction approaches, molecular biological, biochemical, transcriptomic and behavioral techniques, as well as calcium imaging of defined neuronal populations in behaving animals. The proposed research is expected to provide fundamental knowledge with translational impact, as when allosteric modulators of 5-containng GABAA receptors, which are currently being developed by others for mild cognitive impairment in Alzheimer’s disease with support of the NIH, become available, clinical trials in humans can be envisioned.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcriptional condensates are dynamical assemblies that form via phase separation of disordered proteins and RNAs. However, much is still unknown about their formation, interactions, and effects on chromatin organization and transcriptional regulation. The proposed studies aim to apply computer simulations to systematically characterize biomolecular condensates, evaluate hypotheses on their roles in transcription, and suggest new therapeutic strategies for their modulation.

PHR: NARRATIVE My lab has pioneered work defining the regulation of cell quiescence and elucidating the role of copy number variation in adaptive evolutions. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because the development of new chemical methods will provide new ways to synthesize biomedically important chemicals, including drugs and biochemical tools, and because bioactive natural products can provide starting points for the development of new chemotherapies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal highlights our planned approaches to investigate how dying cells in animal bodies are clearer efficiently through phagocytosis and degradation, using the nematode C. elegans as our model organism. The clearance of dying cells protects humans from the harmful inflammatory and auto-immune responses induced by the contents of the dying cells. Understanding the mechanisms controlling this process will have important therapeutic implications, in fighting chronic inflammatory and autoimmune diseases, and in developing new strategies to target cancer cells for engulfment and digestion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative: Throughout animal biology, cell-cell communication mechanisms are carefully regulated to ensure proper tissue formation and avoid diseases. Our research combines biochemistry, biophysics, and cell biology to learn how a critical family of cell-cell communication molecules known as G protein-coupled receptors operate within the primary cilium, an essential solitary hair-like structure on the surface of nearly all cells. A deeper understanding of these processes will provide insights into how cells send and receive signals to one another, teach us how animal tissues are generated and maintained, reveal the molecular basis for several common human genetic diseases affecting many organ systems, and aid in the development of more effective and durable therapeutic agents for a range of devastating pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  To meet the needs of the growing adult population who manage chronic health conditions, we propose to enhance our clinician-in-the-loop smart environment to prevent and treat condition exacerbations. We will design conformal prediction methods to forecast future exacerbations. Additionally, we will analyze the impact of external events like the COVID-19 pandemic and frequent wildfires on behavior, socialization, environment, and health state. For all of our machine learning tasks, we will train language models from nurse summaries to provide text explanations of observed behavior and machine learning predictions.
