IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a leading cause of preventable death and disability in the U.S., and more than 1.5 million more Americans develop T2D every year. More than half of those new cases could be prevented or delayed if high risk adults were offered resource-intensive lifestyle intervention programs while they have prediabetes. Our proposed center will develop a collaborative network of “sentinel” health systems, National Diabetes Prevention Program and Medicare Diabetes Prevention Program delivery organizations, and experts in natural experimental research using “real world” data. We will collect and harmonize this data and, using rigorous natural experiment designs to identify individual, social, and structural barriers to, and facilitators of, participation in and completion of NDPP and MDPP services and 2) evaluate the long-term effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of structured lifestyle interventions, as implemented under the NDPP and MDPP.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP22-001 A Sentinel Network for Evaluation of the Reach, Implementation, Effectiveness, and Costs of Evidence-Based Lifestyle Interventions to Prevent Type 2 Diabetes in U.S. Adults

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) aims to create a research network of study sites to assess barriers and facilitators for enrollment and sustained participation in the National Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP) and Medicare DPP and to determine the long-term effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the programs. The Coordinating Center (CC) will facilitate scientific collaboration to achieve the program objectives by providing scientific and statistical expertise and logistical and data management support. Specifically, the CC will contribute to the design, development, and management of centralized protocols with common core data elements and will establish study operations to efficiently monitor studies and to collect, manage, analyze, report, and disseminate the research findings.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP22-001 Coordinating Center (CC) for Determining the Long-Term Effectiveness of Real World structured lifestyle interventions in preventing type 2 diabetes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to establish a cohort of overweight and obese adults meeting National Diabetes Prevention Program eligibility criteria who either enrolled (N=5516) or did not enroll (N=7355) in the National DPP between 2013 and 2019. We will reassess their health status 5 years after they enrolled in the DPP or entered the longitudinal cohort to: 1) identify individual and system-level barriers to and facilitators of enrollment in and completion of the DPP and 2) evaluate the long-term effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the DPP in: a) delaying the onset of type 2 diabetes; b) improving cardiovascular disease risk factors including body mass index, hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), blood pressure, lipid levels, and smoking status; c) reducing the incidence of cardiovascular disease including transient ischemic attack, stroke, myocardial infarction, revascularization procedures, and hospitalization for heart failure; d) improving health-related quality-of-life; and e) reducing health care service utilization and cost.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP22-001 Real-world effectiveness of structured lifestyle interventions in preventing type 2 diabetes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed research is to elucidate the role olfactory receptors (ORs) expressed outside the olfactory tissue play in human health and asses their potential as therapeutic targets. Olfactory receptors are a subtype of transmembrane proteins called G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), which are an important therapeutic target. As part of the proposed research, we also work towards understanding how GPCR signaling pathways talk to one another and the consequences of this crosstalk to human health, with the goal of enabling the development of new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dr. Gallagher’s laboratory has provided seminal studies related to epigenetic regulation of immune cell plasticity in the setting of tissue injury in the context of both normal and pathologic states (aneurysm formation, tissue regeneration, sepsis, COVID) for over 10 years. This EIA award will support on-going studies 1) to understand how epigenetic regulation of macrophage plasticity alters abdominal aortic aneurysm development; 2) to understand how JAK/STAT signaling in macrophages regulates chromatin modifying enzymes (CMEs) downstream in a variety of cardiovascular diseases; 3) to understand interactions between structural cells (fibroblasts, smooth muscle cells, keratinocytes) and macrophages in the setting of cardiovascular disease; and 4) to examine the role of epigenetic regulation of macrophages on peripheral atherosclerotic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are widespread racial disparities in the risk of cognitive impairment and dementia, and healthcare utilization among older adults with cognitive impairment. We propose to move beyond individual-level risk factors of cognitive impairment to examine structural racism as an underlying cause of these racial disparities. Findings will guide multi-level interventions to prevent and delay cognitive impairment, as well as policy-makers' decisions regarding possible sectors (e.g., housing, education, labor/economics) in which to intervene to address racial disparities in cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Existing targeted cancer therapies rely on inhibiting or degrading cancer drivers, leading to therapy resistance and subsequent disease progression. While therapeutic approaches that leverage chemically induced proximity have shown promise in overcoming mutational escape, they have largely been limited to degradation approaches, with similar resistance risks as direct inhibitors via epigenetic/transcriptional feedback. In this proposal, I aim to hijack the estrogen receptor by chemically induced proximity to transactivate a pro-apoptotic transcriptional program in breast cancers, to develop and demonstrate a novel targeted gain-of-function cancer therapeutic paradigm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Public Health Relevance. The personally identifying nature of the genomic data create risks of discrimination and stigmatization. We will develop and implement numerous computer-based methods that ensure genomic data is fully protected and the privacy of the participants are intact so that while an untrusted person, such as a genetic testing company, is analyzing data, they cannot directly gain access to an individual personal genetic information. The developed methods can improve public health by enabling the safe usage of the genetic information of patients while the we analyze data, assess risks, and diagnose diseases using genetic data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project will leverage new computational and structural systems biology approaches to provide unified knowledge of the assembly, function and regulation of key transcription and transcription-coupled DNA repair complexes. Unveiling the interplay of molecular-level mechanisms and disease mutations in these complexes will yield foundational understanding of severe genetic disorders associated with cancer, aging, and developmental defects – xeroderma pigmentosum, trichothiodystrophy, Cockayne syndrome and related diseases. Success of the project will thus have major impacts on understanding human disease etiology, opening new avenues to devise effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE:  A subset of T cells, follicular B helper T cells, is necessary to provide help for B lymphocytes in their production of antibodies and autoantibodies in normal and autoimmune responses, respectively. Much remains to be learned about the biology of the former, including the requirements for their maturation and function, and how to interrupt their collaboration with B cells as a potential therapy for autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE or lupus). The results of the proposed studies should help address these issues, and advance knowledge of how lupus develops in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Cocoa products have become a widely consumed food, with growing demand and increasing interest in its anti-aging biology. While the popularity of cocoa consumption remains steady, enthusiasm has outpaced the scientific evidence in humans. Thus, we propose to leverage the large-scale ongoing national randomized clinical trial called COSMOS to evaluate the effect of cocoa supplementation on longitudinal change in biological aging including epigenetic aging and inflammation aging in relation to cardiovascular disease (CVD). Parallel assessments of the randomized multivitamin intervention on the same biological aging and CVD outcomes will be also performed, as multivitamins have remained the most common dietary supplement, taken by at least one-third of US adults. Thus, this study will not only provide valuable insights into the underlying molecular mechanisms for the two popular supplements (cocoa and multivitamin), but also holds great promise for targeting by nutritional interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will provide critical insight into mechanisms by which neuropeptide signaling modulates neural circuits to influence behavior. As neuropeptides and their receptors are druggable targets and their dysregulation is implicated in medical conditions ranging from obesity to psychiatric disorders, mechanistic insight into their signaling is likely to have broad clinical relevance for human health. Understanding how neuropeptide signaling functionally rewires the brain has the potential to uncover novel therapeutic targets for the etiology and treatment of metabolic, sleep, and pain disorders as well as neuropsychiatric conditions characterized by behavioral dysfunction, including depression, autism, anxiety, addiction, and schizophrenia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cells must be able to regulate when they will divide, migrate, or adopt a specialized cell identity. While all these cellular behaviors are important and necessary for an organism to properly develop, their execution at inappropriate times can lead to disease states. Studying the mechanisms that govern when cells should differentiate or migrate will elucidate new targets for the treatment of developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Age is the single greatest risk factor for nearly all of the major causes of death and disability in the United States, including heart disease, most cancers, Alzheimer’s disease, diabetes and kidney disease. The relevance of this Training Program to public health is that we seek to train young scientists in research to understand the fundamental mechanisms of biological aging. It is our expectation that the scientists trained in our program will make significant contributions to improving health through the development of therapies that delay or prevent age-related diseases by directly targeting the molecular mechanisms of aging.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Urea cycle disorders are a group of very rare genetic diseases that cause the build-up of ammonia in the body, which can cause brain damage or death. DNA sequencing of urea cycle genes is used to diagnose patients, but often the test results are not clear because not all genetic changes cause disease. We are bringing together experts from around the world to determine which genetic changes in urea cycle genes cause disease and require treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Integrated load sensing in total knee replacement implants would allow for early warning of load-related failures or other biomechanical problems, but powering such devices is an ongoing challenge. We propose a load measurement system that is self-powered using energy harvested from joint forces during activities of daily living. The goal of this research is to design, manufacture and test prototype self-powered sensors in realistic in vitro loading conditions as a step towards clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our preliminary data suggest that a small family of druggable molecules (Nr4a1-3) can regulate both inappropriate B cell responses to “self” and appropriate antibody responses to vaccines. In this proposal, we aim to define the significance and mechanisms of these effects. This will pave the way for developing new therapeutics to target the Nr4a family in order to suppress inappropriate autoimmune B cell responses (in diseases such as lupus and multiple sclerosis) and to optimize protective antibody responses to vaccination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Heat is a potent environmental and physiological influence on human health: whether in the form of heat illness and exhaustion, or in the form of fevers which we frequently experience in infection. With changing climates and global dissemination of disease, it is ever more critical to understand how heat regulates human biology at the cellular and subcellular level. This proposal investigates how biomolecular condensates and heat shock proteins—two classes of molecular entities that help cells adapt to heat—may enable key human cell types, including immune cells, to sense and respond to heat shock and fever.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of evolutionarily conserved elements of how humoral immune responses are initiated and regulated by antigen dose and dendritic cell subsets is ultimately expected to revolutionize vaccine design as well as treatment of different allergic, infectious and autoimmune diseases. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The innate immune system is equipped with mechanisms such as Toll-like receptor signaling, nod-like receptor signaling, PYHIN family signaling, RIG-I-like receptor signaling and STING signaling, mediates host defense against infections. However, uncontrolled response and excessive production of cytokines are linked to tissue inflammation and autoimmunity and such as inflammatory disease, colitis and lupus. The proposed project addresses the molecular mechanisms of E3 ligase TRIM29 controlling this response, and will lead to high-impact findings with therapeutic implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There continues to be a need to improve the quality and quantity of cancer prevention and control research focused on cancer health disparities, as well as to increase the number of scientists from these underrepresented groups. The overall goal of this T32 Cancer Prevention and Control Training Program Addressing Health Disparities is to facilitate the training of a diverse workforce of cancer prevention and control scientists working in underserved populations to reduce cancer health disparities. This multi-faceted, postdoctoral training experience includes the conduct of a specialized research project, didactic instruction, team science experiences, and individual multidisciplinary mentoring teams of highly experienced and peer reviewed research funded faculty investigators, all to assure the development of quality cancer health disparities researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Fragility fractures are common injuries that have direct implications on patient function and mortality. This proposal uses bioresorbable implants to investigate the effects of gradual introduction of micromotion within the fracture callus in the presence of healthy and compromised bone. These findings will provide new insights into the role of mechanotransduction and clinical standards of care, while establishing a research framework for developing and optimizing implant designs that will improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Current treatments for chronic inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis and inflammatory bowel disease utilize manufactured antibodies to neutralize key inflammatory cytokines, but they possess limitations arising from the need for repeated injections, including sensitization to the biologic drug. In this project, we propose to develop active immunotherapies targeting terminal products of the complement system, which induce a patient to produce their own therapeutic immune responses, potentially solving this issue. This is achieved using innovative supramolecular assemblies of peptides and proteins, which are built in a modular fashion and facilitate the optimization of the strength and quality of the therapeutic antibody response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE SUMMARY We propose the continuation of our pre-doctoral and post-doctoral training program on research in Microbiology and Infectious Diseases. The program, which is entitled “Microbes in Health and Disease”, focuses on training basic and clinical scientists in understanding the beneficial and harmful roles of microbes related to human health. The program will have its intellectual and physical hub in an extraordinary new building devoted to microbial sciences that is located in the heart of the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus, where Microbiology training programs have been ranked the best nationally in 2108.

PROJECT_TITLE: Microbes in Health and Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Aberrant high levels and activity of the c-Myc protein play a key role in cancer formation and progression. This study is to elucidate the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying the regulation of c-Myc protein levels and activity by the deSUMOylating enzyme SENP1, which could yield important insight into how to target the small ubiquitin-like modifier (SUMO) pathway for cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The long term goal of this project is to gain a detailed molecular understanding of nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD) - a cellular quality control process that monitors mRNA integrity and rapidly clears transcripts harboring a nonsense mutation within their protein-coding region. It is estimated that nonsense mutations represent the underlying cause of ~30% of human genetic diseases, but that nonsense-containing mRNA could, in many cases, produce sufficient amounts of functional protein if either the decay of the transcript by NMD and/or extent of premature translation termination was attenuated. Modulation of NMD therefore presents a formative strategy to expand therapeutic options for individuals with inherited genetic disorders due to nonsense mutations, and efforts to develop such therapies would benefit profoundly from a comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying NMD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to identify earlier, and more precisely, which children will develop motor problems later in life in hopes that we can use that information to develop more targeted treatments and create better outcomes for those children. Each year in the United States, 500,000 infants are born preterm (<37 weeks' gestation), putting them at high risk for lifelong neurodevelopmental impairments, including motor disabilities such as cerebral palsy, but we do not yet have a way to predict their individual outcomes and target therapies. This study proposes to investigate a unique, highly valuable cohort of children born very preterm (<30 weeks' gestation) to use data from newborn brain MRI scans and standardized assessments of motor outcomes performed across childhood to build statistical models which accurately predict motor outcomes at the individual level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep is a key process in the maintenance of health; suboptimal sleep contributes to health burden through increased risk for a range of mental health, metabolic, and chronic health outcomes. Environmental exposures, such as air pollution, greenness, and light-at-night, are linked to sleep; due to their ubiquity, modifiable environmental exposures that affect sleep are integral to the promotion of sleep health on a population level. This research aims to address gaps in various aspects of environmental health research on sleep by validating extant mobile health measurement tools for sleep, assessing a possible mediating pathway between an environmental exposure and sleep, and investigating the relationships between multiple environmental exposures and sleep independently and in an exposomic framework.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Research proposed here builds on a new way by which the amount of HIV-1 produced by infected cells is controlled by certain proteins called chemokines released by human immune cells. Interestingly, the genes for this chemokine (CCL2) and its receptor (CCR2) have been previously shown to influence HIV-1 disease – but it was not known why. This application proposes to understand precisely how such chemokines influence HIV disease and develops a foundation for new drugs that can block HIV by targeting the chemokine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project narrative. Infectious diseases and sepsis still remain a major threat to human life. Inflammasome sensing of PAMPs and DAMPs has tremendous implications for human infectious diseases and inflammatory diseases such as sepsis. By uncovering new mechanisms involved in the regulation of inflammasome sensing of PAMPs, the findings from this study could offer new immunomodulatory targets to boost antimicrobial responses and mitigate detrimental inflammatory responses during sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The importance of mechanosensitive channels to human health is underscored by the association of many disease states with compromised mechanosensation, including atrial fibrillation, muscular degeneration, arrhythmias, polycystic kidney disease, and numerous neural diseases. Therefore, it is the goal of this work is to understand both generalizable and cell type specific roles of mechanosensation in regulating gene expression, cellular motility, and cell-to-cell communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  MARC at UAlbany seeks to advance the mission of the NIH and the MARC program to increase the diversity of the pool of biomedical researchers working to address today’s most pressing public health concerns. MARC at UAlbany builds on the incredible diversity of the University at Albany undergraduate student body, track record of excellence in health-related biomedical research, and demonstrated institutional commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion. A structured program of training activities coalesces and augments existing initiatives to offer students traditionally underrepresented in biomedical research careers the individualized team mentorship, academic enhancement, high-impact research experiences, professional skills development, and supportive community necessary for their successful transition into research-focused graduate (Ph.D. and M.D./Ph.D.) training programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative A complex range of psychosocial (i.e., substance use, depression, and stigma) and structural factors (incarceration, poverty) can contribute to racial disparities in HIV diagnoses, prevalence and outcomes (i.e., viral suppression) among Black men who have sex with men (MSM) living with HIV in the Florida, a population that is hard to recruit into biobehavioral HIV research. The proposed K01 application will support an African-American new and early stage investigator to become an independent health disparities researcher and a leader in interdisciplinary research on examining the intersectionality of public health, substance use and HIV, and syndemic research. Specifically, the outlined project will contribute to the identification of subgroups of Black MSM living with HIV in Florida who could benefit from a shared biobehavioral intervention to improve social support and viral suppression based on their shared characteristics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative High expression of NEK2 mediates myeloma cell survival, drug resistance, and bone destruction and is associated with poor patient outcome. We propose to explore how NEK2 promotes myeloma disease progression. We will also investigate the use of combinational immune therapy to prevent myeloma progression and relapse using primary myeloma samples and in vivo mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: At this time of unprecedented growth in scientific discovery and challenges to health, we plan to generate physician scientist leaders to meet the nation’s needs through a training program leading to dual MD and PhD degrees. The program draws on best practices in education and in launching and sustaining careers leading to major research advances and the translation of those discoveries to advance health and combat disease. We seek to train and equip academia, industry and other domains with a superlative and diverse cadre of MD- PhD graduates who will accelerate biomedical progress at the interface of research and clinical medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anopheles mosquitoes serve as vectors for the parasite causing malaria worldwide. This disease causes one of the most significant health problems worldwide, sickening 228 million people and killing over 405,000 in 2018, 2/3 of which are young children — the most vulnerable demographic. This project seeks to develop genetic technologies that would allow to genetically engineer the mosquito population, with the ultimate goal of reducing disease burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because a better understanding of blood epigenetic patterns in osteoarthritis (OA) is likely not only to give insights into the causes of OA, but also to give rise to new biomarkers to assist physicians and researchers diagnose OA patients and predict how rapidly they will worsen over time. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries, innovative research strategies, and their applications as a basis for ultimately improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project provides a new theory that supports a novel mechanistic role for the low abundance membrane localized phospholipid PI(4,5)P2 as a stabilizer of cardiac Cav1.2 channel expression on the sarcolemma. The potent vasopressor Angiotensin II (AngII) is released acutely in the course of normal BP control, and chronically during heart failure as a physiological strategy to increase cardiac output. We propose a mechanism, whereby Gαq-coupled receptor mediated PI(4,5)P2 hydrolysis during this physiological signaling pathway, triggers cardiac CaV1.2 channel internalization, providing a means to acutely tune cellular excitability and modulate EC-coupling in health, but triggering loss of couplons, pathological cardiac remodeling and hypertrophy during chronic stimulation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current therapies for mitochondrial long-chain fatty acid oxidation disorders (LC-FAODs) are only partially effective in heart and not effective in muscle. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Comparative Medicine Program at Cornell University is preparing accomplished and highly motivated veterinarians for discovery-based and public health careers in basic and translational science. By virtue of their broad knowledge of comparative disease and strong intellectual and lateral thinking abilities, veterinarians with advanced scientific training are expected to play an essential role in biomedical science and public health and to promote the NIH goal of developing, maintaining, and renewing scientific human resources that will ensure the Nation's capability to prevent disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This grant supports training of exceptional rehabilitation scientists through a highly integrated, interdisciplinary Movement Science PhD and postdoctoral training program. Our graduates are experts in the study of movement, with work spanning from the basic science level through to clinical application. Individuals trained in the Movement Science Program go on to hold research positions, in academia or industry, and contribute to the science of rehabilitation, its translation to clinical practice and the training of future leaders in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative More than 40% of adults with asthma are obese which leads to increased asthma severity, symptom burden, healthcare utilization and reduced effectiveness of available therapies. This proposal builds on a preclinical and clinical program that indicates glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1RA), FDA approved for the treatment of type II diabetes and obesity, will be efficacious in treating asthma. To validate the therapeutic potential of GLP-1RA in obese and non-obese asthmatics and to address the multimorbidity and polypharmacy plaguing the adult asthma population, we propose to conduct a randomized controlled clinical trial to test the hypothesis that GLP-1RA treatment improves asthma control and reduce airway inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Thyroid cancer patients who are refractory to radioactive iodine treatment have the poorest survival outcomes amongst all thyroid cancer patients. In this context, drug treatments that restore or enhance iodine uptake could significantly improve the treatment of these tumors. This project will develop an assay to study how targeted drugs enhance the ability of tumor cells to concentrate radioactive iodine, which could eventually be translated toward individualizing treatment according to specific patient characteristics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal aims to develop the classic Cope rearrangement into a versatile reaction for preparing complex, bioactive molecules of interest to drug discovery. As described herein, our current and future directions will involve continuing to improve our understanding of this transformation, develop unique, complexity-generating transformations and/or sequences where this Cope rearrangement plays a key role, introduce a variety of catalytic-asymmetric methods for accessing enantioenriched building blocks, and prepare molecules of modern interest to drug discovery; a well-rounded and diverse research program focusing both on fundamental and applied chemical discoveries. ! 1!

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will extend existing and develop new models that use whole-genome data measured in parents and offspring to help disentangle the genetic and environmental causes of parent-offspring similarity on traits. We will deploy these new and existing models on three large, publicly available datasets to (a) elucidate which parental traits influence anxiety, depressive, and attentional symptoms in offspring; and (b) better understand how parental psychiatric illness influences their offspring’s social, physical, and mental well-being.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need for novel approaches to treat pain since current available chronic pain medications are limited by incomplete efficacy, risk of substance use disorder, or other adverse effects. Insights from this project will enhance our understanding of the mechanism of how an omega-6 fatty acid diet modulates nocifensive orofacial behavior. These studies will lay the foundation in a continuum of research leading to the development of novel preventative and therapeutic strategies targeting these lipids and potential proteins in the mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cells are composed of thousands of molecular assemblies – protein complexes – that both define the identity of the cell and carry out its specific functions. Specific defects in protein complex assembly and function also underlie human disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The human voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is an emerging drug target for a variety of diseases, including ischemic stroke, neuroinflammation, and cancer. There is an unmet need for drugs capable of modulating Hv1 activity. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 70% of U.S. hospitals belong to multi-hospital networks. Proponents of hospital mergers tout the potential of hospital consolidation to improve patient outcomes and decrease costs, butevidence that hospital networks actually achieve these benefits is lacking. This project will identify specific network strategies to optimize healthcare delivery that result in improved outcomes and costs, as well as provide insight into how high-performing networks have achieved success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE While recent work has identified a cathepsin K-expressing skeletal stem cell in the periosteum that specifically undergoes intramembranous ossification in vivo, we have discovered that a second cathepsin K-expressing stem cell population exits in the tendon-associated paratenon that controls tendon structure and function. Interestingly, while both stem cell populations also express the collagenolytic metalloproteinase, MT1-MMP, the molecular mechanisms that control stem cell fate in these two populations remain undefined. Herein, we outline a series of new animal models and experimental approaches to define an unexpected role for MT1-MMP – independent of cathepsin K – in defining periosteal and paratenon stem cell fate and function by controlling a novel, dual YAP/TAZ-linked mechanotransduction and TGFβRIII/ TGFβ signaling axis in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: A “graying of America” is projected to occur over the next several years, with the number of older adults expected to exceed the number of children in the United States in 2035, according to the Census Bureau; therefore, research to understand the pathophysiological manifestations of aging and the best way to prevent them is critical. The increase in elderly Americans will also necessitate sufficient numbers of physicians specifically trained in geriatrics to care for them. This application describes a Program for Aging Research in the Summer (PARIS), which will recruit underrepresented minority medical students from Puerto Rico to perform summer research in aging at Augusta University with a long-term goal of promoting interest in aging research and geriatrics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The landmark Institute of Medicine report, “Emerging Infections: Microbial Threats to Health in the United States," noted that roughly 60% of human diseases are caused by zoonotic pathogens. The importance of this observation is exemplified by the current SARS-CoV2 pandemic, underscoring the urgent need for understanding the biology of zoonotic pathogens, including mechanisms of persistence, evolution of virulence, and epidemiology, to predict, prevent and control emerging infections This Infectious Diseases and Microbial Immunology Post-doctoral Training Program specifically prepares a scientific workforce prepared to and capable of addressing critical knowledge gaps in zoonotic infectious diseases and antimicrobial resistance emergence.
PROJECT_TERMS: Communicable Diseases;Immunology;microbial;post-doctoral training;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Infectious Diseases and Microbial Immunology Post-doctoral Training Program
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Microbiology and Infectious Diseases Advisory Committee[MID]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the circuit, cellular and synaptic mechanisms by which the hypothalamic circadian clock regulate arousal is ultimately expected to increase understanding of how wakefulness and associated electroencephalographic rhythms are produced and maintained. As such, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that may yield improved pharmacologic approaches and interventional strategies, and thereby reduce the burden of human disability. This would apply to not only sleep- and arousal-based disorders, such as hypersomnia and fatigue, but also many neuropsychiatric, neurodegenerative and neurological disorders in which arousal is often severely disrupted, including depression and Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This research is relevant to public health and NIH’s mission because it aims to test a highly accessible mobile app behavioral pain intervention (PainPac) compared to a standard therapist led videoconferencing protocol (PCST-Video) for cancer patients with pain. Behavioral pain interventions are not currently widely available to cancer patients. If PainPac is found to be feasible and beneficial for helping cancer patients learn to manage their pain, the mobile app is poised to be widely disseminated ultimately decreasing pain and suffering for patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We will develop deep learning-based models to predict the TCR binding specificity of neoantigens/MHC complexes (immunogenicity). We will predict patient response to checkpoint inhibitors and other forms of immunotherapy based on immunogenicity and other properties of neoantigens. We will build a comprehensive neoantigen webserver, which will facilitate a coordinated effort to accelerate tumor immunogenomics research and clinical applications for personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The breakdown of naïve T cell homeostasis is closely associated with increased susceptibility to infection during aging. However, very few strategies exist to study the mechanisms of long-term T cell maintenance in humans and particularly with age. The goal of this project is to utilize new single cell technologies to elucidate naïve T cell complexity and to develop novel methodologies to study age-related homeostatic decline, which will ultimately enhance immune protection against infections in older individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The roles of specific cell types in complex in vivo biological processes, such as inflammation, are difficult to disentangle. The proposed research focuses on differentiating the requirement for specific signaling pathways in macrophage versus neutrophil function. The goal of this project is to identify specific receptors and effector mechanisms that could be targeted to inhibit the function of single cell types during human disease, in place of broadly immunosuppressive treatments that cause susceptibility to opportunistic infection or organ damage.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rare genetic diseases are collectively a common cause of morbidity in children. Precision clinical management is often hindered by the difficulties in making an accurate and precise diagnosis, even with new DNA sequencing technologies that can scan all genes or even all genetic material (the `genome') at once. Here, we will extend our widely used diagnostic tool Exomiser to meet current challenges and opportunities in pediatrics by adding algorithms for new genomic technologies, analyzing molecular pathways involved in intellectual disability, and providing approaches to analyze groups of unsolved cases to identify novel disease genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will investigate alcohol metabolism in the liver and how alcohol metabolites can be used to modify protein structure (through a modification called acetylation). We will specifically investigate acetylation changes of histone proteins, which play an important role in gene transcription, and how the enzyme ACSS2 is involved in this process. The results of this project will provide novel insight into the link between alcohol metabolism in the liver and subsequent liver injury after long-term, excessive alcohol use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: More than 40% of adult Americans are obese and obesity is common among patients with severe asthma. The objective of this project is to characterize airway physiology and pathology in obese asthma patients to explore the mechanisms by which obesity causes airway disease. In this way we will provide data to help inform novel treatment approaches for these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: This revised Direct Phase II SBIR research project will improve the lives of people by providing researchers with novel and more physiologically-relevant tools and methods for in vitro testing. These tools will be used for testing potential toxicity of drugs and chemicals as well as for developing therapeutic drugs. This research project will use advanced products and methods to produce in vitro human tissue models of human respiratory and skin tissues. These products and tissue models will be utilized by researchers to test consumer products, cosmetics and chemicals for potential toxicity to the skin, and for testing chemicals and products such as tobacco smoke for potential toxicity to respiratory tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Birth defects and skeletal diseases affecting the skull and jaw are a major societal burden. We propose to use zebrafish, a highly regenerative vertebrate amenable to powerful genetic and imaging techniques, to understand how stem cells build and then maintain and repair the head skeleton. The long-term goal is to use foundational knowledge acquired in the zebrafish to develop new regenerative medicine treatments for human craniofacial diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Auditory-guided behavior is ubiquitous in everyday life. The deep layers of the auditory cortex gives rise to a major projection system that exerts brain-wide influence over many downstream regions, providing a putative substrate for such behavior. The proposed studies will monitor and manipulate this cortical output in awake, behaving mice, providing an important first step in understanding how corticofugal circuits govern animal behavior and insight into how descending contributions that may underlie sensory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: HIV reservoirs and meth use grant. M. Stevenson, H. Tookes, PIs. A. Carrico, L Ndhlovu Co-Is Project Narrative This project will assess whether use of meth by HIV-1 infected MSM triggers activation of viral reservoirs and whether this correlates with an increase in HIV clinical disease markers. The project will use novel molecular approaches to assess HIV reservoirs within infected MSM who use meth. This information will provide a fuller understanding of how drug use promotes clinical disease progression in the face of antiviral therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of individuals with opioid use disorder (OUD) smoke cigarettes, and they have less success quitting smoking and higher rates of tobacco-related mortality compared to the general smoking population. Novel cigarette reduction approaches, such as substitution of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) for combusted cigarettes, are urgently needed in this population. This proposal will employ a randomized waitlist-controlled trial with a mixed-methods sequential explanatory design to investigate the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effects of substituting e-cigarettes for cigarettes on tobacco use and exposure (e.g., cigarettes smoked per day, biomarkers, cigarette dependence) in individuals who smoke (not ready to quit smoking) receiving OUD treatment, to help inform tobacco control policy and clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Wnt signaling is a rapidly evolving and important field of investigation and new regulators involved in this cascade are continuously being identified. Our study focuses on developing a mechanistic understanding of PTPRF-mediated regulation of Wnt signaling and intestinal stem cell function. Results from our studies will help identify new therapeutic strategies for treating Wnt-driven diseases by using PTPRF as a target.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop and evaluate a connected health system for upper limb myoelectric pattern recognition-controlled prostheses in which data collected from wearers during everyday prosthesis use and while using a mobile application will be stored in the cloud. The cloud-connected data will be processed using cloud computing tools and presented in a web-based data portal to provide clinicians actionable insights and suggestions for assessments and interventions. Access to objective measures of wearers’ daily prosthesis use and performance will assist clinicians in their clinical decision making towards delivering more effective therapy which will improve rehabilitation outcomes for wearers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative/public health relevance Lumbar spinal stenosis is a common cause of low back pain and disability among older adults. This prospective, inception cohort study aims to develop and evaluate a clinically applicable model to reliably predict long-term function of older patients initiating non-surgical care for symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis. This approach will enable matching these individuals to optimal treatment approaches to provide care that is more effective and of higher-value.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Immunotherapies have potential to provide curative treatment for patients with HNSCCs, but there is a major unmet clinical need to overcome resistance that limits the clinical response rate. We will determine the yet undetermined role of mechanical regulation of monocytes towards developing new strategies to target and re- program myeloid inflammation in HNSCCs. Therefore, these proposed studies will significantly advance fundamental and translational insights on cancer immunology and ultimately impact patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is present in nearly 20% of the mid-life U.S. population, and recent large cohort studies have raised the independent association of CKD with cancers of the urinary system. With elevated rates of cancer-specific mortality and common coexisting risk factors for renal or urothelial cancers (smoking, obesity, and hypertension), mid-life patients with CKD merit evaluation for cancer screening. We will build a simulation model for urinary system cancer screening, accounting for cancer-specific morbidity and mortality as well as competing mortality risks, and include stakeholder input on the acceptability of benefits and harms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative This research will establish how blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) signals in white matter (WM), detected using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), are related to neural activity in gray matter (GM). IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Early-onset atrial fibrillation is a disordered rhythm in the top part of the heart that occurs before 35 years of age and typically requires medical, interventional and/or surgical management. Genetic abnormalities in the atrium may be easier to detect and describe in children, but have implications for a disease that affects millions of adults every year. This prospective, observational study will enroll patients with early onset atrial fibrillation, perform genomic sequencing, and perform clinical follow-up for two years to determine whether genetic substrate is associated with earlier recurrence of atrial fibrillation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will carry out the first unbiased high-throughput exploration of genes governing bacterial DNA supercoiling, an essential property holding great untapped promise for therapeutic manipulation. This exploration will reveal novel factors that dictate the abundance and activity of the two enzymes that control DNA supercoiling: DNA gyrase and topoisomerase I. This project capitalizes on a technological innovation developed in our lab, as well as our track record solving fundamental biological questions using the model pathogen Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium, to shift the paradigm of DNA supercoiling control and identify novel antibacterial targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic studies have and continue to identify a large number of genetic associations with neuropsychiatric disorders, however translating these into causal genes or variants, biological mechanisms, and therapeutic targets remains a major challenge. Here, we develop a suite of computational innovations to 1) determine the shared and distinct genetic components of neuropsychiatric disorders, 2) infer the causal gene networks underlying these components, and 3) model how common and rare genetic variants disrupt these networks. These novel methods will be applied to genotyping and sequencing data from both early onset disorders such as Autism spectrum disorders and developmental delay, and later onset disorders in particular schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome editing technologies like nucleases, base editors, and prime editors may become safe and effective genomic medicines to treat monogenic human diseases either ex vivo or in vivo. Although fit-for-purpose biochemical methods like CHANGE-seq and gRNA sequencing have advantages as highly-sensitive IND- enabling assays for nucleases and base editors, to our knowledge, fully optimized and qualified protocols for use in regulatory submissions are not generally available. Here we propose to optimize and qualify CHANGE- seq adapted for nucleases and base editors, and associated gRNA sequencing, for use in future therapeutic genome editing INDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The phagocytes of the immune system require a rapid burst of energy to fight infections and to clear cellular debris. Our long-term goal is to understand the intracellular signals and machinery that reallocate the metabolic resources necessary for cellular defense against pathogens. Doing so will reveal novel molecular targets and pathways to modify immunological processes for clinical benefit. Toward that end, this application breaks new ground by defining how phagocytes use mitochondrial Ca2+-signaling to fuel cell-intrinsic defense mechanisms against microbial pathogens. The research has the potential to lead to drugs that can enhance our immunity or modulate it, and thus address critical needs in public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Kv3.3 potassium channel regulates the excitability of neurons in the auditory system and cerebellum. Mutations in the gene for Kv3.3 in humans results in disorders of movements and an inability to localize sounds is space. The experiments in this proposal will determine how such mutations alter cellular signaling in auditory neurons and will provide novel therapeutic approaches to counteract the effects of these mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: To meet the challenges in regenerating, repairing or replacing tissues that serve a mechanical function, the Biomechanics in Regenerative Medicine (BiRM) training program aims to provide holistic training to doctoral students in bioengineering to excel in both biomechanics of all relevant length scales and in regenerative biology. The combined strengths of the University of Pittsburgh, Carnegie Mellon University, the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center and the McGowan Institute for Regenerative Medicine make it a unique place for a new generation workforce to be trained in order to meet the critical needs for improving existing as well as to develop novel and advanced therapies in regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Rapid molecular oscillators are important for generating segmental pattern during development, for promoting heterogeneous responses in neural stem cells, and for biasing embryonic stem cells toward different cell fates. We propose to discover new oscillatory genes, uncover their biological functions, and dissect the regulatory mechanisms that govern their oscillatory expression. We propose that our discoveries will impact studies in fields as diverse as stem cell biology, tissue engineering, and even cancer cell biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Cocaine use disorders (CUD) are consistently associated with disrupted processing of non-drug stimuli to dysregulate behavior outside the context of cocaine seeking. Deficits in fundamental behavioral functions such as learning and decision making negatively affect the lives of individuals suffering from CUD, and the severity of these symptoms is strongly associated with disease progression and treatment outcomes. CUDs are at a unique disadvantage when it comes to treatment with no FDA approved therapies, necessitating further research on stimulant use neural dysregulation to produce novel interventions.

PHR: Project Narrative We seek to validate, calibrate, and translate restricted spectrum imaging (RSI-MRI) across vendors to asses in the detection of clinically significant prostate cancer. RSI-MRI is a novel sequence protocol with software post- processing accomplished along with standard of care MRI to improve the quality of prostate MRI imaging. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation is a basic immunological mechanism that helps to protect the host from injury and infection under normal physiological conditions. Pathological inflammation is a pervasive component in many human diseases including chronic infections, autoimmune diseases, vascular and neurological diseases, and cancer. Training a new generation of the brightest scientists in the study of immunology and inflammation will facilitate the understanding and ultimately treatment of multiple diseases of public health importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Myelin is a lipid-rich membrane produced by specialized cells called oligodendrocytes, which wraps the axons of neurons and increases the velocity of action potentials, thereby enhancing the efficiency of long-distance neuronal transmission. Disrupted myelination contributes to many debilitating neurological disorders, including multiple sclerosis and schizophrenia. We propose to answer fundamental questions regarding the mechanisms that control cell-type specific myelination, and test hypothesis on how “attractive” and “repulsive” cues, expressed by neuronal subtypes and on axon compartments, dynamically regulate neuronal interactions with oligodendrocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although RNAs drive a diverse array of cellular functions throughout biology, and are causally dysregulated in many human pathologies, probing the interactions RNA molecules make within cells remains technically challenging. To address this technological gap, in this proposal we will develop a robust and straightforward method for identifying the proteins, RNAs, and genomic loci that interact with a target RNA, that can be easily applied to different RNAs and cellular states. This technology will transform our understanding of RNA interactions across numerous biological settings and diseases, paving the way for paradigm-shifting discoveries in cell biology, and revealing novel RNA-based therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will determine the impact of an acute influenza A virus infection during pregnancy on maternal and placental antiviral immune responses to elucidate the pathogenesis of severe lung injury in a highly relevant nonhuman primate model. These studies are critical for IAV pandemic preparedness to enable testing of efficacy and safety of new universal influenza vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This renewal application proposes training postdoctoral candidates and cognitive neurology fellows researching Brain Aging and Neurodegenerative Diseases at NYU Langone Health (NYULH). There is a critical need to train the next generation of MD and PhD researchers to investigate disorders of brain aging, develop new therapeutics and interventions, and translate these findings from bench to bedside to the community. This training program is housed in the Center for Cognitive Neurology, a school-wide, extradepartmental, multidisciplinary program designed to foster collaborative, translational research at NYULH and will train the next generation of research and clinician scientists in rigorous methodologies and innovative approaches to advance the field of brain aging and neurodegeneration

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Regardless of whether they choose careers in research, medical education or clinical care, medical students who participate in aging research are more likely to pursue careers in aging. The David Geffen School of Medicine at the University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) is partnering with the University of California San Francisco School of Medicine (UCSF), and the University of Washington (UW) to seek continued support for a formal 8-12 week program of training in aging research as well as clinical exposure to aging for medical students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Glutamate-activated NMDA receptors mediate a Ca2+-permeable component of excitatory synaptic transmission in the brain that is involved in learning, memory, and development. NMDA receptors have been implicated in a wide range of neurological conditions, and there is intense interest in the development of allosteric modulators as new therapeutic treatments for neurological disease. This research program is designed to address all key aspects of glutamate receptor signaling, including the structural underpinnings of function, genetic variation as it relates to rare disease and risk factors, identification of therapeutically-relevant molecules that can be used as probes to develop novel treatment strategies, and the fundamental process of synaptic transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Recent studies have identified that proteins that bind RNA to regulate RNA translation, stability or splicing, play key roles in human cancer. We recently identified a group of such RNA binding proteins (RBPs) that are required for the survival of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), a deadly form of cancer in great need of improved therapy. In this proposal we aim to understand the role of one such protein called RBM39, which is a putative, novel, and exciting new AML drug target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We will develop and evaluate an Embodied Conversational Agent – Patient-Reported Outcome (ECA-PRO) smartphone system that engages patients with interactive communication and empathy, while delivering standard PROs in a way that minimizes missing data and enables user- friendly visual sharing of results. The ECA-PRO system will create a strong foundation for PRO- based clinical decision-making. This novel system will be tested as a means to monitor symptoms and adverse events in patients with cancer receiving chemo- and/or radiation therapy, and to monitor medication adherence in patients taking oral medication for breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The UCLA-CMCR has an effective infrastructure for the discovery and development of novel mitigators of acute radiation syndromes (ARS); both hematological (H-ARS) and intestinal (GI- ARS), later radiation pneumonitis and lung fibrosis, and the delayed effects of acute radiation exposure (DEARE) that result in multiple organ disease (MOD) and shorten life span. We have identified numerous mitigators of radiation syndromes and several have been optimized and entered further development. Here, we focus on our existing agents that target highly conserved, developmental signaling pathways and have broad activity against radiation damage to multiple tissues, and explore the potential of these pathways to provide new agents and targets for mitigation of radiation damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Childhood obesity is a major public health problem that disproportionately affects low- income Hispanic children. Hispanic families, especially Spanish Speakers, have been under-represented in studies of childhood obesity treatment, and existing interventions have not demonstrated effectiveness for this group. The goal of this project is to evaluate a novel family-inclusive childhood obesity treatment program designed for low-income and Hispanic, including Spanish Speaking families.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Growth-arrested bacteria display a remarkable resilience to antibiotics and host immune defenses, thereby contributing to the growing burden of antimicrobial resistance. Uncovering the mechanisms used by bacteria to establish a long-term viable growth-arrested state in stressful situations such as during infection of immune cells can serve as a springboard to develop better antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Advanced Training in Environmental Health Sciences program at UC Davis provides unique training in environmental health sciences (EHS) to predoctoral students to prepare them for diverse careers focused on the impacts of environmental factors on human health and disease. This program builds on existing interdisciplinary and collaborative research strengths at UC Davis, with vertical integration of studies at the molecular, cellular, organismal, and population levels directed toward understanding environmentally-induced disease. Trainees will receive a combination of didactic and experiential training to promote understanding of current and emerging concepts, controversies andtechnologies in environmental health, as well as a deep appreciation of responsible conduct of research, including rigor and reproducibility while working with diverse collaborators.

PROJECT_TITLE: Advanced Training in Environmental Health Sciences

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arthritis and systemic autoimmune diseases afflict more than 40 million Americans with pain, diminished functional capacity, and for many a shortened life span. To prepare national leaders dedicated to improving the lives and futures of those afflicted, this program provides advanced clinical and laboratory research training to physicians and scientists specifically focused on these diseases. Training will be accomplished through strong mentorship by experts in the field, specialized didactics, and substantial research projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A striking 83% of adolescents and young adults (AYA) with type 1 diabetes (T1D) have suboptimal glycemic control, placing them at risk for acute and chronic complications. Rigorous research investigating strategies to enhance T1D management in AYAs, prior to the transition from pediatric to adult healthcare, is needed to optimize their health and adequately prepare them for the transition to independence. The proposed intervention includes all key stakeholders (AYAs, parents, and providers) in a multisystem intervention, and is designed to enhance T1D self-management and increase AYAs’ readiness for transition to adult healthcare during this critical developmental period, thus has the potential to inform clinical practice guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Infections caused by Toxoplasma gondii remain a significant cause of human disease in immunocompromised patients, and wide spread chronic infections raise the risk of complications in healthy people should their immune system decline. The immediate goal of our studies is to define molecular pathways that control the entry and exit of the parasite from its host cell. The long-term goal of these studies is to provide fundamental knowledge as a foundation for future development of new therapeutic interventions against toxoplasmosis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dexterous prosthetic hands have the potential to greatly increase quality of life for upper limb amputees. Unfortunately, complicated and outdated control methods limit the potential that the user can access. In this project, we will develop and launch Glide, a novel controller that enables prostheses with greater function and more intuitive control. It is our hope that this will increase the ability of amputees to live independent lives and to work productively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE New drugs that target metabolic pathways have shown promise for the treatment of cancer, but the benefits of these drugs have been restricted to rare patients whose cancers have mutations in metabolic enzymes. We have identified a metabolic pathway whereby normal stem cells and almost all cancer cells produce a metabolite called L-2-hydroxyglutarate (L-2HG) that regulates key aspects of cell identity and function. The proposed research will test the importance of L-2HG in normal blood stem cells and leukemia cells to determine how L-2HG affects cells and whether targeting the L-2HG pathway represents a useful and broadly applicable strategy for treating cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The majority of approved molecularly targeted cancer drugs are either kinase inhibitors or monoclonal antibodies that target cancer-specific molecules. Several lines of evidence have demonstrated that oncogenic transcription factors are both necessary and sufficient to drive cancer initiation and progression. Although targeting transcription factors has proven difficult to date, we propose to build on work that has identified initial inhibitors of a key epigenetic mechanism, histone acetylation, that regulates gene expression. Using a novel high throughput small molecule screen, fit for purpose biochemical and cellular assays, medicinal chemistry and systematic genetics, we propose to identify histone acetyl transferase inhibitors suitable for clinical development and the means to stratify patients most likely to respond to these inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance We propose the development and implementation of an ultra-long acting drug delivery implant for HIV prevention, offering constant, extended drug release, reliable user-independent dosing, discretion and safety for long-term use. The proposed research will increase understanding of the pharmacology of long-acting implantable drug delivery devices and establish the clinical merit of our implant in terms of prevention efficacy and safety of islatravir across different routes of HIV transmission, namely rectal, penile, vaginal, and intravenous. The goal is to maintain effective preventive drug levels systemically for an unprecedented duration of 2 years, advancing the device towards clinical development as a viable, widely acceptable HIV prevention strategy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is a proposal for the competitive renewal of a T32 supported Training Program in Developmental and Stem Cell Biology at the Weill Cornell Graduate School of Medical Sciences. The existing, inter- disciplinary research programs in Developmental Biology, Stem Cell Biology and Systems Biology at the Graduate School are outstanding, highly interactive, and have outstanding faculty and pre- and post-doctoral trainees. To support the next generation of academic leaders in biomedical and translational sciences, it is imperative to provide the highest level of organized instruction through a T32-supported training program in developmental and stem cell biology, tissue differentiation, organogenesis, systems biology, and regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The purpose of this training grant to is provide intensive short-term training in research areas of interest to NIA for 10 selected pre-doctoral medical students in the most outstanding laboratories and training sites in the Yale School of Medicine relating to aging. The specific training experiences will range from fundamental molecular biology, cellular and organ physiology to applied clinical research. The program is designed to attract the most highly qualified Yale medical students into careers as physician-scientists in the biomedical sciences in areas of interest to NIA.

PHR: Project Narrative The rapid emergence and spread of Clostridioides (Clostridium) difficile in hospitals and nursing homes presents a large and urgent threat to human health. We are studying how C. difficile assembles and remodels its cell envelope during growth and division. These studies are relevant to public health because they might lead to new ways to combat C. difficile infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Living kidney donation is the best available therapy for kidney failure patients. However, the medical evaluation process of potential living donors is challenging and lengthy, and access to transplant centers is a key barrier to engagement of potential donors. The goal of this project is to integrate a telemedicine care coordination intervention in the donor evaluation process to enhance engagement of potential donors to complete their evaluation and counseling more effectively and efficiently.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Meiotic recombination is essential for the successful segregation of chromosomes during meiosis, the failure of which can lead to infertility, aneuploidy, genomic instability, and spontaneous abortion. Despite this essential function, recombination rate varies across genomes, populations, and species, and the forces shaping this variation remain largely unknown. This program leverages laboratory evolution and genomics in the model system Saccharomyces to interrogate the genetic and environmental components shaping recombination rate evolution, and the influence of recombination rate on genome evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Zika virus (ZIKV) recently emerged and rapidly spread throughout Southeast Asia, the South Pacific, and South and Central America. In addition to the severe burden of disease and association with congenital Zika syndrome and Guillain–Barré syndrome, ZIKV’s alternative transmission routes such as sexual, perinatal, and potential blood-transfusion transmission are especially concerning. This proposal will apply a revolutionary new strategy to develop a safe, efficacious, single-dose ZIKV vaccine candidate that will be ideally suited to affordably control large outbreaks and protect the health of billions at risk of ZIKV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell immunotherapies have little effect in the treatment of solid cancers due to the tumor’s immunosuppressive microenvironment. We recently developed CAR T cells as delivery vehicles for immune modulators that neutralize immunosuppression and activate broad anti-tumor immune responses. Our strategy is effective with multiple CARs targeting different tumor types, thereby supporting its potential as a universal CAR T cell platform for solid cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Maladaptive processes of uncertainty have been linked to a variety of mental illnesses, including anxiety disorders, behavioral addictions, and schizophrenia. However, it is still unclear what specific computations support this ambiguous notion of uncertainty, how they go wrong, and how these same computational constructs transdiagnostically influence many mental illnesses. In this project, we address these questions in humans by collecting data from a large general population in a novel behavioral paradigm, which allows us to disentangle computations related to two major sources of uncertainty and paves the way for the development of biomarkers related to mental illnesses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Einstein-Montefiore Institute for Clinical and Translational Research’s K12 Career Development Program trains physicians and other health professionals, called Scholars, for careers in translational research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Pattern formation of the pharyngeal arch establishes the identity of cells that give rise to the bone, cartilage, and connective tissue of the face. Disruptions to this process can lead to a variety of craniofacial birth defects. The overarching goal of this project is to elucidate cell signaling pathways that establish cellular identity so that we can better understand mechanisms of development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB), especially multi-drug resistant TB is a major global health problem and causes more than 1.5 million deaths annually. The worst scenario is that some multi-drug resistant TB patients have nonresponsive totally drug resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis and cannot be treated by current multi- antibiotics regimen. This project seeks to combat this urgent public health threat by developing the hits from our recent high throughput screening campaign against bacterial DNA gyrase into new anti-TB antibiotics targeting Mtb gyrase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Infectious diseases continue to extract a considerable individual, social and financial toll on humans due to factors such as the ongoing global epidemic of HIV/AIDS, increasing antimicrobial resistance rendering some pathogens untreatable, and emerging infectious diseases as reflected by the pandemic of coronavirus infection caused by SARS-CoV-2; in fact, infectious diseases represent the leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The training of new scientist-physicians who can elucidate the epidemiology, microbial pathogenesis, and host response to infectious agents is critical for the formulation of new and improved strategies to diagnose, treat and prevent infectious diseases that impact humans.

PROJECT_TITLE: Host Defense Training in Allergy and Infectious Diseases
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Allergy, Immunology, and Transplantation Research Committee[AITC]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PD-1 is an immune inhibitory receptor that down modulates immune responses and has been a successful pharmacologic target for certain cancers; however, complications arising from disruption of normal immune function are sometimes observed, suggesting that novel approaches are needed. One approach could involve the manipulation of PD-1 gene expression in human T cells, but to do this, the transcriptional and epigenetic mechanisms regulating PD-1 gene expression in humans, which are not well characterized, must be defined. This application seeks to provide an in-depth analysis of the mechanisms that regulate PD-1 gene expression in human T cells, information that could be ultimately used to manipulate its expression.
