IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Major risk factors for melanoma include fair skin and a history of sunburns, yet incomplete understanding of how different skin pigments and types of ultraviolet sunlight (UVA, UVB) contribute to melanoma progression has hindered efforts to curb disease incidence. In this application, we will use models genetically representative of human melanoma to determine how different skin pigments and forms of UV light contribute to melanoma progression. This work will identify deficiencies in the biological mechanisms that protect us from the sun, which could be mitigated to improve melanoma prevention strategies and patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiovascular diseases such as atherosclerotic vascular disease, is the leading cause of death. Current studies suggest that persistent inflammation is an important driving force in the progression of this vascular disease. This project will provide a new understanding of age-related mechanisms that contribute to why inflammation is not controlled and will provide new avenues for the treatment of atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Columbia University proposes to consolidate their three NIEHS T32 training grants into a single, unified program. Trainees will pursue training in mechanisms of disease, environmental epidemiology, or climate and health. All students will receive foundational training in the study of health throughout the life course, the exposome, and data sciences, which will prepare them to solve major environmental health science challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The major limitations of DNA targeting drugs that are used in clinics today for treating cancer include life threatening toxicity, acquired resistance and occurrence of secondary cancers. These problems mostly stem from the ability of DNA targeting drugs to indiscriminately bind to cellular DNA or other non-DNA macromolecules resulting in DNA damage. In this proposal, we provide compelling evidence that development of new DNA interacting drugs that display high sequence/region specificity, do not directly damage the DNA and take advantage of DNA-related processes that tumor cells use but not the normal cells could have favorable therapeutic outcomes. We propose that a novel DNA targeting drug that we have recently developed meets these criteria and therefore, will not only inhibit tumor growth but will also will enhance the efficacy of the current targeted therapy and prolong survival of the breast cancer patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The current proposal will investigate the relations between developmental changes in white matter fiber bundles and functional responses to faces using a multimethod approach with infants. We will draw a full picture of brain organization and sensitive periods underlying face processing ability identifying developmental changes in structure-function coupling. The results of these studies will constitute a premise for the examination of changes in the cerebral architecture resulting from specific training with faces.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to improve weight loss treatment outcome for adolescents with overweight and obesity. Extant treatments for adolescent obesity do not take into account the aberrant decision-making processes that characterize adolescence and contribute to problematic eating behaviors. The proposed study will investigate aberrant decision-making as a predictor of treatment outcome for adolescent obesity, providing direction for treatment development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the mounting genetic discoveries for neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders (NPD), effective treatments remain beyond reach due to a lack of understanding of the pathophysiology of NPD. This proposal seeks to establish an Assay and Data Generation Center (ADGC) within the framework of the NIMH Scalable and Systematic Neurobiology of Psychiatric and Neurodevelopmental Disorder Risk Genes (SSPsyGene) Consortium. Our ADGC will generate data from ~200 high-confidence NPD risk genes on multiple genetic backgrounds, including understudied African American iPSC lines, to enable robust inferences of potential cross- disorder and cross-population biological convergence relevant to NPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Dysregulated NLRP3 inflammasome signaling causes detrimental pathologies of the expanding spectrum of sterile inflammatory diseases, including Cryopyrinopathies, Gout, Silicosis, Asbestosis, Atherosclerosis, Diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, Cancer, kidney dysfunction and others. However, the mechanisms that control this NLRP3 inflammasome response are still poorly understood. In this application, we propose to define a novel identified NLRP3 binding partner, which is absolutely required for NLRP3 inflammasome activation specifically in human macrophages, which may provide novel targets for developing improved therapies for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The gut is a key immunological organ, where host-microbe interactions shape both local and systemic immune tolerance. Prevailing immunological views conflate the two organs that comprise the gut—the small and large intestines (or SI and LI)—yet recent evidence from our labs, and others, suggest that T cells infiltrating the SI and LI utilize unique sets of ligand-regulated nuclear receptors (NRs) to tether key regulatory functions, including IL-10 expression, to discrete bile- and microbe-derived metabolite classes. In this proposal, we use both agnostic and targeted approaches to interrogate the mechanisms by which NRs execute T cell regulatory functions in the SI vs. LI, thus laying a foundation for understanding compartmentalized immune regulation in the gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  More than 100 million new skin scars appear annually in the United States, and scars may cause severe emotional distress and physical disability. Although many products are marketed for scar prevention, their results are modest. If successful, this project will generate major new insights into the cellular and molecular mechanisms controlling scar formation and skin regeneration in mammals and identify new strategies to prevent scar formation in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Laparoscopic surgery is the standard of care in high-income countries for many cancer procedures but is largely inaccessible in low- and middle-income countries. We describe a multi-disciplinary collaboration between biomedical engineers, surgeons, oncologists, global healthcare delivery teams and business developers to move a low-cost and durable laparoscopic system to the next stage. Construction of the laparoscopic system will be demonstrated in Uganda, its clinical performance will be tested in a clinical First-in- Human study and regulatory approval will be achieved to bring this system to commercialization in Uganda.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Using a multidisciplinary approach we will combine centralized immunogen design with TMV conjugation and plant-based expression systems to create a novel universal influenza vaccine candidate. We will test these approaches in a systematic series of experiments that examines immune correlates of protection, protection against lethal influenza challenges in both mouse and ferret models, and vaccination in the context of pre- existing anti-influenza immunity. We are confident that this approach will lead to a single immunization with a universal vaccine that provides life-long protection and eliminates influenza virus infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We propose an ESCC diagnostic strategy comprising a single-use swallowed retrievable sponge-capsule to collect esophageal cells for biomarker analysis, coupled with a portable microfluidic chip device for automated POC sample processing and DNA methylation detection. This strategy does not require endoscopy (EGD), can be administered in rural settings without the need for electricity or persons with medical training, and uses a portable analytic chip. The sponge is cheaper, less invasive, safer, and faster than EGD; the microchip integrates DNA extraction, bisulfite DNA conversion, and methylation analysis into a single POC device.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Due to the opioid crises in the United States, many pregnant women are using opioids or are treated with opioid maintenance therapy drugs like buprenorphine. Buprenorphine exposure during pregnancy and parturition may alter the endogenous opioid regulation of the maternal brain network, which could explain the reduced maternal care and increased offspring mortality and altered long-term outcome of the offspring that is observed in animal studies. Our translational rodent model will help illuminate consequences of gestational opioid exposure for the maternal brain, maternal care and the gut-brain axis and explore interventions to help improve the health and outcome of mothers and their offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The lack of clinically available tools for identification of bone abnormalities in patients who undergo spine fusion surgery contributes to high rates of complications after surgery. This prospective study will investigate a new technique, based upon standard clinical MRI scans, to detect abnormal bone in patients before surgery, monitor changes in bone and predict complications that occur after surgery. The long-term goals of our research are to improve identification of patients at high risk for complications after surgery and provide knowledge that will help plan follow-up treatment studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: No practical noninvasive antemortem test exists to detect cervid, human, or any, prion disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physician-scientists are uniquely suited for the bidirectional translation of basic science research and clinical medicine. With the exponential increase in biomedical knowledge, the proliferation of new technologies, and the aging of the biomedical research workforce, the need to train diverse physician-scientists who can capitalize on these advances to improve prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of disease is greater than ever. The Medical Scientist Training Program at UT Southwestern Medical Center is helping foster the next generation of physician-scientists who will improve human health through biomedical research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will provide timely methodological advancements to efficiently and accurately analyze histopathological information using deep learning models. The results of this study will remove current methodological and computational bottlenecks in the application of deep learning technologies in digital pathology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative New understanding of microbiome communities have shifted paradigms on what determines eukaryotic host health. We seek to understand how microbiomes assemble, what drives microbiome community succession and strain evolution, and how microbiome network structure confers stability and host homeostasis. We seek to understand these question by harnessing the microbiomes of microbes because with this understanding we might gain new insights into how microbiomes fail in disease, ultimately leading to new insights into how microbiomes can be modulated to develop microbiome-based therapeutics.

PHR: Project Narrative: Clinical manifestations of unwanted immune response against proteins are autoimmune conditions, food allergies and immunogenicity against therapeutic proteins. Our long-term goal is to address this medical need, by inducing tolerance towards protein antigens in a directed and specific manner. The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission of seeking fundamental knowledge to enhance human health and relevant to public health because the proposal addresses an unmet medical need and is focused on developing novel clinical approaches to reduce and reverse such unwanted immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Adolescent/young adult kidney or liver transplant recipients have unacceptably high rates of immunosuppressant medication nonadherence and, thus, are at elevated risk for nonadherence-related organ rejection, graft loss, or death. Our research involves (1) validating a new, non-invasive Real-Time Adherence Measure based on real- time adherence data easily downloaded from electronic pillboxes to accelerate provider identification of when nonadherence puts patients at risk for rejection, and (2) designing and pilot testing an innovative just-in-time adaptive mobile health intervention, leveraging real-time electronic pillbox data to support in-the-moment adherence at the point of medicine dosing. Both of our clinical tools have immense public health potential for improving medication adherence, reducing nonadherence-related health problems, and improving health-related quality of life among AYA kidney or liver transplant recipients and for other people taking daily medicine for chronic illnesses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is a uniformly fatal disease that is closely associated with the accumulation of insoluble, potentially toxic protein aggregates within motor neurons. The goal of this work is to understand how the enzymes within lysosomes - "the recycling and disposal compartments of the cell" – are able to clear out these old proteins and how impairments within this organelle may contribute to motor neuron degeneration. This understanding could promote the development of rational therapeutics aimed at stabilizing or reversing lysosomal dysfunction in ALS to prevent motor neuron death and preserve motor function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial site-specific vanadium dependent haloperoxidases (VHPOs) are a unique family of halogenating enzymes that oxidize aqueous halide ions and install them in a regio- and stereospecific manner on organic substrates. This proposal merges interdisciplinary chemical, biochemical, and genomic techniques to identify novel VHPO homologs from diverse microbes, characterize their roles in secondary metabolism and chemical ecology, and define the structural determinants of halide and organic substrate specificity. By expanding the characterized VHPO repertoire, we will provide new biosynthetic tools for the construction of biomedically relevant small molecules and biocatalytic alternatives to conventional organic chemistry halogenation strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Researchers-in-training in biomedical fields, particularly those from underrepresented groups, contend with a number of barriers to their career success. In the proposed project, we plan to address the Triple Threat to trainees’ career success (impostor phenomenon, fixed mindset, and perceived discrimination) by developing and testing dual interventions—one for trainees and one for their mentors—that directly target and mitigate these threats. These dual interventions, which will not only address trainees’ coping skills but will also foster environmental change via their mentors and training program directors also trained to deliver the interventions, are designed to be scalable and sustainable over time, with the goal of increasing retention of all underrepresented groups in the biomedical research pipeline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapies represent a powerful therapeutic paradigm because they are applicable to a wide variety of tumors and can produce durable clinical responses; however, only a fraction of patients experience clinical benefit from current immunotherapies, and as such there is an urgent need to develop new therapies. Our studies will focus on the immune cells underlying the resistance to current immunotherapies. Uncovering novel aspects of the immune system is crucial not just for better understanding the biology of the immune response to tumor, but also for designing the next generation therapeutics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic mutations underlie cystic fibrosis (CF) and other respiratory lung diseases that are global public health burdens. This study seeks to use a gene editing technique to correct a mutation causing CF and to investigate the role of understudied CFTR mutations in the development and progression of lung disease. Findings from this work will inform the diagnosis and treatment of genetic lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The integrity and long-term function of tissues demand the presence of immune cells to preserve health. We have recently found that neutrophils, the most abundant innate immune cell in the organism, infiltrate most organs under homeostatic conditions and tailor their molecular properties and functions for each particular organ. Under this grant we will explore the molecular programs that drive neutrophil specialization in tissues, mechanisms of action, and their relevance for vascular and barrier integrity of organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research proposed here will systematically quantify the effects of craniofacial transcription factor dosage changes on molecular, cellular, and morphological phenotypes. This work will provide: (1) mechanisms underlying sensitivity to transcription factor dosage in normal-range and disease-associated variation, (2) insights into the specific facial phenotypes observed in a range of craniofacial syndromes, and (3) basic insights into the mechanisms of transcription-factor mediated regulation. Finally, by driving forward our understanding of craniofacial variation and disease, the proposed research will nominate key genes and pathways that one day could inform disease prediction and/or therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intellectual disability (ID) disorders lead to difficulties in the educational, social, and financial realms for those affected and their caregivers. Defective neuronal translation is common theme found in ID, neurodevelopmental, and neurodegenerative disorders. Using a combination of genome wide approaches, we will characterize the effects of ID-associated mutations on a class of histone modifying proteins essential for translation in neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is characterized by progressive breakdown in the circadian system, which regulates 24-h cycles in a number of homeostatic processes such as sleep, hormone release, and immune function. The immune system is critically regulated by the circadian system and trafficking of immune cells into the central nervous system is an understudied area implicated in regulating AD. Here we propose to determine circadian regulation of the brain-immune interface, how dysregulation of circadian rhythms contributes to AD-pathology, and whether strategies to boost circadian rhythms protect against brain aging and AD, with the goal of unveiling novel, translationally-relevant insights into the mechanisms mediating AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  While it is well documented that some individuals show vulnerability to cognitive decline with advancing age, the mechanisms that lead to this decline are unknown, and no interventions to rescue brain function in aging individuals exist to date. The proposed studies explore the association between aging-related degradation of circadian rhythms, blood-brain barrier function and neuroinflammation as potential culprits to vulnerability to cognitive decline. We apply a novel lighting treatment we developed that rescues degrading circadian rhythms to recover cognitive functioning and brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research aims to develop novel statistical methodologies for longitudinal integrated mechanistic modeling of multiview data, including environmental, *omics, imaging, and neurocognitive data. The proposed methodologies, developed and applied to alcohol & neurodevelopmental and Alzheimer's disease research, are expected to elucidate longitudinal variations in brain structure and function, to characterize population hetero- geneity, to enhance understanding of disease pathology, to help identify biomarkers, and to provide guidance on personalized early prevention/intervention strategies to promote well-being in adolescent and elderly popula- tion. Therefore, the proposed research will seek fundamental knowledge in integrated analysis for improving our understanding of neurodevelopmental/neurodegenerative trajectories and related mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fatigue is one of the most prevalent and debilitating symptoms among male cancer survivors and has a negative impact on their quality of life. These patients also have a greater prevalence of testosterone deficiency compared with healthy age-matched controls. Pivotal trials of testosterone replacement therapy in non-cancer patient populations have shown an improvement in fatigue in men randomized to testosterone compared with placebo; however, the efficacy of testosterone replacement therapy on cancer-related fatigue has not been studied. This large randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial will determine the efficacy of testosterone replacement on cancer-related fatigue in young male cancer survivors who report fatigue and have testosterone deficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Our ability to study the brain during development, aging, how it changes through learning, or during disease progression is fundamentally enhanced through our ability to make genetic constructs and viral products for genetic manipulation of neuronal circuits and to carry out functional and behavioral validation in the whole animal, tissue slices or culture systems followed by in vivo or post-mortem imaging. The Stanford Neuroscience Research Center (SNRC) for Human Brain Organogenesis (HBOP), Behavior (BFNL), Gene Vectors (GVVC), and Microscopy (NMS) was created to meet these needs. Here we aim to centralize and disseminate these fundamental tools and techniques with annual workshops and 6 annual integrated free of charge pilot studies for merit-based selected projects for external laboratories from the national neuroscience community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Targeted monoclonal antibodies have become essential for use as both life science tools and as clinical therapeutics. Although there are currently several methods for producing antibodies, including hybridomas and in vitro immune display libraries, the process is laborious, costly, and inefficient. Screening these antibody libraries requires iterative rounds of affinity screening and cloning without functional validation, which is typically post-screening against a limited number of antibody clones. To improve the efficiency of this process, we propose this Phase II study using a fully automated method for functionally screening hundreds of thousands of primary B-cells from immunized animals on the high throughput CellRaft-HTS array and automated CellRaft AIR® System. The CellRaft Technology allows imaging-based sorting and isolation of single cells and clones, thereby allowing sophisticated phenotypic characterization to be incorporated into antibody discovery screening workflows.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  The NIGMS has asked for plans to create new tools and technologies that will allow researchers to ask new questions, questions that they might not even think of asking without these tools. We provide such a plan here, to deliver a technology platform that will create molecules that covalently modify, tag, and destroy protein targets that are chosen by researchers and clinicians to solve scientific, diagnostics, and disease management problem. This platform has been sought without success for over 40 years, because it can be applied to every area of medical research, diagnostics, and disease treatment. As just four examples, modification may attach a payload to the protein, allowing it to be internalized to cancer cells. It may fluorescently tag cancer cells to guide a surgeon cutting out a tumor. Its tagging capabilities will help neurobiologists map the brain. For researchers, modifying the targeted protein, researchers will test hypotheses about the role of that protein in biology, both natural and diseased.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall—Project Narrative  Our proposed renewal, the Health, Aging and Dementia in South Africa: A Longitudinal Study (HAALSI) Program, aims to assess the biological, social, and economic factors and public policies that interact to influence the course of dementia and cognitive decline among older adults in South Africa, as well as major diseases and disorders (cardiometabolic disease and HIV) that impact cognitive function. We build upon our existing HAALSI cohort of older adults embedded within the well-characterized Health and Demographic Surveillance System (HDSS) of Agincourt, South Africa, which will provide 13 years of in-depth follow-up, establish a new nationally representative cohort, and conduct detailed dementia assessments within subsamples of each cohort using the Harmonized Cognitive Assessment Protocol (HCAP). We seek to implement approaches to the study of dementia and other health and aging related disorders that are valid, reliable, and harmonized with global studies of dementia and aging, in a country where little research has been done on a population basis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This research addresses the public health concern of metastatic breast cancer, a major cause of breast cancer related deaths in women and treatment is largely reliant on systemic therapies that have adverse side effects. This project will provide a detailed understanding of the cellular underpinning of metastatic cells and provide novel approaches for preventing or reducing metastatic burden. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to improving outcomes for patients with metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Retinoic acid, a physiological active derivative of Vitamin A, controls multiple processes during embryonic development in a concentration-dependent manner. Dysregulation of retinoic acid concentration results in numerous developmental defects and congenital diseases, but the mechanism responsible for establishing the correct spatiotemporal pattern of retinoic acid concentration is not known. The studies proposed in this application will test a hypothesis that the retinoic acid concentration pattern is controlled by a unique antagonistically bifunctional retinoid oxidoreductase complex that dynamically regulates the output of retinaldehyde, the immediate precursor of retinoic acid.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Anxiety disorders ̶one of the most common mental health conditions in the US and globally ̶increase the risk for depression and suicide in adolescence and adulthood, with levels of symptoms increasing dramatically during early adolescence, especially in girls. This longitudinal study will examine the effects of pubertal hormones on the development of brain circuitry implicated in emotion regulation in early adolescent anxious boys and girls and test to what extent these effects are linked to sex differences in increases in anxiety symptoms and levels of threat reactivity in a real-world context. Results from this study will provide important new information about brain changes during puberty that could lead to the discovery of sex-specific targets of intervention grounded in neurodevelopment thereby maximizing efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Endothermic animals including humans need to maintain their brain temperature steady while their interior body temperature changes during exercise or intake of hot or cold fluids. Critical for survival during prolonged exposure to extreme thermal conditions, the brain temperature has to be maintained even when thermoregulation of peripheral body parts becomes difficult. Having identified the first molecular marker for temperature-sensitive neurons in the preoptic area of the anterior hypothalamus, we propose to elucidate the functional circuitry of central neurons in the brain, for monitoring brain temperature changes and mediating homeostatic thermoregulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: HUNTSMAN CANCER INSTITUTE PROJECT NARRATIVE Huntsman Cancer Institute (HCI) at the University of Utah is the only National Cancer Institute-designated Cancer Center in Utah and the vast area of the five-state Mountain West; HCI effectively promotes research and public policy to address pressing needs of this region, particularly the special cancer burdens of rural/frontier populations. We care deeply about the next generation of cancer researchers and have implemented a portfolio of programs, including special initiatives for rural and disadvantaged youth. Through the Cancer Center Support Grant, we will make high-impact scientific discoveries across basic laboratory; clinical; and prevention, cancer control, and population-based research, and disseminate these findings to improve outcomes for individuals impacted by cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Black older adults and their caregivers in the United States are unduly burdened by poor health outcomes related dementia. Black immigrants are poised to make up a significant portion of the Black older adult population and are at risk of poor health outcomes related to dementia, similar to U.S. born Black older adults. The present training and research will directly facilitate the development of interventions that meet the intersecting cultural and social needs of Black immigrants with dementia and their caregivers, which is an important first step towards improving their health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: In pancreatic cancer, 95% of patients possess mutational activation of the KRAS oncoprotein, leading to persistent activation of the RAF-MEK-ERK mitogen-activated protein kinase cascade. Our studies have targeted this pathway as a strategy to create a dependence on autophagy, which we can subsequently co-target for the treatment of KRAS-mutant pancreatic cancer. We propose studies to facilitate further clinical advancement of novel combination anti-autophagy strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Oligodendrocytes play an important role in a number of brain injuries and neurological diseases. This proposal details an innovative in vivo imaging technology to explore how these cell types cause negative tissue responses to intercortical microelectrodes in the cortex. Transgenic indicators, electrode design, pharmaceutical intervention strategies, and gliomodulation technologies will be examined to improve oligodendrocyte health and recording performance over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed project is to address the gap in current research on public perspectives about ethical best practices and the impact of Artificial intelligence-enhanced Clinical Decision Support (AI-CDS) on the trust of the public. We propose to focus on policy and practice options such as certification, notification, and product labeling related to essential, endemic issues in the AI-CDS ecosystem: transparency, privacy, equity, non- maleficence, accountability, and utility (Aim 1 and Aim 2). For Aim 3, we evaluate key attributes for product labeling and an accompanying multi-dimensional metric of trust reflective of the Food and Drug Administration's system of categorizing software used as a medical device.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will test an implementation strategy that seeks to align system, organization, and clinic leadership and strategies to implement and sustain an evidence-based practice (EBP) for substance use disorders. The Leadership and Organizational Change for Implementation - System Level (LOCI-SL) seeks to improve implementation leadership, climate, provider attitudes and behaviors, and EBP fidelity for enhanced client engagement in services and outcomes. LOCI-SL will be tested in a large, statewide, integrated mental health and addiction service system through clinics in community mental health centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research investigates different types of non-canonical molecular events expressed in RNA that can change the sequence of genes and spark abnormal disease-causing proteins. By developing innovative computer algorithms for analyzing population-scale datasets, we will systematically detect these previously unexplored events and highlight their functional relevance to health and disease. We will distribute the developed tools in open-source software packages to benefit the scientific and biomedical communities.

PHR: Project Narrative Extracellular vesicles are shed by all cells in the body into the blood and so provide a unique opportunity for monitoring the tumor microenvironment with liquid biopsies. We propose developing an ultra-high-throughput droplet-based multiomic profiling platform, Vesicle Epitope Transcript sequencing (VET-seq), that can simultaneously resolve the surface proteome, internal proteins, and broad RNA spectrum with single vesicle resolution. The proposed technology will be of high value to the fundamental and clinical oncology communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of modern oligosaccharide synthesis is the efficient production of natural and unnatural oligosaccharides, and their mimetics, capable of interfering constructively in disease states. This interference may be brought about by the blocking of oligosaccharide processing enzymes, by disruption of bacterial cell wall biosynthesis, by modulating cell-cell recognition, by enhancing binding and selectivity of drugs to DNA, and by the provision of antigenic oligosaccharides in synthetic vaccines. All of these processes require the highly efficient synthesis of oligosaccharides. The goal of this project is to provide a deeper understanding of glycosylation reaction mechanism, and to apply that understanding to i) the design of new and improved methods for the synthesis of biologically-relevant glycosidic bonds, and ii) the design of improved glycosidase and glycosyl transferases inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Fragile X is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability and autism. Herein, we will examine the link between altered signaling pathway activity and robust deficits in mitochondrial pathophysiology in a Fragile X animal model and in patient derived cells. The goal of these studies is to determine if the mitochondrial and associated metabolic phenotypes displayed by the Fragile X models are due to established signaling pathway defects that are known to underlie the behavioral and cognitive phenotypes displayed by the Fragile X animal models and are ameliorated by treatments being used in ongoing clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This is the fourth competing renewal of the Pitt Integrated Clinical and Geroscience Research Training Program T32 with an overarching long-term goal to produce a new generation of investigators committed to performing collaborative aging research across clinical, translational, and basic sciences. The University of Pittsburgh offers an outstanding milieu for this training, with exceptional depth and breadth of multidisciplinary aging research; experienced, involved, and well-funded mentors; and extensive resources for training in aging research across the clinical, translational, and biological perspective. The training program – one of only a few in the nation to train within an integrated clinical and biological perspective – focuses on two levels of trainees: 1) a 2-to-3-year postdoctoral program for physician investigators and postdoctoral fellows and 2) a 2-to-3-year predoctoral MD/PhD training program integrated into the University of Pittsburgh School Of Medicine Medical Scientist Training Program and select other Pitt predoctoral students with career interests in multidisciplinary aging research.
PROJECT_TERMS: Clinical;Geroscience;Research Training;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Pitt Integrated Clinical and Geroscience Research Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent advances, largely technology-based, are improving the diagnosis and management of cancer. However, despite a need, individuals from underrepresented groups and cross-trained in cancer biology research and metabolic studies are rare. The CMTP T32 postdoctoral training program addresses this need by providing a unique learning experience focused on cutting edge training in translational cancer metabolism research with exceptional institutional support for stipends, research funds and research environment. In this, the pipeline of cancer metabolism-talent and breakthrough discoveries will be enriched, locally at COH and beyond to patients worldwide.

PROJECT_TITLE: Cancer Metabolism Training Program

PHR: Overall Narrative The SBDRC enhances research in cutaneous biology at Northwestern University and throughout the U.S. by providing networking and learning opportunities, advanced technology for performing studies, and shared data, thereby attracting new investigators into skin research. The Administrative Core, with its Enrichment, Pilot Grant, and Diversity-focused Programs, and the Research Cores will foster cooperative interactions among scientists and between scientists and clinicians, which will translate into innovative research, discovery, and ultimately better health care for patients with skin diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to improve cervical cancer (CC) screening rates for Indigenous women by using an innovative mobile web app intervention called wPap. Specifically targeting Indigenous women living on the Yankton Sioux Tribe Reservation in South Dakota, the project will develop and evaluate the efficacy and feasibility of the theory-driven, culturally-tailored, multilevel, and multimedia wPap intervention. By offering a low-cost and easily replicable alternative to existing interventions, the project seeks to increase CC screening rates, reduce cancer-related health disparities, and enhance health outcomes for underserved Indigenous women at both local and national levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This proposed Autoimmunity Center of Excellence, comprised of the Massachusetts General Hospital Rheumatology Division and the Ragon Institute, highlights the power of translational research that can occur when thoughtful and engaged clinical investigators team effectively with innovative basic researchers. Because IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD) and giant cell arteritis (GCA) are fundamentally different conditions with regard to pace of disease and urgency of treatment, the designs of the Primary and Alternate Clinical Projects are geared to reflect these differences, underscoring the depth of clinical understanding that our group has for these conditions. The Collaborative Project, based on work from our group that builds upon a new human model of autoimmune fibrosis, points the way to new understanding of the relationships between autoimmunity and fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Persons with serious mental illness (SMI) experience one of the largest health disparities in the U.S., dying 10 to 20 years earlier than the overall population, primarily due to cardiovascular disease. The proposed Center to Accelerate Translation of Interventions to Decrease Premature Mortality in Persons with SMI will study implementation strategies to scale-up effective interventions to address cardiovascular risk behaviors (unhealthy diet, physical inactivity, tobacco smoking) and risk factors (obesity, hypertension, diabetes and dyslipidemia) among persons with SMI, with an explicit focus on health equity, partner engagement, methods innovations, and building capacity amongst researchers and community partners to enact our Center’s mission – to advance health equity so that persons with SMI can live long healthy lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoiesis is the process of formation of all blood cell types in our body and is essential for our physiology and survival. Developmental origins of hematopoietic cells are established, but the molecular mechanisms of blood formation are less defined. This proposal establishes a crucial family of epigenetic modifiers (Tet enzymes) as key regulators of blood formation during development. Findings will expand our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of blood formation, with implications for treatment of blood disorders where Tets are mutated or dysregulated, as well as for generating blood cells from pluripotent cells for clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Native Americans in Oklahoma endure a disproportionate burden of colorectal cancer incidence and colorectal cancer-specific mortality, which is partly explained by poor rates of follow-up diagnostic colonoscopy after an abnormal home stool test. The proposed study aims to co-develop and pilot test a culturally sensitive digital outreach intervention to increase motivation, reduce structural barriers, and, thus, improve rates of diagnostic colonoscopy. This study offers a substantial public health impact to reduce avoidable CRC morbidity and mortality among Native Americans, and will provide valuable insight on how to scale culturally sensitive digital outreach interventions across our Tribal partners in Oklahoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Mental Health, Earlier ALACRITY Center addresses a key development driver of the youth mental health crisis: 1 in 5 children have a mental health diagnosis by the age of 3 but existing evidence-based tools and approaches have failed to be systematically implemented in routine primary. To achieve population reach, the proposed Center advances scalable approaches to pediatric primary care-based early mental health promotion via targeting toddler transdiagnostic behavioral vulnerability at the preclinical phase to impact lifespan mental health. The Center's unique equitable implementation framework, tools and strategies are poised to foster mental health equity, promote resilience, and reduce the public health burden of early-onset severe mental health problems for children and families with diverse lived experience, with innovations including quantitative tools for bias reduction, digitally delivered prevention for increased access, ongoing integration of community partner priorities and values, interactive provider training to improve confidence in developmentally-based decision making and accessible strategies for bridging the screening to services gap via heightened family engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed T32 Integrated Mental Health Fellowship is designed to train clinician scientists who are interested in improving the quality of mental health care delivered in primary care, medical subspecialty, and school-based clinics. Faculty supervisors will include senior investigators in the University of Washington Departments of Psychiatry, Pediatrics, Family Medicine, as well as Kaiser Permanente Washington Health Research Institute, and the Puget Sound VA Health Services Research and Development (HSR&D) Center for Innovation. Postdoctoral fellows will engage in mentored research and receive training in biostatistics, epidemiology, health services research, and implementation science through coursework, seminars led by program faculty from two NIMH-funded P50 Centers, one-on-one mentoring, statistical consultation, journal clubs, grant writing bootcamps, and a weekly works-in-progress seminar.
PROJECT_TERMS: Fellowship;Mental Health
PROJECT_TITLE: Integrated Mental Health Fellowship

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  A goal of the proposed Core Center for Musculoskeletal Biology and Medicine is to facilitate translational discovery, moving laboratory advances into the diagnosis and treatment of human musculoskeletal disease. The Center is organized to reflect the spirit of the broad, interdisciplinary mandate of NIAMS: to develop ‘cross- cutting’ research that integrates many disciplines and involves the interplay and collaboration of a diverse array of specialists from both basic and clinical areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The overall purpose of these studies is to determine the relationships between early adolescent nicotine exposure and later abuse of methamphetamine. Understanding this relationship will allow for the discovery of new interventions that can prevent methamphetamine abuse. Additionally, this proposal will include adolescent female rats a group often ignored in preclinical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed short-term research traineeship program provides a pathway for pre-doctoral students in the clinical field of audiology to expand their knowledge of research and foster development of a research mindset. Completion of this research traineeship will facilitate progression towards a career in research as a clinician scientist. Supporting an increase in the clinician-scientist workforce will benefit society by ensuring a strong future for discovery and advances in hearing health and patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By 6 years of age 73% of Alaska Native (AN) children in the Yukon-Kuskokwim (Y-K) region of southwestern Alaska have had a full mouth dental reconstruction (FMDR), requiring general anesthesia for extensive early childhood caries. Data indicate only 12% of Y-K children have an oral exam by age 24 months; in contrast almost 80% obtained standard childhood vaccinations. We propose a mixed methods comparative clinical effectiveness trial to study whether the use of care coordinators to educate caregivers and to assist in coordination between well child visits and dental visits at ages 0-24 months increases the proportion of children who receive oral health exams and interventions and reduces the incidence of ECC in AN children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project proposes to conduct research examining autism spectrum disorder (ASD) assessment practices and processes provided to Diné (Navajo) parents/guardians of children ages 2-6. The research will identify how ASD assessment practices align/misalign with Diné parent/guardian cultural beliefs; describe practitioner perspectives on how assessments are conducted with Diné children; and examine the cultural responsiveness strategies used by interdisciplinary assessment teams. The research findings will be used to develop guidelines for improving ASD assessment practices and processes for Diné parents/guardians and their children.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Precision Medicine Initiative Cohort Program will enroll one million volunteers into a national Biobank that broadly reflects the diversity of the U.S. population and help accelerate progress toward a new era of precision medicine on a larger scale than previously possible. The proposed Biobank will be a valuable resource of biological specimens and related health information from human volunteers that can then be used to address a wide range of scientific questions to improve public health. Mayo Clinic proposes to provide a state-of-the-art infrastructure and cost-effective services to ensure the success of the Precision Medicine Initiative Cohort Program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because asthma, increasing in prevalence, represents a major national cost measured by both patient suffering and economic burden. Our studies proposed will provide a conceptual framework linking the environmental pollutant/allergen exposure, AhR signaling, ROS generation, and ox-CaMKII to mast cell activation and asthma development. In the long term, these studies may reveal novel therapeutic targets for allergy and asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 1.5% of the practicing ophthalmologist in the US are under-represented minorities. Increasing the number of minority practitioners would improve access to eye care in underserved communities as these physicians are more likely to practice in these communities than majority physicians. Recruiting more under-represented minority medical students to the field of ophthalmology and supporting these already in residency programs will help decrease health disparities in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative This application seeks funding for an Initiative for Maximizing Student Diversity Award to support the recruitment and training of predoctoral students from diverse backgrounds with the overall goal of increasing the pool of PhDs from under-represented minorities who engage successfully in biomedical research and research-related careers. Our program structure and activities are designed to bring together and train under-represented predoctoral students - including IMSD trainees and non- trainees - from across the biological/biomedical graduate programs on the flagship Rutgers-New Brunswick campus. Our training program adds IMSD-specific program elements to existing institutional and graduate program-specific initiatives in order to enhance student success and performance and at the same time improve career preparation and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL – PROJECT NARRATIVE The Multicenter Osteoarthritis (MOST) Study has been a major source of new knowledge about the course of OA and factors that affect it, having published over 180 articles providing insights into OA causes and consequences, and serving as the basis for 31 career development awards to date. We will use an integrated approach in the next cycle of MOST (MOST4) overseen by an Administrative Core, involving a Clinical Data Collection and Management Core, Analysis Core, and Imaging Core, to efficiently address key knowledge gaps through the conduct of three Projects that will examine impairments in response to exercise in knee OA, and its risk factors and consequences; synovial fluid proteomics to gain insights into localized versus generalized OA phenotypes; and the relation of intra-articular mineralization and of different crystal types to knee pain, inflammation, and OA structural pathology. This work will produce new actionable insights regarding pain, structural deterioration and function loss in knee OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiotherapy regimens continue to be delivered using a “one-size-fits-all” paradigm and therefore do not currently take into account the genetic content of individual tumors. Our results indicate the primacy of Nrf2 and Braf as regulators of radiation resistance in non-small cell lung cancer. The deliverables of this proposal include new biomarkers calibrated on the basis of radiotherapeutic efficacy and new drug-radiation therapeutic strategies that more precisely and effectively target the most resistant lung tumors to radiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe pneumonia is characterized by an increased bacterial burden, exaggerated host immune response, and cellular damage in the lungs, and is a leading cause of death worldwide. There is an urgent need to better understand host defense mechanisms in the lung, with the goal of yielding new therapies to improve pneumonia treatment. Our proposal directly addresses this need by investigating and employing Factor B — a complement protein that is an important part of the host immune response for killing pathogenic bacteria — to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with pneumonia by leveraging its ability to protect the lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A severe complication of influenza infection is secondary Staphylococcus aureus, and previous data has shown that type I interferons produced during influenza infection result in a defective bacterial immune response. Type III interferons are a more recently discovered family of interferons that share signaling pathways with type I interferons. This project will determine the role of type III interferons in impairment of the immune response against secondary bacterial infection by decreasing lung macrophage function and subsequent type 17 immune induction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Orthodontic relapse is one of the most challenging and ubiquitous problems in the field that leads to negative treatment outcomes for orofacial aesthetics, oral functions, and increases the risk of dental disease as well as the health care cost burden. Biologic therapies that mitigate this response have shown promise in animal models, but the lack of appropriate drug delivery systems has precluded their translation. The experiments outlined in this application will elucidate the use of anti-osteoclastic OPG administered for local and sustained release via an osteoconductive hydroxyapatite drug delivery system to mitigate relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Projective Narrative The objective of this proposal is to characterize the microbiome-gut-brain axis in individuals with AUD. Specifically, this proposal seeks to evaluate the relationship between gut dysbiosis, clinical phenomenology of AUD, and a brain-based biomarker in individuals with AUD and matched controls. This study has important clinical implications as it will provide the first data linking the gut-brain axis to AUD in a single sample of human participants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is a public health crisis with no disease-modifying treatment, so prevention is key to reducing its prevalence. The proposed research will elucidate the extent to which infection with Herpes Simplex Virus Types 1 and 2, Cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr Virus, Toxoplasma gondii—measured four times over ~25 years—and SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19) are associated with subsequent cognitive and functional decline and diagnoses of mild cognitive impairment and dementia, measures of Alzheimer’s disease pathology from blood samples, and accelerated biological aging. Results will advance our understanding of whether common infections increase the risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias and how they might do so.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to establish a new national training program designed to increase the size of a highly skilled, successful, and diverse behavioral and biomedical workforce. We will do so through workshops that train researchers who work in a variety of venues to transmit essential professional skills to trainees at their home institutions or scientific societies. Those skills will include preparing grant proposals and manuscripts; securing and maintaining jobs; teaching and mentoring; time, stress, and conflict management; and the responsible conduct of research. Special emphasis will be placed on ensuring that the instructors, the workshop participants, and the participants’ trainees include both ethnic diversity and people with disabilities. Careful evaluation of our effectiveness will occur throughout.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer vaccines based on peptide tumor antigens have been shown to be an effective treatment option for various cancer states. However, challenges in the delivery and protection of these peptides from degradation and clearance have severely limited their clinical utility. This proposal seeks to address these challenges by utilizing a novel peptide delivery system that allows for the protected delivery of tumor antigens, either alone or in proportion-controlled combinations with multiple different antigens and immunomodulatory compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative While an infectious etiology has been proposed to be involved in Alzheimer’s disease, more evidence is needed. We have found that intestinal Bacteroides can increase amyloid-beta plaques in animal models of Alzheimer’s disease, and will now test whether AD patients harbor Bacteroides strains that can contribute to AD. Through the identification of novel pathogenicity factors for AD, this research may lead to new strategies to prevent and treat AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rett syndrome (RTT) is a neurodevelopmental disorder with a high mortality rate caused in part by respiratory dysfunction. RTT is caused by mutations in the gene encoding methyl-CpG-binding protein 2 (MECP2) and evidence suggests MeCP2 regulates expression of astrocyte Kir4.1 channels; however, it is not known how loss of MeCP2 or Kir4.1 channels disrupts breathing. This project seeks to identify astrocytes and Kir4.1 channels as the cellular and molecular basis for breathing problems in a mouse model of RTT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While HIV persistence in resting T cells has been extensively characterized, the role of HIV in brain myeloid cells (BMC) as a reservoir and as a source of rebound upon cessation of antiretroviral treatment (ART) is yet to be determined. Using CNS tissues from 20 participants enrolled in the Last Gift cohort (an ongoing rapid autopsy study), we will determine the role of BMC: (i) in the maintenance of HIV reservoir across the CNS with different ART and opioid penetration, (ii) as a source for HIV dispersal, and (iii) in inflammation-induced neurological damage. This will provide new insights for the development of strategies to effectively clear HIV infection and lessen HIV-associated neurological damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most disease-associated genetic variants are suspected to act by regulation of expression of a nearby gene, yet in most cases these regulatory effects have not yet been identified. One challenge for efforts to map these disease loci to target genes is that their regulatory effects are often highly context-specific, varying between cell types or tissues. This work will use a human embryoid body system to study an expansive array of dynamic contexts involved in cellular differentiation, revealing novel dynamic genetic regulatory effects on gene expression and improving our ability to map disease loci to target genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerosis is the most common underlying cause of cardiovascular disease and is characterized by unresolved chronic inflammation of the vessel wall. Despite the availability of efficient low-density lipoprotein lowering therapies, there remains substantial residual inflammatory risk. As there are no approved therapies limiting the inflammation that contributes to plaque development, we propose to explore the role of the IRG1- itaconate axis in regulating the immune environment within the atherosclerotic plaque, which can be leveraged to treat atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in a novel way.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Based on our extensive preliminary data we now believe we have determined the degradation event that may underlie nuclear pore injury loss that occurs early in the pathogenesis of ALS/FTD. Our preliminary experiments suggest that this novel disease pathway can be pharmacologically manipulated. Thus, candidate ASO therapy could be useful for C9orf72 ALS/FTD patients. Furthermore, the pathological reduction of nucleoporins that make up the nuclear pore complex are present in a substantial subset of sporadic ALS patients and nuclear pore complex injury is a common feature of diseases caused by mutations in specific nucleoporins, Alzheimer’s disease, and Huntington’s disease. As a result, therapeutic targeting of nucleoporin and nuclear pore complex degradation and CHMP7 has potential to extend far beyond C9orf72 mediated disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The major -hemoglobinopathies, sickle cell disease (SCD) and -thalassemia, are two of the most common monogenetic diseases. Although gene therapy by CRISPR gene editing and lentiviral gene delivery have been shown to correct the -globin gene mutations in SCD and -thalassemia, initial clinical efforts have shown low correction frequencies or have resulted in the serious side effects of anemia, leukopenia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, or a combination. Harnessing techniques of targeted protein degradation against transcription factors critical in the -globin to -globin switch, namely BCL11A, ZBTB7A, and ZNF410, to reactivate -globin expression and fetal hemoglobin expression is a novel therapeutic avenue towards developing much needed treatments for sickle cell disease and -thalassemia.

PHR: The mechanisms used by the immune system to control bacterial infections is incompletely understood. We propose that metabolic intermediates, namely aldehydes, are used by the immune system to kill Mycobacterium tuberculosis and possibly other microbial agents. This proposal will identify sources of metabolic aldehydes that can control bacterial growth as well as bacterial pathways that affect susceptibility to aldehydes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE These studies will utilize cutting-edge molecular and genetic approaches to dissect the mechanisms controlling the function and differentiation of Age/Autoimmune-associated B cells (ABCs), an emerging B cell subset whose expansion has recently been associated with the development of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), a prototypical systemic autoimmune disorder characterized by autoantibody production and multi-organ involvement. Since peripheral expansion of ABC-like cells in SLE correlates with SLEDAI and specific clinical manifestations, in particular lupus nephritis, and since ABCs from SLE patients are the major producers of autoAbs, understanding the molecular mechanisms responsible for their regulation and differentiation will provide critical information into SLE pathogenesis and help uncover novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) has caused over 32 million cases of Coronavirus disease (COVID-19), with greater than 1 million associated deaths to date. Though vaccine trails are ongoing, the correlates of viral clearance and immune protection from SARS-CoV-2 are unknown. This proposal seeks to understand how innate immune signals drive adaptive immunity to SARS-CoV-2, with the goal of identifying fundamental immunologic rules that govern SARS-CoV-2 immunity to promote development of highly effective vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will expand upon the ongoing activities of the DC Cohort, a population-level longitudinal cohort of over 10,000 people living with HIV (PLWH) at 15 clinics in Washington, DC. We will 1) enhance the Cohort database to incorporate new data sources to comprehensively describe and monitor HIV and co-occurring conditions; 2) expand the use of the existing DC Cohort Clinical Dashboard to monitor HIV care outcomes as well as key indicators related to ending the HIV epidemic; and 3) use the Cohort as a platform from which to develop pioneering interventions to improve the quality of care of PLWH. The Cohort is an unparalleled clinical, research, and public health resource to assist in monitoring the local response to the HIV epidemic and to generate lessons learned for other urban areas of high HIV prevalence in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Narratives: Stroke remains a leading cause of disability in the United States. Despite recent advances, interventions to reduce damage and enhance recovery after stroke are absent. In this proposal we will investigate a novel drug target “Purinergic receptor P2X4” for the treatment of ischemic stroke in mice. The overall goal of this proposal is to determine if reduction of acute P2X4R response is a viable therapy for stroke in elderly, working towards our long-term goal of developing and identifying target-based therapies for stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NHGRI Sample Repository for Human Genetic Research facilitates studies of human genetic and genomic variation by establishing, characterizing and distributing a large and diverse publicly available collection of biospecimens obtained from human populations living around the world, including the prominent 1000 Genomes Project cell line and DNA collection. We propose to continue Coriell’s record of excellence in the management, maintenance and global distribution of this critically important genomic resource, and we are also proposing several new innovations that will increase the value and impact of the resource to ensure that the NHGRI Repository collection remains relevant and meets the growing needs of the scientific community. We plan to further diversify the NHGRI Repository collection with the addition of new sample submissions collected for the Human Pangenome Reference Consortium, and the development of an unprecedented collection of induced pluripotent stem cells that will include a wide range of human genomic diversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance Successful completion of the proposed project will increase the usability and accuracy of our publicly available segmentation tools, and open up new possibilities, such as integrating them into the MRI scanner and rapidly detecting Alzheimer’s-related changes. These new capabilities well enable other studies to significantly increase their ability to detect AD and other disease effects in research settings as well as phase II and phase III clinical trials due to the radical increase in speed of the new tools, enabling them to be applied to a diverse set of MRI contrasts and much larger datasets, rapidly and accurately. Further, they will allow rapid application of cutting-edge analyses to the ongoing Alzheimer’s Disease NeuroImaging Initiative dataset, improving the ability to extract early biomarkers of this devastating disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Acid-sensing ion channels (ASICs) sense extracellular pH and are potential drug targets for stroke, neurodegenerative disorders and pain. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal addresses the mechanisms by which cells coordinate two of their major cytoskeletal polymer systems, septins and actin, to promote intracellular transport and cell morphogenesis. Elucidating these mechanisms will advance our basic understanding of fundamental, conserved biological processes mediated by septins and actin, and how they go awry in a broad array of human disease states caused by mutations in actin, septins, and their regulatory proteins, including cardiovascular disease, renal and immune disorders, cancer, deafness, and autosomal dominant neurological disorder Hereditary Neuralgic Amyotrophy (HNA).

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVDs) represent a major public health crisis in our Nation. This research proposal aims to test a novel anti-atherosclerotic nano-therapy to treat the underlying causes of atherosclerotic plaque formation, while protecting the vascular endothelium. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The loss of sleep's neuroprotective properties is a major risk factor for the development of Alzheimer's disease, and recent reports suggest that measuring age-related changes in sleep activity may indicate risk of Alzheimer's disease and identify potential targets for novel Alzheimer's disease therapies. Our preliminary data suggest that components of sleep's role in memory processing — termed theta bursts — indicate risk of cognitive decline among aging adults and may be a key connection between sleep and Alzheimer's Disease. Here, we propose to further investigate relationships between changes in theta burst activity during sleep's memory processing and cognitive changes among aging adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hyposalivation is directly associated with radiation therapy, which is administered every year to approximately 60,000 head and neck cancer patients in the United States. Hyposalivation contributes to oral microbial infections and impairs activities of daily living (e.g., speaking, chewing, and swallowing) and current treatments for this condition are limited to medications that induce saliva secretion from residual acinar cells and the use of saliva substitutes. However, given that these therapies target relatively surface-level symptoms and provide only temporary relief, development of alternative treatments to restore gland function is essential. This project aims to design a scaffold (consisting of fibrin hydrogels linked to basement proteins and growth factors) and apply it into damaged salivary glands (with the aim of forming new tissue and recovering lost secretory function).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial Fibrillation (AF) is the most common arrhythmia affecting 46 million people globally. More relevant in vitro models of the condition are needed to identify novel preventative therapeutic targets to curtail the steady increase in prevalence. Our human induced pluripotent stem cell derived atrial cardiomyocytes, cardiac fibroblasts, and decellularized extracellular matrix based engineered heart tissue incorporated into our collaborator’s Cell-in-Gel platform has promising potential to accurately recapitulate AF development and allow us to elucidate the mechanisms underpinnings afterload-induced AF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: High-risk neuroblastoma remains an incurable disease with an urgent need for the identification of novel therapeutic targets and design of novel therapeutics. In our preliminary studies, we used a CRISPR-based knockout screening and identified CAMKV kinase, a novel member of serine/threonine kinase (CAMK) family, as an important mediator of an oncogenic signaling pathway in neuroblastoma cells. In this research proposal, we aim to determine the role of CAMKV kinase activity in neuroblastoma development in mouse models and the therapeutic potential of CAMKV inhibition by knockout/knockdown as well as its small molecule inhibitors for treating neuroblastoma and overcoming chemotherapy resistance in preclinical animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The activation of CD8 T cells against pathogens and tumors requires the activity of a specific type of dendritic cell, called cDC1, which captures antigens that interact with the T cell receptor of the CD8 T cell. However, cDC1 must first be “licensed” in order to be able to activate CD8 T cells for effective responses against pathogens or tumors. The process of DC licensing is incompletely understood, and our published and preliminary data indicate that our current models are incomplete. This proposal aims to define novel pathways activated by Batf3 and CD40 signaling responsible for DC licensing and the cell types capable of initiating this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Advanced age is accompanied by weaker and more fatigable limb muscles making it difficult for older men and especially women (≥65 years) to generate the power necessary to perform daily activities. The proposed studies will address this issue and identify potential sex differences by determining whether the greater fatigability of older adults performing dynamic contractions is due to impaired skeletal muscle bioenergetics and/or vascular dysfunction. Furthermore, we will conduct a clinical trial testing the effectiveness of coupling high-velocity resistance exercise with blood flow restriction of the limb to improve function, power and fatigability in older men and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Prolonged injury to the pancreas causes pancreatic fibrosis and is associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer. We recently discovered that pancreatic stellate cells, which are the source of fibrosis, react to pressure through the mechanically-activated ion channel, Piezo1. The current proposal will determine if blocking Piezo1 prevents stellate cell activation and protects against pancreatic fibrosis. These studies could lead to new therapies for chronic pancreatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: In recent years, severe outbreaks and epidemics of Ebola, Lassa, and Zika have illustrated how vulnerable the world is to threats from RNA viral pathogens. To counter the dangers posed by these viruses, we must develop flexible and scalable technologies for diagnostics, surveillance, pathogen discovery and transmission, and deploy them in the most outbreak-prone regions of the world. Here, we will establish the West African Research Network for Infectious Diseases with partners in the United States, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Liberia, and Nigeria, to develop effective strategies, and deploy the necessary tools, for detecting, mitigating, and preventing future outbreaks from emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE IgE sensitization to house dust mites and other indoor allergens is associated with development of asthma, a disease that affects 26 million people in the U.S. Monoclonal IgE antibodies specific for asthma-associated allergens will be isolated for the first time as they occur in vivo, to analyze IgE antibody epitopes on group 1 and 2 mite allergens and their associated IgE antibody repertoire. The goal is to elucidate the importance of the intrinsic properties of these allergens on their role in causing allergic disease, and to produce hypoallergenic mutants that will be tested for B and T cell reactivity, to generate information that will facilitate a rational design of mite allergy vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trans-ancestry genetic analysis can facilitate genomic discoveries and is critical for equal delivery of precision healthcare globally. However, current trans-ancestry genetic research is impeded by limited genomic resources for non-European populations and inadequate statistical methods that can appropriately model and analyze data from ancestrally diverse populations. This project will address these challenges by aggregating and harmonizing data from large-scale biobanks across the globe, and developing novel statistical methods that can integrate data from multiple populations for improved trans-ancestry genetic studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies will investigate a novel aspect of prohibitin (PHB) in that the function of this important protein is dictated by the cellular environment. This form of functional regulation is directly related to its role in the ischemic neuronal injury and on mitochondrial functions. The findings will advance our understanding of the fundamental processes governing neuronal survival and death through regulation of mitochondrial functions, and have the potential of identifying mitochondria targeted treatment strategies for stroke and other neurological diseases linked to mitochondrial dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will develop a single LC/MS-based platform that allows for discovery proteomics as well as the targeted analysis of immune system-relevant protein groups requiring less material and less time than previous methods. Such assay will enable us to establish molecular immune profile with hundreds of protein analytes even from the most vulnerable populations such as premature newborns or frail elderly adults, for whom samples availability is often extremely limited. These immune profiles of unprecedented resolution will enable faster response to challenges to the immune system such as infections and will inform a more rational approach to designing vaccines that work in all age groups.
