IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The US continues to grapple with an opioid epidemic, with close to 70,000 opioid overdose deaths in 2020. This project will test whether combining machine-learning based overdose risk prediction tools with simple behavioral ‘nudge’ interventions in the electronic health record can improve clinician prescribing behavior to reduce overdose risk. If successful, the project will demonstrate how risk prediction can help target low cost and scalable interventions to reduce overdose risk, opening the door to larger scale implementation and substantial public health benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Oral drug delivery via the mucosal route is considered to have practical advantages, including reduced need for trained medical personnel, cost efficiency, and increased safety. While progress has been made increasing stability and innate activation of potential mucosal drugs, significant knowledge gaps exist at the intercellular and intracellular levels, which leaves poor understanding of the specific and non-specific factors determining recognition and transport of drug candidates across the intestinal epithelia. The proposed research is relevant to the NIBIB's mission because that understanding how nanoparticles-based oral drug delivery systems transport through intestinal epithelium and how the transport behavior can be manipulated through surface modification to create guided transport pathways through intestinal epithelium will provide fundamental and essential knowledge on future design and development of effective drug delivery systems for oral administration.

PHR: Project Narrative This project examines the genetic and molecular mechanisms responsible for the diversity of living things. This diversity includes variation within a species as well as between species. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MARC at the University of Colorado Denver prepares undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in the biomedical sciences for doctoral programs in academic biomedical research through skills-based in-class learning and on and off-campus research experiences. Diversity in the Ph.D. workforce in higher education and research settings contributes to biomedical advances, to economic growth in a global, knowledge-based economy, and to addressing the needs of underrepresented communities regarding health-related research. Programs that are wholistic (knowledge, research, communication, professional, and wellness skills-based) and interdisciplinary (including behavioral and biomedical focuses) can best prepare future scientists with sophistication and resiliency in research careers that study and address complex health challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Diffusion magnetic resonance imaging (dMRI) has a unique ability to non-invasively characterize microstructure and long range connectivity in brain tissues with coherent organization, such as white matter (WM), but has been less effective in more complex tissues that lack such coherency, such as gray matter (GM). This has limited its potential in detection and characterization of widespread but often subtle brain GM and WM changes associated with Alzheimer's disease and its related dementias (ADRD), Our proposal will optimize and validate a novel extension of dMRI that can simultaneously assess both GM and WM microstructure and connectivity in order to translate it into a new practical clinical imaging method for improved detection of Alzheimer's disease-related microstructural abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Novel imaging technologies are needed to facilitate the study and visualization of the early and low-grade gastrointestinal (GI) inflammation. Our proposal aims to establish fluorescence lifetime imaging (FLIm) as a nondestructive and label-free research tool to visualize and quantify the tissue-level response to microbiome- mediated inflammation using the in vivo murine colon as a study model. The long-term goal of this research seeks to translate FLIm as a clinical tool for the early diagnosis of human GI inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative ALK receptor expression and mutation are oncogenic drivers in multiple cancers, particularly in pediatric neuroblastoma. The ALK receptors form a unique family of receptor tyrosine kinases whose mechanisms of regulation are poorly understood. This proposal aims to elucidate the molecular underpinnings that dictate and direct ALK receptor signal transduction to uncover novel therapeutic opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will identify the pathways and mechanisms by which ENPP1 induces low bone mass, as well as an investigation into a therapeutic treating paradoxical mineralization states, which fracture and survival rates demonstrate to be poorly understood and treated by current therapies. The deliverables of the proposal are not only important for understanding an unknown form of hereditary osteoporosis, they may also contribute to our understanding of an adynamic bone disease present in chronic renal failure known as chronic kidney disease bone mineralization disorder CKD-MBD, in which ENPP1 activity is also known to be reduced.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Numerous studies support the premise that inflammation rises in aging. Drugs with anti- inflammatory actions such as metformin may promote healthspan, the length of one's life spent in good health, especially if given prior to onset of age-related declines. We will analyze deidentified samples from an NIA-funded clinical trial to test the possibility that baseline insulin sensitivity impacts the ability of metformin to ameliorate pathogenic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Macrophages are immune cells that propagate inflammation in many inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. Choline metabolism during macrophage activation is essential for lipid remodeling and cytokine production. Identifying the cellular responses that are fueled by choline during macrophage differentiation and activation are essential for defining innovative therapeutic manipulations critical to myriads of inflammatory diseases including rheumatic diseases such as osteoarthritis, gout, or rheumatoid arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the extraordinary rise in the number of wildfires in the Western US over the past decade, we seek to use Medicare data and emergency department visit data to quantify the relationships between acute and chronic exposure to wildfire smoke and cardiovascular disease outcomes. Combining advanced chemical transport models and machine learning techniques, we will generate detailed estimates of major air pollutants in smoke, then establish concentration-response functions of multiple CVD endpoints, and then estimate future smoke- related CVD burden due to climate change. The findings of this study will fill major knowledge gaps and improve our understanding of the serious threat of increasing wildfire activities to population health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The homologous recombination pathway plays critical roles during the response to replication stress and disruption of the response leads to a wide variety of human diseases. We are elucidating the molecular mechanisms of recombination proteins at stalled replication forks. Our discoveries will lead to a better understanding of how disruption of the pathway results in human disease potentially leading to identification of novel targets for therapeutics for recombination-deficient inherited disorders and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Summary Lewy body diseases (LBDs), including Parkinson's disease (PD), Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD), and dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), share a common spectrum of disease pathology but also have distinct Lewy Body deposition patterns which were correlated with regional-specific neuronal loss and the unique clinical manifestations in each disease. This proposal will dissect the molecular mechanisms of selective neuronal and regional vulnerability in LBDs via novel genomics technologies and bioinformatics tools. Our study will provide molecular biomarkers and tools for neuron cell-type-specific protection and targeted astrocyte/microglia subpopulation isolation and manipulation as well as molecular biomarkers for distinguishing PD, PDD, and DLB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Pediatric cardiology, like all of medicine, is poised to benefit from burgeoning advancements in genetics, genomics, bioengineering, and developmental, cellular and molecular biology. It is also fertile ground for rigorous prospective clinical investigation related to bioengineering, transcatheter, and pharmacological interventions, as well as cell therapy and regeneration for selected cardiovascular diseases. This Training Program will recruit basic, translational, and clinical researchers to these tasks and train them to bridge the still substantial gap between the laboratory and the bedside in pediatric cardiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to improve the long-term physical and psychosocial outcomes of adolescents with chronic musculoskeletal pain (CMP) in order to reduce healthcare utilization and mitigate the psychosocial sequelae of ongoing chronic pain in this vulnerable patient population. The goal of the proposed research is to examine the impact of a resilience coaching program adapted for adolescent chronic musculoskeletal pain in a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT). Achievement of the study aims has the potential to be a significant contribution to building and fostering resilience among adolescents with chronic musculoskeletal pain, as the proposed research will inform a future multicenter RCT of the resilience coaching program and thereby augment current interdisciplinary management of adolescent CMP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The past five years have been transformative in our understanding of the neurobiology of the addictive and therapeutic potential of drugs of abuse. Given the highly polygenic and multi-factorial nature of drug use and misuse, and the growing emphasis on incorporating neuroscience into precision medicine, there is an immediate need for young investigators with training in biomedical approaches. Led by scientists who are deeply invested in human (Dr. Agrawal) and animal (Dr. Moron-Concepcion) addiction neurobiology, the competing continuation of this training grant will continue to provide research training in genetics, neuroscience, neuroimaging, neuropharmacology, statistics/computation and biology as well as career development to 6 postdoctoral scholars with MDs or PhDs. Situated within the Department of Psychiatry at Washington University School of Medicine, and supported by 27 preceptors, this T32 will leverage the extensive array of coursework, workshops and seminars available across the medical and arts and sciences campuses and rich assortment of large datasets available to trainees.

PROJECT_TITLE: Biomedical Research Training in Drug Abuse

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This R01 application will investigate a targeted nanoparticle that possesses the ability to selectively knockdown multiple proteins in drug resistant lung cancer cells and thereby sensitize tumors to therapy. The project goal is to assess safety and efficacy of the nanoparticle-platform in murine and canine models to ease clinical translation for patients with drug resistant non-small cell lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY/ABSTRACT Malaria cases and deaths primarily caused by Plasmodium falciparum have declined significantly in sub- Saharan Africa as a result of the broad deployment of vector control and effective clinical management. In low to moderate-transmission settings slated for elimination, imported cases become an increasingly important epidemiological consideration. In these settings, imported cases may a) represent a high but poorly defined proportion of the overall malaria burden, b) result in secondary transmission that can impede local elimination efforts, and c) may require additional or alternative interventions than standard control measures. Imported cases, when currently evaluated at all, are operationally defined as infections acquired outside of a defined geographic area and identified based on travel history. However, lack of capture of asymptomatic infections together with variable quality of travel history collection limit the utility of this standard approach to identifying imported infections and quantifying their role in transmission. Further, there are no routinely collected data that would allow evaluation of the impact of imported cases on local transmission. In this proposal, we will collect detailed travel histories, perform active surveillance for asymptomatic infections, and generate parasite genomic data to more accurately define the role of imported infections in two representative border regions of sub-Saharan Africa (Tororo District, Uganda and Mutasa District, Zimbabwe) that leverage substantial surveillance infrastructure from the NIH-funded International Centers of Excellence for Malaria Research (ICEMR) network and will employ active (via a longitudinal study) and passive (via health facility surveillance) designs to capture asymptomatic and symptomatic infections. We propose the following Specific Aims.1) To quantify and characterize imported malaria infections. We will use a probabilistic approach to classify infections as imported or local via detailed travel and other behavioral survey data and determine the travel patterns and risk factors associated with importation. 2) To determine the impact of importation on local transmission and identify appropriate targeted interventions. We will use parasite genomics and epidemiological data to define local transmission and the impact of imported infections, taking advantage of dense sampling of symptomatic and asymptomatic infections in focused geographies. We will use a robust set of statistical modeling approaches, including Bayesian estimation of transmission networks incorporating all genomic and epidemiologic data. We will use these data to model the predicted impact of various combinations of targeted interventions. The expected outcome of the proposed research is evidence on appropriate surveillance methods for imported malaria infections and on the contribution of these infections to sustaining transmission. By identifying ways to better target interventions, these results will impact malaria control efforts as they strive for elimination and require evidence on how to mitigate the risk of imported malaria infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many metabolic disorders are associated with infertility and sex hormone dysregulation, though the molecular mechanisms that link nutrient status to reproductive events are not well understood. The evolutionarily conserved Integrated Stress Response (ISR) pathway responds to environmental and cellular stress cues like starvation, directing transcriptional changes that prioritize survival at the temporary expense of nonessential processes like oogenesis and mating. The work proposed herein will combine genetic, biochemical, and neuromodulatory tech- niques to examine how the ISR links nutrient status to reproductive potential via steroid hormones, revealing new insights into how metabolism impacts fertility across organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Overall Project Narrative American Indians (AIs) experience disproportionately high rates of trauma-related health disparities. This COBRE aims to mentor junior faculty at UND to enhance research capacities and skills and to address AI health disparities related to trauma, and the health promoting effects of resilience. Three individual research projects include: (1) Historical trauma and resilience as a biological state and its association with the effects of the traditional Indigenous food chokeberry; (2) Impact of boarding school attendance on perceived stress, allostatic load and resilience; and (3) Stress and health in American Indian pregnancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opportunity and motivation to seek help are vital to long-term suicide prevention and to outreach in times of acute suicide-related crises, and yet almost half of people do not disclose suicidal thoughts to anyone. This study combines lab-based and digital data collection tools to investigate how specific deficits in the reward system interfere with long-term supportive relationships and to social outreach behavior during crisis, in order to identify new treatment targets for improving the interpersonal aspects of an array of suicide prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal will investigate how epithelial cells that line mucosal surfaces, and macrophages that are a key innate immune cell involved in host defense against infection, communicate with each other to cross-regulate each other’s function in homeostasis and following microbial challenge. We will investigate how modification of an essential protein tyrosine phosphatase in one cell type changes the behavior of the other cell using novel model systems with complementary in vivo and in vitro approaches. In addition, we will identify novel mediators and mechanisms of cellular cross-talk that are vital for macrophage polarization, epithelial barrier maintenance and protection against infection at mucosal surfaces.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative: A significant population of HIV infected people abuse drugs such as Methamphetamine (Meth). Both Meth and HIV can affect the brain negatively. HIV also hides in the brain even if it is not detected in the blood. Studying where HIV hides in the brain and effects of HIV and Meth on the brain is difficult because the brain cannot be accessed unless the person is deceased and even then, there are limits to what one can learn from these brains. As a result, there are animal models that are half human/half mouse brain that can be used to understand where HIV hides in the brain of Meth users. We will u se these models in a unique way by taking cells from Meth using/ HIV positive people and reprogramming them to become brain cells to put into these mice to understand the extent of where HIV hides, effects on the brain, and how HIV genotype changes over time (evolution). Together, these studies will allow us to define the scope of the challenge to be in a better place to solve it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The discovery of GPIHBP1 as the transporter of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) transformed textbook descriptions of intravascular triglyceride processing, but the model remains incomplete. Our objectives are to investigate the function of GPIHBP1's intrinsically disordered acidic domain and to refine our understanding of GPIHBP1 and LPL localization and function within the capillary lumen. An improved understanding of plasma triglyceride physiology is quite relevant to human metabolic diseases, including atherosclerotic coronary heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury is a common orthopedic injury that results in an immediate shutdown of neural activation to the quadriceps muscle that leads to strength deficits and drives poor patient outcomes. Neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) is commonly prescribed as part of the standard of care to activate the inhibited motoneurons to promote strength recovery, however the clinical success is mixed. The goal of this proposal is to maximize the effectiveness of NMES by testing specific treatment parameters and the underlying mechanisms of action in preclinical studies to provide fundamental knowledge to guide clinical practice.

PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative Using variation in medical malpractice protection of military members and their families, this project explores the impact of malpractice pressure on the quality and quantity of patient treatment, including an analysis of liability's effects on “high-value” and “low-value” outpatient care and on opioid use. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our study systematically addresses unresolved ethical concerns and barriers to harnessing emotional and biobehavioral PC data to improve clinical care by identifying diverse stakeholders' informational needs and perceived ethical challenges for translating PC metrics into actionable clinical knowledge. This research will carefully examine diverse stakeholders' concerns and perspectives toward risk/benefit tradeoffs of PC and will evaluate impacts of integrating PC into clinical assessments. Our methods will generate policy solutions for responsibly translating PC into clinical care, with far-reaching potential to advance precision medicine and to improve and personalize care across a range of disorders where quality of care depends on accurately eliciting and interpreting information about emotional states and behavior.

PHR: The intestine is an important regulatory and signaling organ, enabling diet-derived nutrients to perform essential actions. In this project, we explore a novel role for an intestinal lipid-metabolizing protein, stearoyl- CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), in regulating whole body lipid levels and metabolic health. These studies have important translational implications to the development of novel nutritional and pharmaceutical therapies for maintaining and improving cardiometabolic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) and AD related dementia (AD/ADRD) poste a serious public health crisis in the aging population. Although the disease disproportionately affect the elderly, with women having a significantly higher rate than men, few sex-specific studies have been conducted in older women. In the study, we have two specific aims: Aim 1: To examine the association of vascular, metabolic and inflammatory biomarkers with risk of incident MCI and dementia in women aged 65 and older. Aim 2: To develop a machine learning (ML)-enabled algorithm to predict individuals who are at high risk of incident MCI and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  By 2050, osteoporosis is expected to affect >50% of Americans over the age of 50; further, osteoporotic hip fracture incidence is expected to increase by >200% compared to rates in 1990. Recent studies have identified a large number of loci associated with bone mineral density (BMD), an important clinical marker for osteoporosis diagnosis. This project aims to define causal genes at these loci to understand their biological mechanisms, and in turn, identify new drug targets for osteoporosis therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed studies will yield fundamental and novel knowledge regarding the role of human constitutive androstane receptor (hCAR) in liver cancer development, which is profoundly different from its rodent counterparts. The anticipated outcomes will offer proof-of-concept evidence that hCAR has an anticancer function that represses the growth of hepatoma cells. These studies will also explore the mechanisms underlying hCAR-mediated suppression of human liver cancer, which may eventually lead to novel strategies in controlling liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Overall – PROJECT NARRATIVE Decades of research have generated new knowledge and tools with the potential to prevent all new HIV infections and improve the lives of all persons living with HIV. Unfortunately, reality falls far short of these goals. The Tennessee Center for AIDS Research leverages complementary strengths of its four partner institutions to have broad and substantial impact on the HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality among American Indian populations, and investigations of early-life determinants of cardiovascular disease are warranted. The proposed project will examine multiple pathways linking maternal ACEs and infant growth, a recognized risk factor for cardiovascular disease in adulthood. This project will highlight specific pathways that could potentially be modified to reduce future risk of cardiovascular disease among American Indian populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance NIGMS supported work in the Tracey lab leads the field of bioelectronic medicine, holding promise to benefit patients by using electronic devices to replace their drugs. It is based on the science of targeting molecules to stop inflammation, which affects millions of patients with arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, diabetes, asthma, Alzheimer's, heart disease and stroke. The studies proposed here focus on how the brain and nervous system control inflammation in order to design new bioelectronic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this proposal is to advance a large animal model of spinal cord glioma (SCG) as a translational platform. We will accomplish this by scaling and adapting previously implemented strategies for vector- driven gene transfer of oncogenes and shRNA knockdown of genes implicated in gliomagenesis to induce SCG of variable phenotype. This will provide improved utility for preclinical therapeutic testing and surgical device development with varied grade, growth rate, and underyling genetic lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Complex structural variants are a frequent but underexplored aspect of cancer genomes that may drive aggressive tumors and reflect treatable defects in DNA repair. While long-range and single cell genomic profiling technologies have matured, algorithms for inferring complex structural variants from these data are lacking. This proposal will develop such algorithms and apply them to study the evolution of pyrgo, a recently identified complex structural variant class prevalent in ovarian and prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus is the leading cause of cardiac device infections, a devastating complication that jeopardizes the function of these lifesaving devices. This research proposal will build novel bioengineered model systems to examine how specific patient and bacterial factors interact to influence why some people with S. aureus bloodstream infection and cardiac devices (pacemakers, artificial heart valves) develop an infection of their cardiac device while others do not. The results from this research can be used to develop new diagnostics to identify patients at high risk for developing a cardiac device infection or new therapeutics to augment a person's ability to fight these infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Each year, more than 12 million women in the U.S. will be recommended for diagnostic work-up for concern of breast cancer and must navigate multiple steps including breast imaging tests, breast biopsies, and specialist consultations before diagnostic resolution. Compared to screening mammography, surprisingly little is known about how differences in breast cancer diagnostic work-up contribute to the persistently higher morbidity and mortality experienced by women of minority race/ethnicity and lower socioeconomic status. We will conduct the largest observational study to date on breast cancer diagnostic evaluation involving 1.4 million U.S. women across 198 individual practices to identify novel diagnostic quality of care indicators that can be used to develop interventions and guidelines aimed at closing the persistent breast cancer disparities gap.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To advance our understanding of Glioblastoma (GBM) therapeutic resistance, it is essential to characterize the individual cell during therapy those fueling tumor recurrence in GBM. We have identified a novel mechanism of Ribonucleotide Reductase promoting resistance by performing a single-cell RNA sequencing screen in the patient-derived xenograft model of GBM during temozolomide (TMZ) TMZ therapy. This application is set to evaluate Ribonucleotide Reductase as a target to overcome therapeutic resistance in GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common neurodegenerative disorder and currently has no disease- modifying treatment. Regulatory T cells (Tregs) express several NMDA-type glutamate receptors (NMDARs), including GluN1, GluN2A, GluN3A and GluN3B; however, the effect of glutamate on Tregs migration/activation has not been reported, and, specifically, it is not known how this might impact neurons in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) brain. In this study we will utilize human cells: Tregs isolated from blood and hiPSC-derived microglia and neurons to study the interaction between these cells and understand how glutamate regulates the crosstalk between microglia and Tregs in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For people who use drugs in Uganda, services for harm reduction as well as HIV prevention remain in their infancy, despite a growing epidemic and potential for up to 45% of drug users to be living with HIV. The proposed work leverages methods from implementation science to develop, pilot, and determine the cost of two approaches to integrated harm reduction and PrEP delivery – a facility-based model within a medication-assisted treatment program and a community-based model for needle and syringe exchange. Results will have implications for the Ugandan context, as well as communities in the US, by demonstrating co-location of PrEP and harm reduction services and novel data on PrEP adherence and retention among people who use drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The advent of CFTR modulators, a new class of therapies which correct the underlying protein defect in CF, have led to a dramatic improvement in the lives of those with CF. However, underlying airway inflammation persists and currently no studies that have examined the effect of inflammation on response to modulators or trialed therapies to augment response. The knowledge gained in this study will improve understanding of the impact of airway inflammation in the post-modulator era and potentially identify a widely-available, well-tolerated therapy (losartan) to improve response to CFTR modulator therapy.

PHR: Narrative: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is characterized by high blood sugar levels during pregnancy. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral palsy (CP) is one of the most prevalent and costly developmental disabilities in the United States. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black/African American (AA) older adults are vastly underrepresented in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) research despite the high prevalence of the disease in this population. This novel and innovative study will reduce prevalent barriers to participation by implementing home-based assessment and blood collection, provide technology, and facilitate door-to-door transportation services to MRI and amyloid PET imaging facilities. Novel cognitive assessment using our Cognitive Challenge Tests (CCTs) and the deep phenotyping proposed including state-of the-science blood-based biomarkers of AD and neurodegeneration using advanced Single Molecule Array (SiMoA) technology, MRI and PET neuroimaging, and examining the potential contributions of common co-morbid conditions (e.g., cerebrovascular disease, diabetes, and chronic kidney disease, etc.) and social determinants of health will answer important questions regarding how our novel CCTs map onto sensitive biomarkers for the early detection of preclinical and prodromal AD among AA individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: RELEVANCE  The proposed project has direct clinical relevance to Alzheimer’s disease, a devastating neurodegenerative disorder that is the sixth leading cause of death in the US and affects 44 million people worldwide. The disease presents a significant economic burden as it costs the US over billions of dollars each year and places significant social and psychological burden on caregivers. In response to this looming public health crisis in the United States, the proposed study will obtain experimental evidence for the role of cerebral microvasculature in the disease and provide a computational framework to better investigate and understand the role.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative:  Increasing evidence suggests that “reservoirs” of HIV-infected cells which persist on anti-HIV medicines (“ART”), and especially those cells that produce HIV RNA and/or protein (“active reservoirs”), cause ongoing damage despite treatment and also allow the virus to relapse when treatment is stopped, preventing cure. In this program project grant, multiple novel and cutting-edge technologies will be applied to samples from different groups of HIV-infected individuals in order to understand how the diverse reservoirs of HIV-infected cells that do or do not produce different forms of HIV RNA and/or protein differ in many respects, including their cell numbers, survival, clearance by immune responses, contribution to inflammation, production of human RNA and proteins, differences across tissues, contribution to virologic relapse after stopping anti-HIV medicines, and susceptibility to new therapies aimed at HIV cure. Findings from these studies will generate a wealth of new knowledge about these HIV-infected reservoirs, which may lead to new approaches aimed at HIV cure or improved tolerance of lifelong infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The human pathogen Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Ngo) is the causative agent of gonorrhea and remains a major public health concern due to increasing rates of antibiotic resistance and lack of a protective vaccine. The work will investigate a protein that I hypothesize Ngo uses to acquire zinc in metal-limited conditions. Understanding the metal transport mechanism Ngo utilizes to undermine host-mediated metal limitation will translate into development of targeted new therapies against this antibiotic-resistant bacterium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative: Aortic Aneurysm (AA) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality; AAs weaken the vessel wall and lead to dilation that often progresses to rupture in the absence of symptoms. There are no point-of-care diagnostic tests available that either screen for AAs or follow disease progression to optimize timing for surgical intervention. This award will advance a standardized screening technique that determines aneurysm presence, location, and diameter; such information may be used for risk stratification and will surely mitigate life-threatening aortic complications in the general population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: A critical component of acupuncture theory and therapy is the existence of specific locations across the body surface where inserting and manipulating a needle can engender salubrious, clinically beneficial effects. These locations are termed acupuncture points, or acupoints, and have been the source of great controversy for the acupuncture research field. Our platform, called the Topological Atlas and Repository for Acupoint research (TARA), forms an invaluable Research Resource Center for the acupuncture research and clinical community by strengthening the biological basis of acupoints, facilitating acupuncture integration into clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Liver disease causes more than two million deaths worldwide per year, and unlike most other major killers, deaths due to liver disease are rapidly rising rather than falling. We are working to address this major medical challenge by building bioartificial livers that can serve as a bridge or alternative to transplantation. Here, we will 3D print human liver tissue that grows within the body and therapeutically rescues mice with liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Racial disparities in the incidence and treatment of end-stage kidney disease are well-documented and largely consistent across outcomes, and an emerging consensus indicates that these disparities are likely to be primarily driven by structural racism (SR). We will develop theoretically-driven, innovative measures of SR using restricted microdata and other sources, analyze the role of SR in racial/ethnic disparities in end-stage kidney disease incidence and mortality outcomes, determine how best to operationalize meaningful racial/ethnic disparities in sequences of kidney disease therapies, and work with two established community advisory boards to develop proposed interventions to ameliorate racial/ethnic disparities in kidney disease on the basis of our findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The human genome encodes a diverse collection of membrane tethered enzymes that play vital roles in human health and disease pathogenesis; however, the molecular and atomic details that govern enzyme activity are poorly understood. Here, I present a basic research program to study these different enzyme families, using a multidisciplinary approach, to reveal unifying themes in ectodomain shedding and unique characteristics that position the enzyme into its biological niche.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elevated risk of maternal mortality in African-American women is a complex and urgent problem in the US, and approaches that take into account social determinants of health along with clinical factors to understand and mitigate this risk are sorely needed. We propose to develop, in collaboration with patient, provider, and community support personnel stakeholders, a machine learning-based technology to link biological, clinical, and social determinants of health data, identify risk factors for conditions antecedent to maternal mortality, and translate this understanding of risk into user-facing apps designed to support the individual and shared decision-making of patients, providers, and community support personnel. The project will include needs assessment, systems development, pilot-level deployment, and evaluation phases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) are at high risk for developing cardiovascular disease, but as diseas progression leads to costly dialysis or high-risk transplantation, therapies to protect the heart and vasculature and to increase lifespan do currently not exits. Soluble klotho (sKL) is a protein in the blood with protective effects on various organs, and sKL levels are reduced in CKD patients and are thought to contribute to CKD-associated pathologies, such as cardiovascular damage. Alpha Young LLC has developed an early-stage mimetic protein of sKL, and here we will introduce and test additional mutations to increase sKL’s stability and bioactivity, in order to develop a novel drug with widespread protective effects that can be injected into patients with CKD and prolong their survival.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative  We propose to develop and use mass spectrometry technologies in conjunction with statistical methods to better understand, detect, and diagnose endometriosis. By leveraging the advantages of the chemical sensitivity and specificity of mass spectrometry with the simplicity, speed, and spatial correlation offered by ambient mass spectrometry techniques, we aim to develop new methods that can improve the diagnosis and management of endometriosis at multiple stages of patient treatment using a large cohort of patient samples. The experiments proposed will explore the molecular differences between eutopic and ectopic endometrium tissues, correlate molecular data with patient phenotypes and disease presentation, advance development of a diagnostic method for endometriosis, and improve the surgical resection of endometriosis lesions in vivo during surgical procedures, leading to new understanding of this disease and offering improved treatment options for patients.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Eliminating injury-related fear in patients after ACL reconstruction can decrease the healthcare burden associated with ACL reinjury rates by allowing patients to safely return to physical activity, improve their overall health and wellness, and decrease the risk for the development of overuse conditions like post-traumatic knee osteoarthritis. Relevant to the NIH mission, virtual reality mindfulness meditation may incite a paradigm shift in current treatment strategies, by promoting patient-centered holistic healthcare, for the hundreds of thousands of individuals who sustain an ACL injury and undergo ACL reconstruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic foot disease represents the costliest of diabetes complications with fiscal as well as personal costs driven by the difficulty of healing diabetic foot ulcers, with non-healing ulcers frequently prompting lower ex- tremity amputations. In contrast to the current practice of trying to predict how specialized footwear will ‘treat diabetic foot ulcers’ in the absence of considering the patient, this project will assess how offloading devices ‘treat people with diabetic foot ulcers’ by looking at how variations in footwear design influence patients’ func- tional experience with them, and in turn adherence and healing. The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission because it identifies causes for poor healing of diabetic foot ulcers and potential means of improving their treatment; it is relevant to public health by offering means to reduce the fiscal and personal costs asso- ciated with poor healing of diabetic foot ulcers while improving quality of life for patients during wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Although Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) in marijuana provides some medical benefits, researchers need to explore mechanisms that are selective to avoid side effects. This project investigates mechanisms of CB1 cannabinoid receptor regulation by Cannabinoid Receptor Interacting Protein1a (CRIP1a), a protein that targets CB1 receptors in brain cells that express both proteins. Our elucidation of the unique mechanisms used by CRIP1a can offer new insights into human diseases involving neurodevelopment, vision and auditory function, epileptic seizures, and mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive neurological disorder that adversely affects cognition and daily functioning in older adults. This proposal seeks to better understand the association between alterations in dynamic functional brain activity as it relates to biomarkers and decreasing cognition in individuals with mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease, as well as cognitively intact seniors. This project will inform clinical trials by predicting biomarker status based on dynamic functional connectivity in older adults with and without cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chronic stress plays a role in multiple neuropsychiatric disorders, many of which lack highly efficacious treatments. Recently, a single dose of the psychedelic drug psilocybin has been shown to promote long-lasting therapeutic effects in humans, but the underlying mechanisms remain poorly understood. Here, we elucidate the rules governing psilocybin’s repair of specific neural circuits in chronically stressed rodents, with the potential to allow for the design of even more precise and efficacious neuropsychiatric therapies with minimal off-target effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amblyopia is the second most common cause of vision problems in children, and distortions in perceived forms which can negatively impact life as an adult if uncorrected have been documented but nor understood. We propose to show with experiments and a computational model that the defective perception of shapes is due to problems in the development of oriented cortical cells caused by an imbalance between the signals for lights and darks reaching the cortex due to defocus or misalignment of the amblyopic eye. We will investigate whether orientation processing deficits hinder amblyopes in seeing 3D shapes, poses and symmetry which are conveyed by orientations in the retinal image, with a view to identifying top-down signals that could reactivate plasticity in targeted cells of the primary visual cortex in future therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) makes essential contributions to learning, mood, and decision making, including evaluating and responding to threats. Compared to other circuits, mPFC circuits undergo prolonged maturation that is likely necessary in order to support complex behaviors but also extends the developmental window during which insults, such as early life adversity, can perturb healthy circuit assembly. The broad goal of this proposal is to establish causal links between mPFC circuit development and the maturation of learned threat avoidance, and to determine how ELA impacts this developmental trajectory.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 176 million women worldwide have endometriosis, and current treatments are sub-optimal. This project tests a new idea that whereas some gut bacteria promote endometriosis by inducing inflammation, others protect against endometriosis by fermenting fiber to produce short chain fatty acids. In the long term, this project will lead to the development of diagnostic tools and therapies to treat and prevent recurrences of this painful disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Well-documented phenomena in Alzheimer’s disease involve cases where some individuals do not manifest Alzheimer’s disease proteins in their brain despite exhibiting known Alzheimer’s disease risk factors (termed resistance), while others with significant Alzheimer disease burden maintain better-than-expected cognitive performance throughout life (termed resilience). The goal of this project is to develop individualized risk profiles to classify and validate resistance and resilience across 13 data harmonized, independent cohorts of approximately 15,000 individuals. Building individualized risk profiles of resistance and resilience to AD will have broad-sweeping implications for identifying those who will truly benefit from therapeutic intervention, improving diagnostic decision making and optimizing AD prevention trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The microglial receptor TREM2 is a genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD). We will investigate the impact of AD-associated TREM2 gain-of-function mutations on AD pathology using our collection of AD genetic datasets, together with our novel animal models of neuroinflammation and iPSC-derived human microglia-like cells. The proposed study will elucidate novel molecular mechanisms underlying microglial pathology in AD and will facilitate AD therapeutics targeting TREM2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: The ability of the brain’s neural circuits to re-organize after amputation, nerve damage or stroke mediates optimal recovery after a traumatic event, but this neural plasticity can also cause problematic phenotypes such as chronic pain, phantom limb pain or hyperalgesia. The mechanisms underlying these adaptations are poorly understood. Basic research findings from this study will elucidate the specific neurons, synapses and receptors in the circuit underlying adaptive or maladaptive plasticity after peripheral nerve transection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regular exercise provides numerous metabolic and cardiovascular health benefits, however significant inter- individual differences exist in the cardiometabolic responses to regular exercise and there remains a limited understanding of the molecular mechanisms through which exercise confers its salutary effects. The goal of this proposal is to identify new molecular pathways and/or predictors of chronic exercise-induced cardiometabolic changes by integrating genetics, metabolomics and richly-phenotyped cardiometabolic traits from a completed chronic exercise study as well as large population-based cohort studies. In parallel with these aims, this proposal will generate cross-sectional metabolomics and cardiac imaging data in individuals with metabolic syndrome as preliminary data for a future exercise trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mortality and Morbidity in biomaterial and medical device-induced foreign body response (FBR) are very high and are directly related to the development of inflammation and fibrosis in affected organs/tissues. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Substance use disorder is a chronic, long-lasting disorder in which patients suffer from high rates of relapse despite successful attempts at abstinence. The goal of this proposal is to delineate the role of circular RNAs in drug-seeking phenotypes to uncover novel mechanisms that can be targeted for treatment of substance use disorder. This proposal will provide critical information on the neurobiological adaptations that the brain undergoes in response to drugs while also exploring the molecular biology of a class of RNA previously unstudied in addiction models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Our earlier work establishing aberrant regulation of mTORC1 and mTORC2 signaling in NF2 led to clinical trials with mTORC1 inhibitor everolimus for NF2, and dual mTORC1/mTORC2 inhibitor, AZD2014, for NF2- associated and sporadic meningiomas. Our ongoing studies uncover role of growth factors and other receptor tyrosine kinases in NF2-negative tumors, and potential cross talk between mTOR and other signaling pathways. This project will explore these druggable therapeutic targets along with other promising drugs in clinical development using cellular and animal models of NF2-deficient meningioma, which will have a direct impact on developing novel therapeutic strategies and promoting public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the initiation and progression of diabetes is paramount to designing therapies to block or reverse disease. Here, we investigate molecular mechanisms of cellular stress responses in diabetes pathogenesis, and leverage our insights to identify new targets to develop novel therapies for the treatment of the disease. We use sophisticated genetic and pharmacological tools focusing exclusively on human stem cell- derived beta and islet cells to achieve these goals.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to explore how neuromodulation plays a critical role in valence assignment in the basolateral amygdala, a site identified as a divergence point in circuits mediating positive and negative valence. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to public health We are developing a set of technologies to enable real-time intraoperative microscopy of the final resection margins of low-grade glioma (LGG) patients who have been administered with 5-ALA prior to surgery (FDA approved in 2017). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite racial/ethnic disparities in outcomes for younger adults with traumatic brain injury (TBI), there are no U.S. standards for TBI transitional care for patients discharged home from acute hospital care. To enhance the standard of care, we will examine the efficacy of our existing intervention named BETTER (Brain Injury, Education, Training, and Therapy to Enhance Recovery), a culturally-tailored, patient- and family-centered TBI transitional care intervention, compared to usual care, among younger adults with TBI and families. The knowledge generated will drive improvements in health equity for younger adults with TBI of various races/ethnicities and families, resulting in improved health of the public.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Many preclinical and some clinical studies suggest that the irradiation at ultra-high dose rates, namely FLASH-RT, can substantially reduce normal-tissue toxicities while maintaining tumor response, compared with the irradiation at conventional dose rates. However, the effectiveness of FLASH-RT for general cancer patients is to be further validated through clinical trials, for which this project will develop first-of-its-kind simultaneous dose and dose rate optimization (SDDRO) methods with FLASH optimization capability that is currently unavailable and urgently needed for clinical FLASH-RT. The availability of FLASH-RT treatment planning system with SDDRO will facilitate animal studies and clinical trials on FLASH-RT, which will potentially become a new paradigm for cancer radiotherapy in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Oxygen is a lifesaving therapy but needs to be balanced since both high and low extremes are harmful. This proposal describes an innovative approach to maintain targeted oxygenation preventing both extremes. The proposal also looks at identifying biomarkers of oxygen toxicity, which can help health care workers prevent oxygen induced toxicity and result in shorter time on mechanical ventilation, less organ failure and better life quality after illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall: Project Narrative The Adult Children Study has created a cohort of middle age and older individuals, with and without a parental history of Alzheimer disease (AD), who longitudinally undergo a comprehensive battery of biological, clinical, and cognitive tests to identify the earliest brain changes of AD prior to any clinical symptoms. Our hypothesis is that the compromise of neuronal function by these brain changes predicts the transition from preclinical AD to symptomatic AD. This renewal will focus on the factors that accelerate or prevent development of symptomatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Copper is an essential trace nutrient important for fundamental processes including respiration, removal of toxic oxygen radicals, cell signaling, and tissue development. Copper is also toxic, and impaired import and distribution is associated with a number of human diseases including Menkes disease, a fatal genetic Cu deficiency that is characterized by severe postnatal developmental defects. These studies focus on gaining a deeper knowledge of how cells balance copper levels during dynamic states like tissue development by focusing on how the copper is prioritized to control the signaling pathways that promote or inhibit development and how expression of genes regulating Cu import and distribution are regulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will use a population-based approach to conduct whole exome sequencing and targeted gene panel sequencing of single and pooled circulating tumor cells (CTCs), in order to identify CTC mutations/genes that are predictive of treatment response and prognosis in patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC). As, to our best knowledge, the first population study of single-CTC next-generation sequencing study in mCRPC, the findings of our study will significantly improve the potential of CTCs in the clinical management of mCRPC, by precisely tailoring treatment to the genomic make-up of individual CTCs from individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: A conserved feature of aging from flies to humans is loss of circadian regulation, or disruption of 24-hour oscillations in behavior and biological function; unfortunately, there are currently few therapeutic interventions that enhance circadian regulation in the elderly. One potential therapeutic intervention is time-restricted feeding, or TRF; this proposal tests the hypothesis that TRF promotes diverse anti-aging health benefits by enhancing tissue-specific circadian clocks and the expression of circadian- regulated genes in different tissues. Here we propose to use the powerful genetic methods in Drosophila to investigate the role of central and peripheral clocks in different TRF-induced health benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antimicrobial blue light at 405 nm wavelength has attracted increasing attention because of its intrinsic bactericidal activity against a wide range of pathogenic bacteria. However, Staphylococcus aureus, a serious threat to human health flagged by the U.S. CDC, has been found to be much more tolerant of antimicrobial blue light at 405 nm due to its high antioxidant capability. A recent study discovered that the antioxidant capability of S. aureus can be mitigated using 460-nm wavelength irradiation. As such, this application aims to investigate the utility of an innovative dual-wavelength irradiation strategy, by using the combination of 460 nm and 405 nm wavelength irradiation, for improved killing of S. aureus. If this strategy can be demonstrated to be both effective and safe, it would potentially be a further advancement in the treatment of localized S. aureus infections.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Approximately one-fifth of the world's couples encounter fertility problems, half of them being attributed to the male part. The main cause of this problem is attributed to an insufficient knowledge in sperm physiology at the molecular level. This project will use a cross-disciplinary approach to dissect the regulation of soluble adenylate cyclase in mammalian sperm with the goal of understanding unsolved physiological questions related to the acquisition of sperm fertilizing competence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Lay Abstract The number of African Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, and Pacific Islanders who are neuroscientists is much lower than would be expected based on their representation in the U.S. population. We will establish a national Mentoring Institute for Neuroscience Diversity Scholars (MINDS) program that will promote the advancement of these underrepresented minorities who are junior faculty members in neuroscience. The program will involve a series of workshops and mentoring over several years with instruction and mentoring in neuroscience research, professional development, and ethics provided by a large number of nationally recognized faculty members. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Biophysical, Topological, and Functional Studies of Endogenous Circular DNAs (PI: S.D. Levene) Project Narrative Circular DNAs, which are physically and topologically distinct from linear chromosomes, contribute to many biological activities including intercellular heterogeneity and, in particular, are associated with malignancies and chemotherapy-drug resistance. Understanding the structure and topology of these circular molecules, which distinguish them from linear-DNA counterparts, can lead to strategies targeting circular-DNA-specific properties. Thus, the study described in this application can provide valuable information to advance 21st– century therapies for cancer and personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE BPD remains the most common and severe complication of prematurity, in which innate immune mechanisms that may protect the lung are poorly understood. This project will identify unique gene regulatory networks of lung myeloid cells that support a regenerative immune response in the developing lung. These findings will elucidate novel pathways of neonatal lung resilience after hyperoxia, which will inform the development of more targeted management of multifactorial BPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal examines a means of providing potent anticoagulation within extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) circuits without limiting normal coagulation in a patient’s tissues. To accomplish this, we propose combining polycarboxybetaine surface coatings with a highly selective bicyclic peptide Factor XIIa inhibitor. Together, these should improve survival during ECMO and enable long-term respiratory support outside the intensive care unit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CRISPR-Cas systems allow bacteria to defend themselves against viruses and have also provided revolutionary tools for improving human health. Defining the mechanisms of CRISPR immunity is required to understand bacterial population dynamics and evolution, and to use CRISPR tools as safely and effectively as possible. Our work will elucidate the structure and function of protein-nucleic acid complexes that play central roles in CRISPR immunity and have important potential for human therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research will define basic mechanisms that regulate neurotransmitter release and retrograde signaling at neuronal synapses. Alterations in synaptic communication have been linked to numerous neurological and psychiatric diseases of the human brain. By defining how synapses bi-directionally communicate, our research will provide a foundation for understanding brain diseases that alter the ability of the synapse to properly signal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is the renewal application for the T32 training grant originally known as “Cancer Etiology, Prevention, Detection and Diagnosis,” which is in its 44th year, and which is entitled in the current application “Leveraging innovative technologies in basic and clinical cancer research”. The program has developed a thriving and robust training environment as well as an effective administrative infrastructure that has been very successful in attracting highly qualified trainees to Stanford University to be educated in cancer biology. During the next funding period, we propose to implement a new vision in which we incorporate innovative technologies into cancer research to enhance both the training and the research projects of our predoctoral trainees, helping them to become independent scientists that take research or clinical positions in academia, biotechnology industries, government laboratories, and the clinic, and to ultimately become leaders in the field of cancer biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Our studies are relevant to the diseased vessels in the brain, so-called cerebral arteriovenous malformation. This study focuses on factors referred to histone deacetylase 2, bone morphogenetic proteins and Notch, and how they communicate with each other to regulate vessel lumen and vessel lining. Understanding how these factors work may lead to new strategies for prevention and treatment of arteriovenous malformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose that fungal translocation, defined by detection of 1,3-beta-D-glucan (BDG), occurs in people living with HIV (PWH) in the absence of invasive fungal infection, triggers inflammation, and leads to impaired lung function by stimulating inflammation in circulating leukocytes via the dectin-1 receptor. We will explore the role of BDG in HIV-associated COPD, to assess the relationship between gut and lung epithelial barrier integrity, the fungal mycobiome, and circulating BDG levels, and if circulating BDG levels predict disease progression and systemic immune cell activation in HIV COPD using an established lung cohort and in vitro lung modeling. This project could lead to discovery of novel therapeutics to treat and prevent COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) dementia is a devastating syndrome of progressive cognitive impairment that generates a staggering burden for patients, families, and health care systems, and for which there are no clinically-available disease-modifying treatments. Disruptions of sleep and rest-wake rhythm are potentially modifiable, increase the risk of cognitive decline, and have been associated with the increased production and reduced clearance of the two proteins thought to be most central to Alzheimer’s disease progression – amyloid-b and tau. By combining newly-available tau PET imaging, functional MRI, neuropsychological testing, and at-home sleep measurements, we will determine if sleep disruption may act as a driver of tau protein accumulation, pathologic network activity, and cognitive decline in a population of people with Mild Cognitive Impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have discovered a critical role for Notch signaling in the regulation of damaging immune responses that mediate graft-versus-host disease, a severe complication of allogeneic bone marrow and hematopoietic cell transplantation. The goal of this research project is to identify the specialized immunological niches that function as the source of Notch ligands after bone marrow transplantation; investigate where precisely transplanted T cells first get exposed to Notch ligands and other critical activation signals; and explore the mechanisms by which short-term Notch inhibition after transplantation can lead to durable protection from graft-versus-host disease. Completion of this project will bring essential new information about Notch signaling in immunobiology and pave the way towards development of therapeutic strategies of Notch inhibition for patients with immune-mediated disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: There is an urgent need for effective tools to aid in the characterization of Alzheimer’s disease and other dementia subtypes in the earliest detectable stages of the pathophysiological process. Advanced Brain Monitoring’s (ABM) goal, building on our ongoing biomarker research (Phase IIa study), is to provide an inexpensive, non-invasive solution to this problem which combines neurocognitive, electrophysiological (EEG, ECG, & EMG), and sleep-behavior assessment into a single, integrated platform. While this novel toolkit is currently being used in a small group of clinical trials, ABM’s efforts are focused on scaling and expanding the application to be suitable for large-scale drug discovery trials in the endophenotypic stratification of Alzheimer’s and other dementia patients and ultimately used in clinical diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Local field potential (LFP) created by the synchronized synaptic currents is widely used to characterize network dynamics and circuit functions in healthy and diseased brains. We developed a technique that allows a highly nuanced analyses of the LFP dynamics and reveals a new level of the LFP’s structure: a set discrete, slowly varying oscillatory processes—the oscillons—embedded in a weak noise background. Our goal is to record, to analyze and to manipulate the oscillons in the hippocampal network of WT and AD rodents to gain a better insight into the circuit mechanisms of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance)  Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M.tb), the cause of human tuberculosis, is largely composed of waxes (lipids) that our immune system “sees” with the help of T cells. Whole cell mycobacterial vaccines currently under development also contain these lipids, but we do not yet know if lipid-specific T cells contribute to protective immunity induced by vaccination. Here, we will develop tools to study these T cells in small and large animal models and test the hypothesis that lipid-specific T cells provide protective immunity against M.tb. !

PHR: Autism Spectrum Disorder is a chronic debilitating disorders with relatively unknown etiology or pathophysiology. We are proposing to identify pathophysiology by using cellular and animal model of Pitt Hopkins Syndrome, a rare Autism Spectrum Disorder. Electrophysiology, cell biology, imaging, behavior, and molecular analyses will be applied to these models to discover associated pathophysiology and molecular mechanisms for the development of new therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Revitalizing Informal Settlements and their Environments (RISE) is a cluster randomized control trial of a water infrastructure intervention which is currently underway in 24 urban slum communities in Indonesia and Fiji, two countries at high risk for arbovirus transmission and climate change. In my K32 project, I will leverage the RISE platform to evaluate risk factors for dengue and chikungunya infections, test the impact of this intervention on transmission, and create a mathematical model to investigate transmission patterns under a range of climate and intervention scenarios. These studies will lay the groundwork for developing future arbovirus prediction and adaptation strategies and launch my career in emerging infectious disease epidemiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the esophagus that causes distressing symptoms in children. Current gold standard diagnosis relies on histopathological assessment of random biopsies to confirm diagnosis, but the patchy nature of the disease tremendously affects the accuracy. Endoscopic Raman spectroscopy can address this issue by providing an in vivo diagnostic tool to survey the biochemical changes of the esophagus and identify key inflammatory biomarkers indicative of active EoE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Essential tremor (ET) is the most common movement disorder and how tremor is generated in ET patients is poorly understood. Currently, the treatment options for ET are very limited; therefore, many people with ET are impaired in their personal and professional lives. The proposed research will take the recent genetic and neuropathological discoveries of ET into functional understanding how structural and molecular changes in the brain can lead to tremor, and the knowledge gained will serve as foundation for therapy development to slow down the disease progression and to prevent disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Although population mixture or admixture is pervasive through human evolution, we still lack adequate statistical methods to study its functional and evolutionary impact. Our goal in this proposal is to develop a suite of computational methods to characterize the local genomic structure of admixed populations and use this information for a range of applications from gene mapping to reconstructing ancestral genomes. These tools will help to analyze data from admixed groups as efficiently as homogeneous populations, and provide novel insights into the genetic and phenotypic legacy of admixture in human evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative HIV persists on antiretroviral therapy (ART) in clonally expanded CD4 T-cells carrying replication- competent proviruses (termed repliclones), which are capable of producing infectious virus and viremia that is not suppressible with ART. The mechanisms involved in clonal outgrowth, persistence and escape from immune-mediated clearance are not defined. Accordingly, we will investigate the mechanisms of clonal persistence including latency, viral escape mutations to antibodies and cytotoxic T-lymphocytes, and intrinsic clonal resistance to immune-mediated killing, in an effort to gain insight on designing strategies that eliminate repliclones and accelerate progress towards a cure for HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial toxins that target insects could be utilized for developing bio-pesticides to control harmful insects, but a molecular understanding of toxin-host interactions is required. Here, we seek to establish and validate new methods and tools for carrying out unbiased genome-wide screens on insect cell models to uncover key host factors mediating the action of insect- targeting bacterial toxins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is highly aggressive, and over 70% of patients with AML eventually become refractory to chemotherapy and face a dire prognosis. There is a sorely unmet need to develop more effective immunotherapy to improve AML therapy. Our proposed studies to develop the nanobody-directed, bispecific and inducible CAR T approach aims to establish a novel and safe CART system to cure AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent research suggests that the findings from neurodevelopmental research intended to explain adolescent risk-taking behaviors (such as substance use) may not be generalizable. A more robust understanding of the brain systems involved in adolescent risk-taking would contribute to more effective research, intervention(s) and policy decisions. By integrating three adolescent functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) samples, this project will involve training in understanding the effects of analytic flexibility in fMRI, how analytic flexibility affects the construct validity of fMRI tasks and the use of advanced data analysis methods to understand brain- behavior relationships across adolescent samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Appendicitis is the most common surgical condition affecting children, with perforated appendicitis associated with longer hospitalizations, higher hospital readmission rates, worse postoperative outcomes, and higher costs. Photodynamic therapy, which exerts antimicrobial activity through generation of reactive oxygen species, is an appealing adjunct to standard of care therapy that could drastically reduce hospital stay and complications. This study will investigate the use of photodynamic therapy to treat intra-abdominal infections resulting from perforated appendicitis in a rabbit model, as well as against bacteria cultured from samples collected during standard of care human appendectomy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia in humans, yet there is no cure for AD and the increasing incidence of AD in developed countries poses a tremendous cost to society as lifespans increase. There are two forms of AD, those that have genetic determinants and those that arise sporadically upon aging and comprise the vast majority (~95%) of new AD cases diagnosed. Given that alterations in brain mitochondria appear early in the development of sporadic AD, we propose studies to further characterize the role of ECSIT, a key regulator of mitochondrial function in the development of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: A Bio-inspired Latent TGF- Conjugated Scaffold for Patient-specific Cartilage Regeneration Project Narrative While transforming growth factor beta (TGF-) has become one of the most widely utilized mediators to promote tissue engineered cartilage growth, current state-of-the-art delivery platforms are tailored for the administration of highly supraphysiologic doses, which are associated with the induction of pathologic cellular processes (fibrosis, hypertrophy, hyperplasia) that can limit tissue quality and thus the performance of the tissue graft in situ. This proposal investigates a novel, bio-inspired delivery platform, consisting of: 1) the delivery of TGF- to cells in its native latent form, which achieves a beneficial, controlled activity, akin to that during native cartilage development, and 2) the use of patient-specific reaction-diffusion models to guide latent TGF- scaffold design parameters in order to achieve optimal activity doses for individual patients. The delivery of model-optimized TGF- activity levels can yield critical improvements to tissue quality, thus improving clinical outcomes for engineered cartilage regeneration.

PHR: The Einstein-Nathan Shock Center of Excellence is part of the biggest Institute in the world for the study of the biology of aging , encompassing approximately 80 labs, which have emerged to stimulate the investigator intellectual environment for specific fields of research and to provide technology that is not practicable for the individual scientist.
