IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will use a novel statistical framework to obtain rates of new cancer cases and cancer deaths at the ZIP-code level, which will allow cancer control researchers and practitioners to focus their efforts on populations at greatest risk. Since the challenges of, and needs for, calculating small area cancer estimates is greatest in rural areas, we will focus on the largely rural states of Iowa, Kentucky, and New Mexico. We will construct user friendly maps and other interactive graphics that can be tailored and included on cancer control/public health websites and develop communication and educational materials to promote the use of these maps for cancer control purposes.

PHR: Project Narrative Patients with no-option critical limb ischemia (CLI) face to major limb amputations and huge health care costs. We propose to develop novel gene therapy, which employs E-selectin to prime ischemic limb to increase neovascularization and regeneration in ischemic tissues while decreasing tissue damage. It will ultimately eliminate the need for amputation and transform the care for PAD/CLI patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We have found that the growth suppressive effects of noncanonical Wnt signaling by Wnt5a in prostate cancer are mediated through ROR2, and that this Wnt5a/ROR2 signaling is activating the Hippo pathway to suppress YAP1/TAZ activity. We hypothesize this reflects a novel function of ROR2 that is context dependent, and that biomarkers can be identified that will identify the subset of tumors that will be responsive to Wnt5a-mimetic drugs such as Foxy5. The objectives are to determine the precise molecular basis for Wnt5a-mediated activation of the Hippo pathway (Aim 1) and to assess the therapeutic potential of stimulating this pathway, including identification of biomarkers that can predict which tumors may respond to Wnt5a-mimetic drugs (Aim 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common form of arrhythmia in humans, causing unpleasant symptoms, poor quality of life and responsible for ~ 20% of strokes. Available treatments are costly, have serious side effects, long-term toxicities and are not curative. This proposal is to identify novel small molecules that revert AF- associated arrhythmias in human using a novel generation of assays with unprecedented exploratory power and atrial physiology relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have recently established heterozygous gain-of-function (GOF) mutations in two interferon responsive genes, SAMD9 and SAMD9L (SAMD9/9L) as the major hereditary predisposition to childhood bone marrow failure and myelodysplastic syndromes. The molecular and functional consequences of these mutations on HSC biology and hematopoiesis is not completely understood. The proposed studies will use in vivo murine system and iPSC disease model to delineate the underlying mechanism by which GOF SAMD9L mutations cause hematopoietic defect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the development of resistance to PARP inhibitors (PARPis) poses a significant clinical challenge for the management of high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC), the mechanisms underlying the resistance are not fully understood. Our proposed studies aim to explore the role of NAD+ metabolism in the acquired resistance of HGSOC to PARPis. This research will reveal a novel mechanism by which HGSOC acquire resistance to PARPis and will provide important insights into a new therapeutic option for targeting PARPi- resistant HGSOC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Consistent with its fundamental roles in neurobiology and cell development, complete knockouts of dynein stop the entire MT transport machinery and inhibit mitosis. Mutations that alter the processivity or velocity of cytoplasmic dynein movement lead to pathogenesis of motor neuron degeneration, Alzheimer’s disease, ALS, lissencephaly and schizophrenia, and the absence of axonemal dynein arms causes male infertility and primary ciliary dyskinesia. A detailed investigation of dynein’s mechanochemical cycle and its regulation by dynactin and cargo adaptor proteins will significantly contribute to our understanding of how points mutants in the dynein/dynactin complex contribute to human disease and the development of specific chemical inhibitors of dynein function for the treatment of these diseases in future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative  The neural crest is an important stem-like cell population, known for its migratory behavior, and essential for the normal development of numerous derivatives, such as the craniofacial skeleton, epidermal pigment cells, and much of the peripheral nervous system. Abnormalities in the neural crest contributes to neurocristopathies like familial dysautonomia as well as neural crest-derived cancers (i.e., neuroblastoma, pheochromocytoma, melanoma). Further study of the neural crest and its development will lend insight into this unique population of cells and give further indication of how irregularities in its development can contribute to these health conditions, allowing for the development of targeted treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We innovate instrumentation and methodology to develop a novel technology for capturing protein structure at unprecedented depth and speed. Our technology combines techniques from cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM) and mass spectrometry while drawing on concepts from astrophysics to 1) overcome a decades-old methodological bottleneck limiting cryo-EM sample vitrification and 2) maximize the structural insight obtainable by combining the atomic-level detail offered by cryo-EM imaging and the highly resolved measurement of chemical makeup offered by mass spectrometry. These technologies will enable high-throughput proteome- scale structural biology; as such, they will advance our understanding of cellular function and in turn our ability to advance biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 10 million children in the U.S. live with atopic dermatitis, or eczema, a chronic disease of the skin that causes unbearable itch, disturbances in sleep, and decreased quality of life. Although children with atopic dermatitis are more likely to suffer from learning disabilities, inattention, and poor memory, little is known about the direct and indirect effects of atopic dermatitis on cognition, the mental processes involved in gaining knowledge and problem solving and which can significantly impact long-term health, social, and economic outcomes. In this project, I will characterize the relationship between atopic dermatitis and cognition, identify subgroups of children who may be at greatest risk for cognitive impairment, and determine modifiable risk factors that may be targeted to reduce the negative impact of atopic dermatitis on cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Augmented reality (AR) is a rapidly-emerging technology that could provide a novel and exciting treatment strategy for smoking cessation. The goal of this project is to evaluate the efficacy of quitline treatment versus quitline treatment plus an AR smartphone app, while also considering key implementation questions to inform future quitline adoption. If efficacious, the AR app will be ready for dissemination and implementation through quitlines as well as other smoking cessation programs (e.g., in combination with counseling and/or pharmacotherapy), or as a key element of a novel mHealth intervention package.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New generation pod-style nicotine salt e-cigarettes are popular, however the long-term health consequences of vaping, either independently or in conjunction with smoking, remain unknown. Knowledge gained from this project will provide scientific evidence in support of data-driven regulation of e-cigarette devices under The Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act (FSPTCA), specifically concerning the risks of dual combustible and electronic cigarette use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This new application, which builds on success of a prior undergraduate IMSD program, requests funding to support a Maximizing Access to Research Careers (MARC) T34 at Emory University. We propose to support a diverse cohort of MARC Honors Scholars by building scientific identity and resilience while fostering scientific creativity and embracing research excellence through a structured program as well as an engaged and supportive community. The proposed research training program, which will complement, but not duplicate, requirements for students to complete their degrees will incorporate didactic, research, mentoring, and career development elements to prepare trainees for entry into and completion of research-focused higher degree programs in biological/biomedical fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Sepsis is a life-threatening consequence of infection that can cause shock, organ failure, and death. Our preliminary studies suggest that during bacterial sepsis, links between a receptor in the nervous system, TRPV1, and cells of immune system are responsible for strong anti-inflammatory and protective effects of two lipids, N-oleoyl dopamine (OLDA) and N-arachidonoyl dopamine (NADA). We will further investigate the anti- inflammatory and protective mechanisms of OLDA and NADA, with the long-term goal to define therapeutic targets for sepsis and other inflammatory processes based on this novel neuroimmune link.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bariatric surgery efficiently and sustainably ameliorates the symptoms of obesity and its complications, including type 2 diabetes and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, but the precise mechanisms by which the positive effects of bariatric surgery are conferred remain unclear. We propose to leverage our unique surgical mouse models and state-of-the-art technology to examine the role of bile acids in mediating the beneficial effects of bariatric surgery. The results of our studies will provide novel mechanistic insights that may lead to a new generation of cost-effective, non-invasive therapies for obesity and its complications.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Neuroscience Training Program at Mount Sinai provides rigorous, broad-based, individualized and multidisciplinary training to Year 1 and 2 predoctoral students in basic and translational neuroscience research, including research with a disease-focus. The goal of the Program is to enhance the ability of our trainees to acquire critical skillsets necessary for high-quality doctoral dissertation research and a productive and impactful career in the science-related workforce.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Childhood undernutrition is a pervasive problem worldwide, resulting in reduced linear growth (stunting), increased risk of disease and cognitive defects that persist into adulthood. Maternal health profoundly influences fetal and childhood development, and mothers that are stunted are more likely to give birth to stunted children. Because gut microbes influence growth and immune function, we propose to investigate the role of the maternal microbiota in shaping offspring health, with the goal of identifying specific microbial species and immune pathways for targeted intervention to ameliorate the global burden of undernutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this application is to understand how the epithelial-specific ER stress sensor IRE1b (ERN2) and its ubiquitously expressed paralogue IRE1a (ERN1) contribute to intestinal homeostasis and host defense. This will be informative for how barrier epithelial cells interact with the lumenal and sub-epithelial microenvironment, and the biology of events implicated in the pathogenesis of the inflammatory bowel diseases. We also note these studies will uncover general rules underlying the activation of key ER stress sensors, and how the ER stress response affects the development and differentiation of goblet cells to produce a functional mucus barrier: a topic of general relevance to physiology of the alimentary tract and the development of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Neuroene Therapeutics has a clinical lead antiseizure drug (ASD) that is fast-acting, broad-spectrum, well- tolerated, stable at room temperature, and protect mitochondrial and neuronal health. This compound has potential for stabilizing and overriding cascading effects due to poisoning by organophosphate (OP) nerve agents. If successful, our drug could be a dual-purpose ASD for acute settings and to reduce long-term sequela associated with OP poisoning. Neuroene's clinical candidate could be made widely available commercially to improve the United States' health security posture due our commercial indications for pharmacoresistant seizures, while being available during a public health emergency or bio-incident.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug resistance mutations from lack of patient adherence to daily dosing regimens reduce the effectiveness of HIV-1 treatment; therefore, potent inhibitors with the potential to be long-acting are needed to combat this problem. Islatravir (EFdA) is a promising potent, long-acting antiviral that targets HIV-1 reverse transcriptase, an essential enzyme in the HIV-1 replication cycle. I will study a drug mutation that causes resistance to one type of reverse transcriptase inhibitor but increases susceptibility to EFdA, which will aid in developing optimized combination treatments for future HIV-1 therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Germline stem cells (GSCs) are arguably the most fundamental cell type required for animal reproduction because these cells both maintain the germline throughout the animal’s life and produce the cells that go on to form either sperm or eggs. Remarkably, several key GSC regulatory genes are under strong natural selection for protein diversification between species of Drosophila. Our proposed study is aimed at identifying the functional consequences and correlated evolutionary pressures associated with the rapid protein evolution of bag of marbles, the key switch gene for GSC differentiation and its interaction with the intracellular bacterial symbiont, Wolbachia pipientis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Platelets are small cells that circulate in blood for about ten days, and their primary function is to initiate and promote hemostasis – clot formation at a site of blood vessel injury to prevent blood loss which requires rapid activation of platelet molecular and cellular responses to drive clotting; conversely, platelet hyper- reactivity creates a pro-thrombotic state with increased risk of blood clots that can block vessels, a major clinical concern. Therefore, control of platelet activity is a high impact research goal broadly affecting many disease states as well as aging; however, thorough understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms that regulate platelet reactivity remains incomplete. In this study we will investigate new molecular regulators of platelet reactivity in healthy plasma we have identified and begun to characterize, which affect specific but poorly understood platelet responses, including their mechanisms of action, roles in platelet functional response, and contributions to hemostasis and thrombotic potential, with broad implications across the spectrum of clinical management of bleeding and clotting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Impaired sentence processing is one of the major difficulties experienced by many persons with aphasia. In this project, persons with aphasia will participate in a set of implicit structural priming experiments and a treatment study with the goals of improving their independent and lasting sentence production and comprehension. Findings from this project will lead to the development of a novel, implicit-learning based treatment for communication deficits in aphasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Basophils and dendritic cells are white blood cells that release chemicals linked to causing allergy symptoms. We have evidence for a unique interaction between these cells and so-called epithelial cells –a kind of cell common to organs, such as the skin and lung. By better understanding this interaction, we might learn why allergies persist and possibly develop new strategies to treat allergic diseases in general.!

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Substance use abuse and dependence are especially complex disorders, with innumerable genetic and environmental risk factors, highly variable patterns of onset, offset and comorbidity with psychiatric disorders, cardiovascular disease and cancer. This project will develop Mendelian randomization based statistical methods and software and apply them to unique data from the Netherlands on genomic methylation. The project will improve understanding of the causes and effects of substance abuse and dependence, and how best to prevent and treat these disorders and their sequelae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic nephropathy (DN) is a complex, heterogeneous complication of diabetes that is characterized by progressive renal decline, the genetic basis of which is not well understood. To advance this area of research, we’ve developed an innovative family-based approach to accelerate gene discovery in DN that leverages one of the world’s largest and well-characterized cohorts of diabetic patients with rapid progression of renal decline; using this approach, we’ve identified putative disease-causing variants in 2 genes not previously known to contribute to DN. The proposed research will determine the functional roles of these genes in rapid renal decline and expand upon this study by performing WES-based gene discovery in additional, newly identified high-risk pedigrees enriched for rapid renal decline and investigating the biological impact of the identified candidate genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative – Iodine Catalyzed Cross-Coupling Reactions The proposal aims at developing the mechanism for green synthetic protocols of a few key chemical bonds, functional groups, and frameworks prevalently appearing in modern drug molecules. It focuses on the study of coupling reactions for carbon-carbon and carbon-nitrogen bond formations. The proposed iodine-catalyzed cross-couplings have obvious advantages over the transition metal-catalyzed coupling protocols widely employed in the drug molecule synthesis for using an inexpensive green catalyst and effectively avoiding toxic metal catalyst residues in final drug molecules. The new methods are expected to serve the critical need for medicinal chemists in the course of preparing the corresponding chemical bonds and frameworks for novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Elevated large artery stiffness with aging contributes to cardiovascular disease (CVD) events such as myocardial infarction, stroke and CVD death in part from isolated systolic hypertension (ISH, (i.e., increased systolic but not diastolic blood pressure). Sympathetic nerve activity (SNA) also increases with advancing age but it is unknown if SNA contributes directly to large artery stiffness in older adults with ISH. Therefore, successful completion of the proposed aims will have a significant clinical impact by identifying SNA as a novel therapeutic target for the treatment of elevated aortic and carotid stiffness in older adults with ISH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We have developed and clinically translated the combination of trabectedin and irinotecan as an EWS-FLI1 targeted therapy for Ewing sarcoma. While the clinical evaluation of this combination is promising and multiple tumor regressions have been observed, the activity has been limited by what appears to be intrinsic mechanisms of resistance. The goal of the current study is to exploit these mechanisms to develop novel EWS-FLI1 directed combination therapies with improved activity and less toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The late evolutionary emergence of two specialized projection neurons in the hominid insular cortex, von Economo neurons and fork cells, suggests these neurons may be the neuronal correlate of human-like social intelligence, while their malfunctions are associated with devastating neuropsychiatric diseases including schizophrenia, dementia, autism, and Alzheimer disease. A recent finding that these specialized projection neurons also occur in macaque anterior insula provides an unprecedented opportunity for functional characterization of these unique neurons in the laboratory. By complementing the technical strength and unique resources of two collaborating labs in China and in USA, we scale up a cost-efficient, multidisciplinary approach to macaque anterior insula to decipher transcriptomic signatures, physiology and connectivity of these two novel cell types, which will provide unprecedented knowledge and resources to understand human- like social intelligence and related neuropsychiatric conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT This study has high potential for characterizing novel blood-based biomarkers to identify preclinical ADRD and test their utility in predicting clinical ADRD. No other study has a similar design with repeated blood mtDNA mutations, cognitive assessments, and brain imaging data during midlife, a critical time window for interventions to prevent clinical ADRD development. By also using data from four large cohorts of older adults, we can determine the clinical utility of these mtDNA biomarkers to predict clinical ADRD and move the field closer toward the NIH’s goal of personalized health interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Microbial infections are likely risk factors for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease. Evidence of infections can be found by aligning DNA fragments from samples collected in humans to microbial reference genomes. This project will leverage large, existing next generation sequencing cohorts of AD cases in controls to explore mechanisms driving microbe-mediated AD risk, including the role of variants in the human genome.

PHR: The Summer Research Training in Aging for Medical Students Program will accept sixteen medical students between their first and second year of medical school. Students will have nine weeks of research training with experienced research mentors and faculty mentors who will introduce them to clinical geriatrics, didactic sessions on research methods, aging processes and geriatrics, and will be expected to present their research locally as well as at the American Geriatrics Society (AGS) annual meeting.

PHR: NARRATIVE Even though T cells are exposed to persistent antigen in chronic infections, cancer, autoimmunity and transplantation, we know very little about how T cell responses are maintained or how their function is modulated during chronic antigen stimulation. In this proposal, using a mouse model of chronic viral infection, we will study how co-stimulation and cellular interactions shape the maintenance and function of PD-1+ CD8 T cell responses. This understanding will be critical to understand fate decisions by chronically stimulated CD8 T cells and to improve immune interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol and other drug (AOD) abuse and violence in families are co-occurring risk factors that drive health disparities and mortality among Native Americans (NA), and thus, the long-term goal of this research is to promote health and wellness, while preventing and reducing AOD abuse and violence in NA families by testing an efficacious, sustainable, culturally-relevant and family-centered intervention for cross-national dissemination. Our central hypothesis is that the sustainable and community-based Weaving Healthy Families program will reduce and postpone AOD use, decrease and prevent violence in families, and promote resilience and wellness (including mental health) among NA adults and youth. The expected outcomes of the proposed research are an efficacious, culturally relevant, and sustainable community-based program to promote health and wellness among NA families that will address the factors that drive health disparities and promote individual, family, and community resilience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Continuous molecular monitoring has advanced from sensors tested in benchtop beakers, into numerous demonstrations of sensors inserted into animal jugulars for blood monitoring, and is now emerging into monitoring in the skin’s interstitial fluid which is the clinically successful approach used in wearable glucose monitors. However, a major knowledge gap for molecular monitoring centers on a simple yet impactful question: while glucose monitors have found hypodermal sensor placement to be most accurate, for other analytes and diseases what tissue layer in the skin, if any, will provide clinically accurate continuous monitoring? The objective of this R21 proposal is to fill this knowledge gap by creating and in-vivo testing the first ever multi-depth sensor array that enables simultaneous monitoring of analytes in the largely-acellular dermis vs. the adipocyte-rich hypodermis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Integrated Biological Systems Training in Oncology (IBSTO) program, begun in 2008, prepares pre- doctoral students and post-doctoral fellows for careers in cancer research by comprehensive training in basic and translational oncology, communications, and career building. The IBSTO program takes place in a world- class cancer research environment with state-of–the-art facilities, experienced preceptors, extensive resources, and strong institutional support. The long-term mission of the IBSTO program is to advance inclusive excellence in cancer research and to enable and empower a diverse population of talented trainees to pursue diverse and impactful career paths that contribute to the amelioration of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The research in this Center focuses on regulatory mechanisms in skin biology with a focus on epidermal stem cells, epidermal differentiation, skin repair, melanocytes, and skin vascular biology. The work has strong relevance to skin regeneration and regenerative medicine; to skin diseases with a disrupted barrier; and to skin aging and early stages of skin carcinogenesis. The work on melanocytes is relevant to a variety of pigmentation abnormalities and the work on skin vascular function is relevant to a number of vascular abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Lyme disease, caused by bacteria Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato, is the most common arthropod-transmitted disease in the U.S. The investigations proposed in this study will expand our understanding on the mechanisms of wild birds as reservoirs to maintain Lyme disease bacteria in nature. Such information can facilitate the understanding of vector-borne enzootic cycle, fostering the development of public health approaches for the intervention of B. burgdorferi spread in nature, reducing the risks of human exposure to Lyme disease causing bacteria

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The Case Medical Student Summer Research Program in Aging and Alzheimer’s Disease (MSSRPA) at Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine (CWRU SOM) will attract medical students to careers as physician-scientists by providing students with a 12-week research experience during the summer between their first and second year of medical school under the mentorship of highly qualified and motivated faculty mentors in aging and Alzheimer’s disease. The 19 mentors are well-funded, garnering $14M per year, (average $738,000 per investigator) and currently train 25 medical students in their labs, in addition to PhD students and postdoctoral fellows. The academic institutional environment at CWRU SOM is ideal to support this program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, the number of deaths resulting from opioid over dose is rapidly increasing and has reached epidemic proportions in recent years. The available FDA-approved treatment options for opioid over doses and withdrawal symptoms are limited and inadequate. Here we want to test whether TFEB, a master regulator of autophagy could reduce opioid-induced withdrawal symptoms as well as tolerance, dependence and respiratory depression by enhancing synaptic plasticity based on solid evidence that TFEB physically interacts with opioid receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  The actin cytoskeleton has been historically studied for its functional role in the cytoplasm, although its existence in the nucleus has been identified over 50 years ago. In this proposal, we aim to study the elusive nuclear actin in multiple fields that it has never been explored before: understanding its function and consequences of its breakdown during aging, investigating how nuclear actin regulation changes during stress, and investigating the impact of nuclear actin on DNA repair and transcriptional regulation. This highly innovative proposal aims to tackle a very young and burgeoning field by developing cutting edge genetics, microscopy, biochemical, and computational tools to answer questions that were previously unanswerable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Musculoskeletal diseases are among the most prevalent health conditions and lead to chronic pain, disability, psychological distress and decreased quality of life. Thus, research into the prevention and treatment of these disorders is critically needed. The overall goal of the Center for Musculoskeletal Research is to foster interdisciplinary and collaborative work that leads to a deeper understanding of musculoskeletal science, in a way promotes new approaches to the diagnosis and treatment of musculoskeletal diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative: This training program in the fundamentals of biochemistry and molecular biology is designed to equip the next generation of scientists with the skills and basic knowledge that provide the foundation for all modern biomedical science. Key to our mission is to enhance the diversity of our trainees by recruiting and retaining a diverse student body. Students who graduate from this program will be trained in critical thinking, ethical and independent research, and a variety of key skills in biochemistry and molecular biology that will lead to employment in academic and biomedical research in industry, teaching, and a variety of additional science careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The transcriptional history of a cell comprises critical developmental or adaptive ‘decisions’ that have shaped its present state. We aim to capture these past histories on a genome level through the novel approach of transcriptional endpoint marking (TEM), which introduces a permanent genetic mark at the locus of actively transcribed genes. This method will enable us to uncover informative markers of past developmental branch points and drivers of fate decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Systemic lupus erythematosus is a severe autoimmune disease in which antibodies to self- components cause inflammation in many organs. Current therapies for SLE are not effective enough and have many side effects. The focus of the Feinstein Institutes for Medical Research ACE project is to analyze the origins and mechanisms for expansion of the specialized immune cells that arise during flares of disease. These studies may then allow for the proper selection of patients for clinical trials of new treatments that target the relevant pathways to maintain the remission state.

It is necessary to develop new approaches for prevention and therapies. The establishment of the ICMH Basic Science Resource Center (ICMH-BSRC) will provide the resources required by individual investigators and teams of investigators to accelerate progress towards understanding and treating musculoskeletal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the shift in biomedical research towards big data and data-driven strategies, a major challenge is to robustly translate the vast amount of information generated into meaningful biological insights and clinically relevant information. The overall goal of the University of Michigan SBDRC is to leverage our strengths in genomic editing, bioinformatics, and mouse modeling to enable a rapid transition from discovery to function and to address biologic and disease context, as well as facilitating the development of appropriate state-of-the-art in silico and in vivo disease models. The key objective for UM-SBDRC is to accelerate ongoing skin research toward new discoveries and ultimately benefit a wide range of patients with cutaneous disorders.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  The prevalence of hypertension increases with age. The purpose of the proposed research is to determine the role of renal stem cell-derived exosomes in aging-related kidney dysfunction and hypertension. Completion of the project may offer a new preventive and therapeutic approach for aging-associated kidney dysfunction and hypertension which will benefit the US population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parent grant “Reducing Avoidable Nursing Home-to-Hospital Transfers of Residents with ADRD: An Analysis of Interdisciplinary Team Communication using Text Messages” (1R01AG078281-01) In this project we examine how interdisciplinary communication using text messaging can improve delivery of age-friendly care to NH residents and prevent avoidably NH-to-hospital transfer. This study will provide information needed for the development and testing of interventions using convenient, low-cost technologies, like text messaging, to ultimately reduce morbidity and mortality in residents with ADRD.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative University of Iowa researchers use flow cytometry and microscopy to study human diseases or their associated therapies, such as prostate and breast cancer, multiple myeloma, lymphoma, cancer metastasis, autoimmune disease, immunotherapy, neurodegenerative disease, influenza, SARS/COVID infection, cellular effects of PCB pollutants, and stem cell therapies. The cells that hold the key to understanding and treating these diseases are often present in minuscule numbers and cannot be readily examined with both technologies in the same experiment, which necessitates the acquisition of an imaging cytometer to ensure these unique cell populations can be quantitatively and qualitatively examined concurrently. Ensuring University of Iowa investigators are equipped with state-of-the-art instrumentation to perform these studies will enable advances in our understanding of human health and disease and allow us to uncover therapeutic avenues to treat adverse conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Disorders of the nervous system inflict staggering costs to our society across the lifespan, highlighting a major need to train the next generation of neuroscientists. The NBIO program at UNC-CH has provided graduate- level training in neuroscience research for the past 57 years, and our trainees have advanced to careers in academia, industry, and other science-related fields. This predoctoral training grant prepares NBIO graduate students to discover new principles and knowledge of brain function, information that is needed to develop novel treatments for a diversity of brain disorders and diseases.
PROJECT_TERMS: Neurosciences;pre-doctoral;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Neuroscience Predoctoral Training at UNC-Chapel Hill

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Exposure to trauma can lead to premature cognitive decline, as early as mid-life, and adversely affect people quality of life. First responders who were 20-35 years old at the time of September 11 terror attack, are at a greater risk for premature cognitive decline, especially if they have other health consequences such as respiratory disorders or depression. This proposal aims to assess cognitive decline, using a battery of neuropsychological tests and neuroimaging measures, to advance our understanding of premature cognitive decline and its neurobiological mechanisms among the youngest first responders that will contribute to the development of early interventions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Men who have sex with men (MSM), especially young Black and Latino MSM, have the highest rates of HIV diagnoses in the United States. The goal of the proposed Type II Hybrid Study is to improve pre-exposure prophylaxis screening, counseling, initiation, adherence, and persistence in young Black and Latino MSM in two high-priority settings.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Major recent transformations in health care financing and delivery within and outside of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) are now presenting Veterans with unprecedented health care choices. These choices give Veterans opportunities to make decisions about their use of VA and non-VA health care that optimize the timeliness, affordability, quality, and patient-centeredness of their care. However, these decisions also carry great potential for unintended consequences if they are not well-informed. Despite such high stakes, little is known about how Veterans are currently making decisions about using VA and non-VA health care, what information they want to use in this decision-making, and how the provision of information to Veterans about their health care options could be improved. This research will examine how Veterans are now making decisions about using VA and non-VA health care and identify promising new strategies to better support Veterans in making well-informed, personalized decisions about their VA and non-VA health care options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop general-purpose, scalable, and open-source statistical shape modeling (SSM) tools, which will present unique capabilities for automated anatomy modeling with less user input. The proposed tech- nology will introduce a number of signiﬁcant improvements to current SSM approaches and tools, including the support for challenging modeling problems, inferring shapes directly from images (and hence bypassing the seg- mentation step), parallel optimizations for speed, and new user interfaces that will be much easier and scalable than the current tools. The proposed technology will constitute an indispensable resource for the biomedical and clinical communities that will enable new avenues for biomedical research and clinical investigations, provide new ways to answer biologically related questions, allow new types of questions to be asked, and open the door for the integration of SSM with clinical care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: VA has been aggressively hiring additional staff to improve mental health access and working to improve productivity, but productivity measures do not reveal what sequences of care might affect capacity. We propose to use a data science method, sequence analysis, to determine whether we can use VA administrative data to measure reliable sequences of mental health care. We focus on sequences of mental health services following a new diagnosis of depression because depression is highly prevalent, and a new diagnosis is likely to initiate a new sequence of care. Our long-term objective is to implement sequence analysis measures to help managers and clinicians identify whether patients are engaged in a sequence of care that is associated with positive or negative outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Richter’s syndrome (RS) is a critical complication of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) patients, and a barrier to CLL management, with patients exhibiting refractoriness to most existing therapies and a median overall survival of ~12 months. The evolutionary trajectories and biological mechanisms leading to RS development from the antecedent CLL are largely unknown, because of the relative rarity of primary RS samples and the limited availability of genetically-engineered mouse models. The objective of these studies is to dissect pathogenic mechanisms of RS in human genetics-inspired mouse models, to identify disease-specific oncogenic circuitries and targetable vulnerabilities, and to test a panel of drugs pre-clinically to provide the basis for tailored therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed study is relevant to public health because narrowing of brain arteries is one of the most common causes of stroke worldwide. Compelling evidence suggests novel antithrombotic medications could reduce the rate of stroke in patients with narrowed brain arteries. The proposed study will directly compare novel antithrombotic medications to standard care antiplatelet medications for preventing stroke and death from vascular causes in patients with narrowed brain arteries. The study will incorporate the NINDS Common Data Elements.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Alcohol use disorder (AUD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) frequently co- occur, and having both disorders is associated with greater psychological and functional impairment than having either disorder alone. The most effective PTSD treatment, prolonged exposure (PE) is less effective when individuals also have AUD. Anti-relapse medication appears promising to improve the effectiveness of PE to help individuals reduce alcohol use and PTSD symptoms and improve functioning. This study compares PE with and without topiramate, a medication shown to both reduce drinking and PTSD symptoms, with the hypothesis that combined PE and topiramate will be more effective than PE and placebo. The aim of this grant is to improve treatment outcomes for Veterans with AUD and PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This project focuses on a newly recognized function of a unique population of regulatory T cells (Tregs) that resides in visceral adipose tissue (VAT) of lean, but not obese, mice and humans, and is capable of reining in both inflammation and metabolic dysfunction and, thereby, protecting against type-2 diabetes, cardiovascular diseases and certain cancers. We demonstrate that VAT Tregs regulate the dynamics of local adipogenesis by directly controlling the differentiation of stroma-associated adipocyte precursor cells, and study the molecular underpinnings of this function, its age-dependence and its sexual dimorphism. Obesity and its downstream comorbidities are major health challenges of the 21st century -- specifically enhancing the representation or activity of VAT Tregs offers a potential alternative to current frontline insulin-sensitizing drugs, whose side-effects have sometimes elicited concern.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a need for an artificial oxygen carrier to care for patients in settings where banked human blood is unavailable or undesirable. To address this need, we have developed ‘ErythroMer’ (EM), a first-in-class bio- synthetic, nano-cyte, blood substitute. The goals of this project are to conduct IND enabling studies of EM, comprising: Detailed non-GLP pharmacokinetic, biodistribution metabolism and excretion studies with exploratory toxicology, GLP hemocompatibility, GLP-safety pharmacology and GLP expanded acute dose toxicology studies to determine starting doses of EM in an initial clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social behaviors in humans and other animals are dynamically regulated by steroid hormones such as androgens (e.g., testosterone); however, the effects androgens have on the brain are unclear. The proposed research will use the highly social cichlid fish Astatotilapia burtoni to study how androgens regulate genetic and neurobiological mechanisms in the brain. Given that all vertebrates have androgens and similar genes and neurons that regulate social behavior, the mechanisms identified by this work can be studied further in other organisms, including humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given increasing rates of cannabis use, the development and evaluation of new treatments for adults with cannabis use disorder (CUD) is crucial. Reduction in cannabis use may be a viable alternative goal to abstinence, but the amount of reduction necessary to achieve remission of CUD is unknown. This proposal addresses key gaps in CUD trials by determining gender-specific “lower-risk” cannabis use associated with successful CUD remission during an 8-week course of computerized cognitive-behavioral therapy and examining the role of the sex hormone, progesterone, in successful cannabis reduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a hepatotropic virus that establishes chronic infection in ~70% of those exposed. While effective direct acting antiviral (DAA) therapeutic combinations are highly potent, we are not yet on track to achieve the WHO goal of elimination by 2030, which will require a scaling-up of HCV screening, linkage-to-care, reduction of treatment cost as well as advancing our understanding HCV persistence and drug resistance. Importantly, because viral cell-to-cell spread has been implicated in antiviral escape, immune escape, and persistence of viruses in general, the insights gained through the proposed HCV studies should broadly inform future antiviral strategies for hepatitis C and related viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to compare and evaluate the 3D STAIR-UTE direct myelin imaging technique and the SyMRI indirect myelin imaging technique for evaluation of myelin damage in AD. We will conduct studies using biological myelin phantoms, human brain specimens from donors without and with AD, and a cross-sectional study of healthy volunteers and patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and AD, to validate novel quantitative MRI techniques for detection of myelin quantity and quality. This fellowship will conduct a systematic comparison between 3D STAIR-UTE and SyMRI in depicting myelin changes for both ex vivo samples and in vivo controls and patients, thereby facilitating advancement of new diagnostic approaches for AD.

PHR: This training program trains predoctoral and postdoctoral fellows in multiple disciplines and state-of-the-art technologies. The intent is to elucidate biological mechanisms that form the basis of diseases, including cancer, that arise as a consequence of exposure to diverse environmental agents. The goal of this training program is to produce leaders in academia, the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries and regulatory agencies who have the experience and knowledge to understand and make informed decisions in the environmental health sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it helps identify the roles played by small molecular changes in DNA and RNA bases, often occurring in non-Watson-Crick structures, that reside in parts of human or viral genomes regulating gene expression. Methods developed here will aid our ability to sequence genomes, not just for the four common letters A, C, G and T/U, but also for some of the rare but significant base modifications that impact mutations, epigenetics, and viral activity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Veterans’ Choice Program and MISSION Act have transformed how the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) delivers care by expanding Veterans’ eligibility to receive VA-funded care from community providers. However, there is limited evidence about how this major structural change has affected the quality and equity of health care for Veterans, or their satisfaction with care. Given the challenges of coordinating care between VA and community providers, medically and socially vulnerable Veterans may be at particular risk for adverse outcomes from care fragmentation, underscoring a need to examine the impact of these changes on equity. Our study will use innovative analytic methods to examine the effects of these programs on the quality and equity of outpatient care and prescribing in Veterans. We will also examine how patient experiences with community care differ among vulnerable Veterans. This project will provide VA with critical evidence for guiding ongoing implementation of the MISSION Act and efforts to improve community care for vulnerable Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who inject drugs are among the most vulnerable to acquiring HIV, but very few women who inject drugs are prescribed pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for HIV prevention largely due to barriers within our healthcare system. This research will consider the perspectives of women who inject drugs, healthcare providers, and clinic leadership to improve the way primary care and reproductive health clinics deliver PrEP to women who inject drugs, thereby reducing new HIV infections in this population. The research and training in this application will prepare the candidate for an independent scientific career conducting intervention research among vulnerable populations with high capacity for real-world implementation and dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite an increased risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), African Americans underutilize hospice services, often opting for aggressive end-of-life care and are more likely to die in hospitals than non-Hispanic Whites. Though reasons for hospice underutilization are multifactorial, the sources of hospice information for older African Americans living with ADRD and their primary family caregivers have not been widely explored. This study aims to identify the sources and characteristics of hospice information in older African Americans living with ADRD and their caregivers and to determine the influence of information sources on hospice-decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite progress in treating primary tumors, metastatic disease to common sites including bone remains incurable. Inhibition of Gli2 using the bone targeted Gli2 inhibitor (GANT58), BT- GANT58-NPs, has shown promise for reducing tumor-associated bone destruction in 3 independent bone metastatic mouse models. In this application we propose particle modifications to improve tumor killing and further reduce bone destruction to work towards a clinically translatable formulation for use in patients with bone metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To explain the enigmatic endemicity of typhoid fever in the small Pacific island nation of Samoa since at least the 1960s, despite steady improvements in water and sanitation, we hypothesize that a unique strain of S. Typhi entered Samoa decades ago and expanded into the dominant circulating strain, and asymptomatic chronic gallbladder carriers of the strain serve as an effective long-term reservoir and source of infection. Through our close collaboration with the Samoa Ministry of Health, the “Samoa Typhoid Fever Surveillance Initiative,” we propose a series of comparative genomic and geospatial analyses integrating whole genome sequence data of Salmonella Typhi isolates from Samoa with clinical and household epidemiologic data to determine the population structure, evolutionary origins, and local patterns of transmission including the relative role of asymptomatic chronic carriers of Salmonella Typhi. Where previous large scale phylogenetic studies of Salmonella Typhi have demonstrated the feasibility and public health utility of our experimental approaches, none have focused on Samoa nor been implemented as part of an accelerated and coordinated national typhoid control program; therefore, our results will not only contribute a Polynesian perspective to the field of Salmonella Typhi genomics, but also present new information on endemic typhoid fever to assist the Samoa Ministry of Health and our international collaborators in public health decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal alcohol use (PAU) is a major and growing public health problem, with deleterious consequences on both the mother and child. The proposed project will integrate research on Alcohol Use Disorder, neuroimaging, and machine learning to (1) first investigate sex/gender differences in the relationship between stress reactivity and alcohol misuse via brain function in women outside of pregnancy, (2) then determine the role of social support in this relationship, and (3) finally determine how stress and social support interact as risk and protective factors during pregnancy. By identifying the contributions of stress, social support, and brain function to alcohol misuse, this work will form the basis for the development of sex/gender-informed interventions to prevent alcohol misuse during and outside of pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A novel analytic preclinical longitudinal molecular imaging platform that can dissect and quantify intratumor heterogeneity at high-resolution in the context of targeted drug delivery will be developed. Fusion of lifetime- sensing and high-density fluorescence intensity imaging in the Short-Wave Infrared window will provide near cellular resolution maps of subcutaneous xenograft tumors and patient derived xenograft models. Vasculature and glucose metabolism datasets will be integrated with distribution of target engagement of well-known therapeutic antibodies to quantify intratumor heterogeneity at high-resolution in live, intact animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuronal DNA damage and cell-cycle protein dysregulation are features of neurodegeneration that have also been associated with psychiatric diseases (e.g., schizophrenia and bipolar disorder). This study will investigate: 1) how the Rb/E2F pathway, a core component of cell-cycle signaling, is regulated in neurons that have sustained DNA damage and 2) whether this pathway contributes to neuronal DNA damage repair. Completion of this study will support the identification of potential treatment targets for preserving genomic integrity in neurons exposed to genotoxic stress.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public mental health because it will dissect the circuits that mediate different components of motivational drive. Motivational deficits are very prominent in psychiatric disorder and can seriously impact an individual’s quality of life. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trauma can contribute to the development of dampened reward processing (anhedonia) and disrupted cognitive control, which are precipitants and perpetuators of symptoms in mental health disorders. This mentored-training project will use electroencephalography to characterize neurophysiological correlates of anhedonia and cognitive control impairment in trauma-exposed people, and it will identify the neurophysiological mechanisms of response to treatment in those completing a novel mindfulness-based intervention called vibroacoustically-augmented breath focused mindfulness. Results from this study will delineate individual differences in brain mechanisms of mental health disorders and inform future intervention strategies for trauma-exposed people with these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As people living with HIV (PLWH) are aging, comorbidities such as HPV-related anal cancer, are emerging as a new public health concern for this population. HPV vaccination is an essential component to a cancer prevention plan among PLWH. In efforts to decrease the personal, clinical, and public health burden of anal cancer and other HPV-related disease, we propose to tailor and implement the effective, evidence-based, multi-level 4 PillarsTM Transformation program to promote the uptake of the HPV vaccine among PLWH.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Gulf War Illness (GWI) affects an estimated 25-32% of the over 700,000 coalition troops deployed to the Persian Gulf as part of the First Gulf War. GWI causes a range of pain, fatigue, gastrointestinal, skin, neurologic, and respiratory symptoms. New treatments to reduce GWI-associated morbidity are critically needed. Research suggests a role for the gastrointestinal microbiome in mediating health, including through impacting metabolism and immunity. The disruption of this microbiome plays a role in multiple diseases, and preliminary data suggest that Veterans with GWI have altered gut microbiota. Here, we will assess gut microbiome function and inflammation in Veterans with GWI who experience gastrointestinal symptoms. We will also evaluate the effectiveness of a dietary fiber prebiotic supplement intervention on improving the quality of life of Veterans with GWI. Together, these data will provide important insight into the underlying role of the gut microbiome in GWI and the potential for treatments targeting the microbiome to reduce GWI symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative  Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a major global healthcare burden, but effective therapies are lacking in part due to the complex genetic architecture of alcohol consumption and dependence. A combination of genetic and transcriptomic factors has been proposed as mechanisms underlying variation in alcohol-related behaviors, but these factors are difficult to study in humans due to confounding environmental factors. We hypothesize that by using a novel complex mouse genetic model, we can identify candidate genes and functional pathways which may be involved in the genetic mechanisms affecting ethanol consumption and validate individual candidate genes as potential therapeutic targets by modulating gene expression in a mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite inhibitory neurons being a prominent neuronal subtype implicated in numerous psychiatric illnesses including schizophrenia, depression, and anxiety, there is a critical gap in our knowledge about the fundamental governing properties of the inhibitory synapse. A disproportionate amount of research has focused on delineating excitatory synapse neurobiology, which has uncovered substrates for disease intervention, but to better understand and treat psychiatric illness we must also appreciate the role of inhibitory synaptic transmission. This study aims to uncover the governing properties of the inhibitory synapse from two angles by elucidating the postsynaptic structure that mediates the segregation of neurotransmission and how this segregation facilitates an autonomous role of GABAergic spontaneous release in plasticity mechanisms, ultimately impacting how we approach inhibition in psychiatric illness.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI), or concussion, has emerged as a potential risk factor for the development of neurodegenerative conditions including Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer's disease is characterized in part by the buildup of aggregates of the protein tau within cells of the brain. Yet how mTBI may contribute to the development of this tau buildup remains unknown. Disruption of normal sleep-wake patterns is a frequent complaint after mTBI, while in aging populations, sleep disruption appears to promote the development of neurodegenerative pathology. In this study will test whether sleep disruption after mTBI exposure contributes to the development of post-traumatic tau pathology. We will also specifically test whether the dysfunction of the brain's waste clearance system, called the glymphatic system, links mTBI with tau pathology. These studies may pave the way for new approaches to preventing dementing conditions like Alzheimer's disease in both Veteran and civilian populations exposed to mTBI earlier in life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE: Graduates of this fellowship program will be national leaders who will have a significant scientific impact on research in pediatric treatment adherence and relevant health outcomes for many years to come. This program will result in effective interventions that will enhance adherence to medical treatment for children and adolescents with a wide range of pediatric conditions. These advances will reduce the extraordinary negative impact of pediatric nonadherence and enhance children’s health by reducing symptoms, impairment, health care utilization, and the costs of pediatric chronic illness treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance: Stroke - like many brain diseases - is clearly associated with aging and a plethora of age-related conditions, but age-related co-morbidities, as a variable in stroke occurrence, severity and long-term recovery is seldom studied experimentally, but is one of the identified factors in the lack of progress in the discovery of new therapies for acute stroke brain damage. The Stroke and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias Predoctoral Training Program will formalize and standardize our already strong training programs in the biomedical sciences and focus on aging and stroke research by creating a new generation of young scholars who can address the need for innovative stroke research for the citizens of West Virginia and the nation.
PROJECT_TERMS: Alzheimer's disease related dementia;Stroke
PROJECT_TITLE: Stroke and Alzheimers Disease Related Dementias

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The autophagy pathway plays a key role in antiviral immunity by facilitating the clearance of viral proteins and particles in host cells, but how viruses are specifically targeted for autophagic destruction is still poorly understood. In preliminary studies, this proposal shows a novel autophagy regulator cyclin-dependent kinase- like 5 (CDKL5) that protects mice against lethal infections with neurotropic viruses. The goal of this K08 proposal is to provide a 5-year rigorous training plan for the PI, Dr. Josephine Thinwa to cultivate the skills and resources necessary to build a robust independent research program aimed at investigating the interphase between autophagy and viral pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Pertussis (whooping cough) is a highly contagious, airborne disease that is rapidly re-emerging as a serious public health threat in the United States. The study goal is a rapid, point-of-care, antigen-detection, lateral flow immunoassay to detect Bordetella pertussis in nasopharyngeal specimens. If successful, the product will provide early diagnosis that enables effective early treatment and triggers public health measures that limit transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The heart is one of the most mechanically dynamic organs; it dilates and contracts to cycle its volume in order to pump between 5 to 30 liters of blood a minute. Heart stretch accelerates heart rate; however, how the pacemaker cells controlling heart rate sense and respond to mechanical stretch is unknown. We aim to identify the molecules behind mechanosensation in the cardiac pacemaker.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, first, middle): Reddy, Jr., Bobby Project Narrative: In this proposed project, Prenosis intends to introduce a powerful new dimension to the existing NOSIS dataset by generating and analyzing longitudinal, time-series biomarker data that will be linked to the existing time series clinical data from hospital Electronic Medical Records. Using samples that have already been collected and stored in the biobank, we will leverage our existing measurement pipeline to measure the concentrations of 40 critical protein biomarkers from 9,000 follow-up longitudinal samples for ~3,400 patients. Analytics built upon such a dataset could dramatically improve diagnostic, clinical decision support, and drug development products for sepsis and COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project narrative – public health statement The human genome encodes the genetic information required for human development and health. For this information to be used correctly, the genome needs to be folded in intricate three-dimensional structures, and defective folding can lead to many human diseases including cancer, developmental, and metabolic disorders. We will employ recently developed innovative genomic technologies to identify genetic elements encoded in the human genome that control folding of chromosomes, mediate correct chromosome segregation when cells divide, and ensure chromosomes do not become knotted and entangled with each other.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The ClinGen Monogenic Diabetes Expert Panel is determining which genes and genetic variants are involved in certain forms of diabetes known as monogenic diabetes in order to improve our ability to diagnose those forms of diabetes. Determining the specific genetic type of diabetes can improve management of blood sugar levels and other problems associated with the disease. In this project, we will focus on genes and variants that that cause types of monogenic diabetes that involve the immune system, fat distribution, and how the body uses insulin to lower blood sugar.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: There is evidence to suggest that traumatic brain injury (TBI) increases the risk of dementia and stroke; however, pathological mechanisms linking these conditions are yet to be fully elucidated. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA), the accumulation of amyloid protein (most commonly beta-amyloid, associated with Alzheimer's disease) within cerebral vasculature, may be one such mechanism. Following a repetitive mild TBI protocol starting at 2 months of age, we will determine whether cognitive deficits and neuropathology are altered at several timepoints post-TBI (short term: 7 days, and longer-term: 3 months) in a mouse model of CAA, with the goal of identifying mechanisms linking these conditions, which may in turn reveal novel targets for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myocardial infarction (MI) initiates a dynamic cellular response during the early phases of onset, as extensive inflammation propagates throughout cardiac tissues resulting in massive cardiomyocyte death and adverse ventricular remodeling. The RNA-binding protein, tristetraprolin (TTP), has wide-ranging anti-inflammatory effects and has been shown to prevent oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction by binding, and destabilizing the related mRNA transcripts. This proposal explores the regulatory role of TTP in early-onset MI and its therapeutic potential in attenuating cardiomyopathy to improve long-term prognoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a severely debilitating neurological disease primarily affecting young adults, in which some of the body's own immune cells, known as B lymphocytes (or B cells), unfortunately play an important role in damaging the central nervous system. Although there are promising treatments that remove these deleterious cells, we have no way to accurately select patients for anti-B cell therapies or to quantify the effect of such treatments on the number of B cells in the brain and peripheral organs in real-time. Herein, we propose a novel, highly sensitive and specific imaging toolbox that can be used to non-invasively detect B cells in the whole body and brain, monitor response to anti-B cell therapies, and optimize dosing for individual MS patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Making healthy food choices and eating in moderation during early childhood are central to obesity prevention and are thought to require effortful and goal-directed self-regulation. Scientific knowledge of the cognitive- developmental processes that serve to support children’s appetite self-regulation are surprisingly limited. This investigation will provide new scientific directions for obesity prevention by elucidating cognitive-developmental influences on young children’s ability to make healthy food choices and eat in moderation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endometriosis is an inflammatory gynecologic disease of reproductive-age women and is characterized by two primary symptoms chronic pelvic pain and infertility. Withania somnifera (active component Withaferin-A), an ancient medicinal plant, has been used to treat inflammatory disorders, neurological diseases or disorders, neuropathic and inflammatory pain, and cancers; and thus, it provides a therapeutic opportunity to treat endometriosis in women. Successful completion of the proposed research is expected to expand the understanding of the therapeutic effects of Withania somnifera/Withaferin-A and establish a novel preclinical and molecular therapeutic basis to use Withaferin-A as a non-steroidal and non-opioid therapy for the treatment of pelvic pain and infertility in women with endometriosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV (PLWH) are at the higher risk for impaired cognitive functions due to higher use of cocaine that could affect their immune functions and exacerbate CNS (central nervous system) impairment. However, little is known about the HIV harboring cell types in brain, effect of therapy on specific CNS cell types, and the modification of brain functions by cocaine use. Results of proposed innovative single-cell studies employing simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) infection and nonhuman primate animal models will generate cellular part list for brain regions and will illuminate novel insights into transcriptomic and epigenetic landscapes of CNS and how they are altered by viral infections and cocaine use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Simultaneous functional imaging of the brain and spinal cord can provide valuable insight into interactions and processing pathways between these organs in normal and abnormal states of spinal cord injury, chronic pain, and motor disease. Ultrahigh-field (7T and above) MRI offers new opportunities to visualize structures of interest with high spatial resolution, enhanced conspicuity and greater sensitivity, however, B1 and B0 inhomogeneities, and the lack of optimized receive coils limit imaging performance at high fields. In this project, we will develop a pre-shimmed parallel transmit array, an optimized receive array, and an RF/ΔB0 array to correct the severe B1 inhomogeneity, maximize the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), and correct B0 inhomogeneity in simultaneous human brain and spinal cord MR imaging at ultrahigh fields.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Young women in sub-Saharan Africa, who are already twice as likely to acquire HIV than their male counterparts, become even more susceptible to HIV infection during pregnancy and the postpartum periods. Because current prophylactic and treatment measures are unlikely to end the morbidity and mortality of HIV/AIDS in women of reproductive age, this project will explore the safety and antiviral properties of the HIV entry inhibitor eCD4-Ig in pregnant and postpartum rhesus macaques. If successful, this project will establish the pre-clinical foundation for testing the ability of eCD4-Ig to combat obstetric HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Circadian rhythms are fundamental for biology and medicine. Modern high-throughput technologies are revealing how the concentrations of many molecular species, including transcripts, proteins, and metabolites oscillate with the day and night cycle in every species, tissues, and organs. In close collaboration with life scientists, this project will develop the informatics tools that will enable the collection, integration, and analyses of this wealth of information and lead to novel and fundamental insights about the organization and regulation of circadian oscillations, their roles in health and disease, and their future applications to precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid overdose often leads to death due to suppression of respiration; therefore, strategies to prevent respiratory depression in addition to treatment of opioid addiction are necessary to prevent deaths in the opioid-use epidemic. Respiratory suppression occurs because neurons in the brain that drive breathing are inhibited (turned off) by narcotics; thus, understanding the neural pathways for breathing will allow us to devise effective neuromodulatory strategies to treat opioid-induced respiratory depression. We have proposed to characterize a novel breathing circuit that, when activated by stimulation of the cervical spine, has the potential to be an effective treatment of opioid-induced respiratory depression, and it is our hope that findings from these studies may lead to new and more effective treatments for respiratory depression secondary to opioid overdoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) constitutes a crisis public health problem in the United States. We are proposing initial human Phase I studies of C4X3256, a non-opioid, highly-selective orexin-1 receptor antagonist for the treatment of opioid use disorder, in addition to pharmaceutical development and preclinical toxicology enabling work for Phase II Proof of Concept.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Project Narrative: Changes in blood flow to match brain activity are essential for brain health, but the consequences of accompanying mechanical forces remain unknown. We recently discovered that brain blood vessels sense forces through the actions of the Piezo1 channel, and we propose here that Piezo1 is crucial in regulating blood flow to sustain neural activity. The focus of this proposal is to determine the mechanisms underlying blood flow regulation by Piezo1 in the brain in normal and hypertensive mouse models, with the ultimate goal of establishing a foundation for future work that seeks to prevent deficits in blood flow in human cardiovascular disease.

PHR: Project Narrative  The intervertebral discs of the lumbar spine naturally degenerate with age and are implicated in low back pain, the world’s leading cause of disability. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs) arise from stratified epithelia, the most relevant organ sites in the veteran population are the skin and oral cavity. SCC’s worst outcome is to break indolence and cause death through metastasis, most commonly in the lung. SCC deaths actually exceed melanoma deaths due to the high number of SCC cases. In veterans, elevated exposure to UV irradiation and tobacco carcinogens make the total and high-risk SCCs significantly higher than the civilian population. The dearth of spontaneous SCC lung metastasis models has hindered identification of their therapeutic targets. We have developed a genetic mouse model with spontaneous SCC lung metastasis that can be transplanted to immune competent or compromised mice. These models are unique tools for cross-species comparison with patient’s metastatic SCC. The proposed studies will identify prognostic markers and therapeutic targets for high risk metastatic SCCs and simultaneously test interventional therapies that will be brought into clinic in the near future.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative After a pet food recall due to melamine adulteration in 2007, the FDA has increasingly been called upon to expand the testing program that addresses the increasing threat to food safety and security through both naturally occurring pathogen outbreaks and intentional terrorism events. Partnership of FDA with Vet-LIRN laboratories can provides additional means of capacity building and capability enhancement to cope in the event of large-scale outbreak or threat incident. The Wisconsin Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory is committed to participate in Vet-LIRN program to increase the network’s ability to examine samples from animals adversely affected by contaminated or adulterated products, and contribute to overall food safety as animal food events could signal potential issues in the human food system.
