PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this project is for the Iowa State University Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory (ISU-VDL) to enter into a research cooperative agreement with the FDA CVM Vet-LIRN to enhance food safety and security efforts. It is of public health relevance because it will enhance proficiency in diagnostic testing of animal diseases caused by chemical contaminants. The ISU- VDL will participate in all activities in support of the FDA program to meet this public health need including sample analysis, providing analytical data to the FDA, participating in proficiency testing, validation and matrix extension of diagnostic methods, and by participating in the Vet- LIRN AMR Monitoring Program as a source laboratory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adoptive T cell therapy has demonstrated tremendous potential for cancer treatment, but an incomplete understanding of T cell signaling makes manufacturing of these therapies expensive and inefficient. Because T cell signaling has been shown to be regulated by the nanoscale spatial organization of signaling structures, we propose to build DNA origami probes to present 3D patterns of signaling molecules to T cells with nanometer- scale precision. The public health benefit of this project will be to provide new insights into how T cell signaling is regulated by spatial arrangement and provide both knowledge and a platform for efficient manufacturing of therapeutic cell products for cancer immunotherapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This two-phase “health equity acceleration” U01 application is submitted to participate in the FDA OMHHE Health Equity Innovation Award for “Racial & Ethnic Minority Acceleration Consortium for Health Equity (REACH) (U01)” focused on advancing “minority health and health equity focused research, outreach, and communications as well as support training and mentoring of diverse HBCU advanced students, fellows, and researchers.” Two pilot projects/programs submitted in this application will be developed under Phase 1, and subsequently implemented under Phase 2: a) A Pilot curriculum on “Regulatory Issues and Health Equity” and potential FDA OMHHE rotations for advanced students and faculty in HBCUs in Pharmacy (XULA College of Pharmacy) and Nursing (Helene Fuld School of Nursing CSU); and b) A Pilot research project which will move the discussion beyond barrier identification to develop strategies to address barriers to clinical trial diversity, in order to increase trustworthiness, enhance transparency in sponsors and researchers, and bolster willingness to participate for African Americans, thereby strengthening equity in participation of underrepresented minority racial and ethnic groups in clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH There is great need to diversify Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias (ADRD) research cohorts, improve methods and tools for conducting health disparities research related to AD/ADRD, and examine other risk factors like obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), associated with higher AD-risk in older blacks, as this is critically needed to optimize patient care paradigms. In this innovative hypothesis-driven study, we will utilize a health disparities research framework related to aging to examine whether socio-structural determinants of health (SDOH) can help explain racial/ethnic heterogeneity in OSA-AD outcomes. The significance and impact of this proposal is strengthened by enrollment of a unique population of older blacks in which we will obtain neuroimaging measures of vascular burden, amyloid, and tau as well as nocturnal polysomnography (NPSG) recordings, and prioritize acquisition of SDOH data to elucidate disease mechanisms to aid future discovery of novel AD prevention targets and disease-modifying treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV infection is lifelong and there is no cure; most research on HIV cure has focused on a strain called subtype B HIV-1. In this R01 application, we propose to leverage an existing biobank of a previously NIH-funded Ugandan HIV cohort (UARTO), which houses 12360 blood cell samples collected longitudinally over ten years from 500 unique non-subtype B HIV-1-infected individuals to obtain and compare viral reservoir profiles associated with these non-B variants. We expect our results will inform whether HIV cure strategies should be subtype-specific.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiovascular disease remains the major cause of morbidity in the US with the cost of care exceeding $555 billion in 2015 and as such, there has been a shift in emphasis from treatment of disease to the prevention of disease. Prevention of cardiovascular disease necessitates early detection and risk stratification, which may be facilitated by molecular and other multimodality imaging approaches allowing for a more precise and personalized approach to the evaluation and management of cardiovascular disease. For molecular imaging to emerge as a routine part of clinical practice, appropriate education within the cardiovascular physician community and training of a new breed of physicians and scientists is needed.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Multi-Modality Molecular and Transitional Cardiovascular Imaging
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(JA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS) is a devastating form of childhood onset epilepsy characterized by cognitive dysfunction and very frequent generalized onset seizures (GOS) that often lead to injury. Driven by the lack of effective therapies and the demonstrated safety and efficacy of brain-responsive stimulation for treating medically intractable focal onset seizures, this study will test whether brain-responsive neurostimulation can also be used to treat LGS. The intent of the proposed research is to test the safety and preliminary efficacy of responsive neurostimulation of thalamocortical networks (RNS-TCN) involved in GOS, to identify promising detection and stimulation approaches, and to characterize neurophysiological biomarkers of clinical efficacy that will aid future research and clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The recent discovery of 291 new GPCRs, many of which have or are posited to have peptides as ligands, has inspired many structure-activity relationship and drug discovery campaigns that use peptides to understand and target these GPCRs; one of which is CXCR4. Unfortunately, the tools to investigate the SAR of these GPCRs and to develop effective peptide drugs are considerably lacking, relying on one-at-a-time chemical synthesis with a limited variety of amino acids. We aim to expand upon a novel synthetic platform developed by our lab to rapidly equip peptides with non-proteinogenic functionalities, thereby increasing their chemical and pharmacological complexity, and thus establish a brand-new way to evolve ordinary peptides as next-generation GPCR drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  This research aims to leverage state-of-the-art data-driven models for accurate estimation of protein-ligand binding afﬁnity that has wide applications in drug discovery. To this end, a physics-guided neural network has been introduced, which with adherence to the physical models, incorporates new structural features from the input complexes. The outcome of this research will improve the current understanding of protein-ligand interactions and will beneﬁt the computer-aided drug design.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uterine fibroids (UFs; leiomyomas) are the most important benign neoplastic threat to women’s health worldwide. Current treatment options are limited beyond surgery, and the development of more effective medical therapies will require a better understanding of the underlying molecular pathogenesis of UFs. Accordingly, this proposal is impactful as it suggests a novel etiological basis to explain the development of MED12 mutation-positive UFs, the predominant UF subtype, through aberrant myometrial stem cell differentiation and transcription-dependent replication stress, and further offers proof-of-concept for therapeutic intervention using drugs that target the replication stress phenotype. The studies proposed herein thus address and mechanistically connect two overarching issues in the field: the pathogenesis of UFs and the development of non-hormonal treatment options.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks the establishment of the Puerto Rico Racial & Ethnic Minority Acceleration Consortium for Health Equity (PR-REACH) to support the advancement of Hispanic Puerto Ricans health equity, this is a first step in a research agenda to collaborate with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Office of Minority Health and Health Equity (OMHHE) across REACH research projects and activities by first building an administrative research and communication infrastructure; leadership team, three EQUITY research cores (Clinical Trials, Voices and Data), a training and mentoring core, and an advisory team. A pilot study under this consortium will be conducted to advance the understanding of substance use disorder patients’ journey as perspectives, preferences and unmet needs regarding substance use disorder (SUD) treatment with FDA approved medications in PR to be able to improve its outcomes and launch PR-REACH in PR. The PR-REACH will initiate with Hispanics living in Puerto Rico as a model than can inform and guide subsequent extrapolation to Hispanics in the US in collaboration with the FDA.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The advent of remote technologies such as video conferencing and secure web-portals have revolutionized approaches to health data collection and access to healthcare, where these technologies can be deployed in fully remote and hybrid approaches for clinical trials which could help promoting more participation among under-represented groups as well as by bridging geographic distance and reducing participant burden (e.g., less travel time, more flexibility and confidentiality). However, these approaches have yet to be optimized for all possible beneficiaries of technological advances in clinical trials and healthcare, especially targeting under- represented populations that are disproportionately experiencing social and geographic isolation. To address these concerns, the current proposal seeks to leverage the team’s existing community connections in states across 4 different regions of the U.S. among the Asian American and Pacific Islander (including Native Hawaiian), American Indian, Hispanic/Latino, and sexual and gender minority populations to: (1) (a) co-create and maintain 4 virtual and hybrid advisory groups to address health issues and (b) develop materials for the conduct of remote advisory groups; (2) co-develop and administer a national needs assessment survey for the referenced 4 groups (N = 800) addressing the use of home self-testing technology (up to 3 types) and remote data collection for healthcare research and healthcare provision; and (3) pilot community driven approaches to introducing home self-testing technology and remote data collection to potential participants from these groups to assess feasibility and acceptability.
PI_NAMEs: FLORES MILLENDER, EUGENIA  (contact);WONG, FRANK Y.;XAVIER HALL, CASEY DANIEL
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Elevating Community Voices by Developing a User-centered Approach to Enable Self-testing and Remote Data Collection among Under-represented Populations (Project Elevate)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE High-throughput technology and electronic health records (EHRs) have dramatically increased the amount of data that can used for better understanding and new treatments of disease. However, analyzing the data generated by these technologies requires significant quantitative and computational expertise. Our goal is to develop a program to train current and upcoming generations of diverse biomedical researchers in the skills needed to fully mine the potential of the large amount of available data, and put it to use in furthering diagnosis and treatment of disease, and promoting public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The fundamental goal of the proposed study is to determine the potential of a bacterial-derived toxin (from the oral pathogen Aggratibacter actinomycetemcomitans), the cytolethal distending toxin (Cdt), to alter host defenses. Specifically, this study focuses on a novel role for this toxin in perturbing human macrophage function including inducing a pro-inflammatory response and impairing phagocytosis. We propose that this response contributes to the pathogenesis of inflammatory disorders such as periodontal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pediatric patients with congenital heart disease commonly develop complex peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis (PPS) which can lead to right ventricular failure, pulmonary blood flow imbalance, and even death. While surgical treatment of PPS has led to favorable outcomes at select centers, catheter-based interventions remain the current standard of care at most institutions despite unfavorable and unpredictable outcomes. There is an urgent need for personalized treatment planning and improved outcomes in PPS patients. We propose an integrated modeling and experimental approach in which mechanical tissue testing and clinical data collection will inform and validate two complementary computational models: a mechanistic model of pulmonary flow, growth, and remodeling and a real-time uncertainty-aware “digital twin” model for optimal treatment planning, with the ultimate goal to improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aortic stenosis (AS), involving progressive calcification and narrowing of the aortic valve, the main outlet of the heart, is common and universally fatal without treatment with surgery to replace the aortic valve, as no medical therapy has been proven to prevent or slow progression of AS. In this setting, the presence of concomitant chronic kidney disease has been associated with higher rates of and complications from AS on account of rapid and early calcification of the aortic valve and blood vessels. This study seeks to understand the risk factors that are most important in AS progression as well as identify ways to identify those who progress more quickly and how AS progression associates with adverse cardiovascular outcomes using data from Chronic Renal Insufficiency Cohort Study, an NIDDK-sponsored population cohort study of individuals with chronic kidney disease, and the Atherosclerosis in Communities Study, an NHLBI-sponsored population cohort study of individuals, the majority of whom have normal kidney function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The process of mapping acoustic signals onto units of syllables, words, and phrases is essential to human communication and is also remarkably difficult to replicate in machine systems. We propose an approach that leverages novel speech paradigms, computational modeling and invasive neural measures in neurosurgical patients in order to characterize human cortical speech perception. Using these complementary approaches in tandem with high resolution recording, we will greatly advance our understanding of how speech is processed and temporal information is integrated over time in various parts of cortex in in the hopes that our findings will inform new therapeutic strategies for a range of speech communication impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Appalachia is a socially and economically disadvantaged part of the US. Gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (GBMSM) and transgender women in rural Appalachia are at increased risk for HIV, sexually transmitted infections (STIs), and hepatitis C virus (HCV), and yet, little research has been conducted to understand and reduce health disparities among these vulnerable, hidden, and neglected populations in the region. We propose to systematically integrate two evidenced-based strategies (i.e., peer navigation and mHealth) into a comprehensive culturally congruent, bilingual intervention to increase the use of needed HIV, STI, and HCV prevention and care services among racially/ethnically diverse GBMSM and transgender women in rural Appalachia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Overall The National Center for Interventional Biophotonic Technologies (NCIBT) will promote public health by improving the clinical management of a broad range of common human conditions, including cancer, stroke, heart disease, high risk pregnancy, and dementia. Its advanced optical imaging devices will better characterize tissue structure and function and its AI-based analytical intraprocedural platform will integrate these imaging data and other patient-specific information into algorithms guiding treatment decisions. The availability of such helpful guidance as procedures are being performed or critical decisions are being made should help physicians make better choices that lead to improved patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This new application for Margo Minissian, PhD, ACNP incorporates a multi-disciplinary, mentored patient- oriented research plan to facilitate independence as a nurse scientist, generate preliminary evidence and facilitate an R01 application. This comparative, longitudinal study will compare vascular and cardiac structure/ function and novel cardiac biomarkers in mothers who had term preeclampsia (TPre), spontaneous preterm delivery (sPTD) and preterm preeclampsia (PreE) compared to full-term controls. The outcome of this research will inform relationships between TPre, sPTD and PreE which is an important step to uncover the link between adverse pregnancy outcomes and future maternal atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) results in 40% of all deaths and results in serious morbidity in both men and women and it is well known that a key early step in the development of CVD is dysfunction of a thin single-cell layer of cells lining the inner wall of the blood vessels called endothelium. Our goal is to determine the mechanisms responsible for the impairment of endothelial function by hypercholesterolemia, focusing on cholesterol-induced suppression of a specific type of endothelial K+ channel that we showed to play a significant role in endothelial dysfunction. Currently we focus on elucidating the mechanism of how cholesterol binding to the channels impairs their function (a fundamental and still unanswered question), the role of cholesterol-induced suppression of these channels in endothelial dysfunction, and the impact of the loss of function of these channels on atherosclerosis development, which we believe will contribute significantly to the understanding of endothelial dysfunction and provide the basis for new therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative At the most basic level, social communication boils down to what you say and what you do while interacting with other people. Problems with social communication affect individuals with ASD throughout their lives, but expensive and time-consuming measurement tools have hindered the development of effective treatments for this core challenge. In this proposal, we aim to improve clinical characterization and diagnostic decision- making in ASD and other psychiatric conditions by digitizing human vocal interaction and using advanced machine learning techniques to fuse audio-video signals into an autism-specific algorithm, thus laying the groundwork for future precision medicine efforts and advancing the state of public health.

PHR: Project Narrative Our project will create a “Hawai‘i Health Equity Research and Outreach Network (HAWAI‘I HERON)” that will provide resources to support efforts to improve health equity for Asian American, Native Hawaiian and other Pacific Islander (AA-NHPI) populations. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Lack of robust remyelination represents a major barrier in the recovery of neurological function in disease or after injury in many nervous system disorders. These studies can lay the foundation to help define new strategies to stimulate remyelination in the injured and diseased nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In a recent large scale of genome-wide analysis study, a rare coding variant was identified in Abelson interactor family member 3 (ABI3) gene and this variant is associated with increased risk of late-onset Alzheimer's disease. The overarching goal of this application is to understand the role of ABI3 in microglia and the mechanisms by which ABI3 affects in the context of AD. This can lead to identifying the key regulators of the mechanism and subsequently determination of the new therapeutic targets in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Food allergies are on the rise, and yet the care of food allergic patients is limited by the lack of accurate biomarkers of disease development and resolution, as well as by the absence of curative treatments. The goal of this project is to investigate the role of RELMb as a novel candidate biomarker of food allergy and to elucidate the mechanisms by which it contributes to food allergy pathogenesis. This research will address an existing gap in the knowledge of food allergy mechanisms and improve the daily management of patients with food allergies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Aromatase inhibitors (AIs) reduce cancer recurrence and improve survival in breast cancer survivors who are postmenopausal and have hormone-receptor positive (HR+) tumors, but they also cause painful arthralgia that is distressing, reduces health-related quality of life, and contributes to poor AI adherence. Pain coping skills training—an evidence-based cognitive-behavioral pain intervention—could address these problems, especially if delivered as an automated, web-based program that overcomes current barriers to accessing it. Expanding access to an evidence-based behavioral pain intervention that is low cost and highly scalable is consistent with guidelines for managing pain in cancer and would be a step towards addressing symptoms limiting health and well-being in breast cancer survivors on AI therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative/Relevance  This research is relevant to public health because it addresses the basic molecular mechanisms of how cells signal and how this signaling is deregulated in disease. Specifically, we focus on understanding the mechanisms of and enzyme that generally suppresses tumors, protein kinase C, and its negative regulator, the phosphatase PHLPP. This understanding will allow us to develop effective therapies to restore normal activity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cutaneous lupus lesions are disfiguring, difficult to treat, and often associated with flares of systemic lupus that lead to organ damage and disability. This project will uncover novel mechanisms that regulate the pathologic features of lupus skin and will ultimately lead to new preventative and therapeutic strategies for this devastating disease. Discoveries made through this research are directly relevant to the NIH's mission to foster fundamental discoveries and their applications to protect and improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The use of technology to deliver health care and manage chronic and critical illness is becoming increasingly pervasive. The overarching goal of this T32 (Technology Research in Chronic and Critical Illness) is to provide rigorous research training and interdisciplinary professional socialization to build nursing science aimed at promoting health, managing illness, reducing disability and enhancing quality of life through the aid of technology and clinical data science. This program will enable nurse trainees to be well-positioned to conduct innovative, state-of-the-art research in this growing field based on principles of design-justice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), which worsens cardiovascular disease and commonly causes cirrhosis, is the most prevalent cause of liver dysfunction in Western countries. The studies performed herein will be the first to reveal the importance of hepatocyte ketogenesis in regulating the most predictive index of poor prognosis in NAFLD pathogenesis, fibrosis. These studies will quantify how ketogenesis feeds back to regulate mitochondrial oxidative function in the liver, determine how ketone metabolism becomes dysregulated in NAFLD, and provide new potential intervenable metabolic nodes within distinct liver cell compartments to prevent NAFLD complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychosocial assessment is a core component of genetic counseling practice but has not been systematically studied. The proposed research will be the first to characterize current psychosocial assessment practices in genetic counseling and pilot a standardized psychosocial assessment tool, the BATHE method, which has been found to be useful and effective in other healthcare fields. The ultimate goal of this foundational study is to provide a basis for further evaluation and implementation of effective and consistent psychosocial assessment practices to benefit all genetic counseling patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Digital technology, including recorded speech, has the capability of providing a wealth of information about early changes to cognition and communication associated with developing Alzheimer’s disease pathology, with the potential for highly accessible, yet low-burden measurement. In this innovative proposal, we leverage existing and prospectively collected speech data from two longitudinal cohort studies to examine novel acoustic and linguistic measures and their associations with amyloid, tau, neurodegeneration, and progression to clinical impairment, using signal processing, machine learning, and theory-driven methods. By recruiting a subset of these participants to record their speech at home with a mobile device, our interdisciplinary team can validate digital markers across all stages of ADRD, including the prodromal phase, and can enhance sensitivity and specificity of speech metrics while contributing valuable information about remote, noninvasive, and accessible assessment and disease monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is epidemic throughout the population and is a major driving force in the epidemic of type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome and many other disorders. This grant focuses on defining the interactions between adipocyte heterogeneity, insulin signaling and exosomal miRNA mediated cellular communication in the pathogenesis of these disorders. It also explores new techniques to directly track adipose-derived exosomes and their miRNAs, as well as their potential role as novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical studies have consistently shown a strong association between aging and increased risk for intracranial aneurysmal rupture (i.e., aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage). One of the hallmarks of aging is cellular senescence, a state of permanent proliferative arrest. We will study the mechanisms by which aging and cellular senescence promote aneurysm rupture to develop new therapies that target aging-related biological processes or senescence to prevent aneurysm rupture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The human GlcNAc-1-phosphotransferase catalyzes a key step in covalently tagging the mannose-6- phosphate (M6P) signal to the lysosomal hydrolases, thereby targeting these hydrolases to lysosomes. Mutations in the encoding genes GNPTAB and GNPTG cause the lysosomal storage disorders mucolipidosis II and mucolipidosis III and are directly associated with neurological and neurodegenerative disorders. Our work will provide mechanistic insights into the enzyme catalysis and into how mutations in the enzyme cause the associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Loss or collapse of narrow tubes contributes to lung, kidney and heart disease, and to stroke, blindness and age-related dementia. These studies investigate how narrow tubes are built and how a sugar- and fat-rich lining helps protect the tubes from collapse. Understanding these mechanisms will help in the design of therapies to prevent or treat tube-related disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Study of the evolution of the immune system permits an view of those characteristics of immunity that are vital for defense in all animals, including humans, versus those features that are “primitive” or specific to particular species. Our research in comparative immunology gives an overall view of immune molecules, such as the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules, that are required to combat infectious diseases and cancer and avoid autoimmunity. We have detected MHC molecules in sharks, the oldest animals with adaptive immunity, that are likely the forerunners of their human counterparts. We will examine the structure and function of these molecules to gain insight into their functions in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common cancer in children (age 0-14 years) and has become more frequent over the years in the United States. We have found that children who have an infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV) at birth are at a high risk for ALL and will further assess the role of this infection in a novel, unprecedented study with thousands of children with and without ALL, and will assess CMV at pregnancy, birth, and ALL diagnosis, potentially identifying a validated target for prevention of ALL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal explores untapped potential for turning water network perturbations from a nuisance into an exploitable reporter of protein-ligand interactions. The work will re-define structural water features using variable temperature crystallography and implement a smooth, experimental water term into computational docking to distinguish and selectively target highly similar protein isoforms. By using a water-centric approach at physiological temperature we can overcome current limitations of protein-centric, cryogenic approaches that have failed to produce an FDA approved drug for disease-promoting molecular chaperones despite decades of intense research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research programs are relevant to public health because the systematic assembly of many genome editors will produce a greater understanding of the biological processes controlling genome editing inside human cells and tissues. Robust genome editing techniques could enable the production of personalized drugs, cell therapies and gene therapies for future genomic and precision medicine. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to laying the foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The Jackson Laboratory proposes to initiate, with partners in higher education, a multi-state teacher education program to provide genomics, bioinformatics and bioethics instruction to students preparing to enter the teaching profession. By targeting pre-service educators and expanding our online content, we hope to reach a broad audience of future and current educators that will expand genomic and health literacy in high schools across the US, with the ultimate goal of strengthening the future STEM workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: This technology development proposal will develop novel tools to study immune responses against HIV at the single cell level. Specifically, this work will use DNA-bar-coding methodology to build reagents capable of resolving immune responses to differing molecular structures of the HIV virus. These methods will accelerate the discovery of effective antibodies against HIV, and enable rapid identification of structures of the virus against which the immune system is most effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The Smc5/6 complex is a conserved protein complex whose roles in genome replication, DNA repair, and suppression of extra-chromosomal DNA underlie its clinical functions of tumor suppression and repression of tumor-causing viruses. To address the mechanistic knowledge gap of how Smc5/6 operates as a molecular machine, this proposal aims to: (1) characterize Smc5/6’s ability to manipulate and compact DNA; (2) elucidate the binding preferences of Smc5/6 on DNA substrates of different topologies; and (3) define Smc5/6’s interactions with DNA replication factors. Completion of this project will contribute fundamental knowledge to how cellular systems maintain genome integrity and advance the prospect of establishing Smc5/6 as a therapeutic target to treat cancer and viral infections.

PHR: NARRATIVE: Diseases that impact facial development are difficult to repair because a large source of skeletal tissue is often necessary. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Childhood maltreatment is a major risk factor for suicidal behavior; however, the molecular mechanisms by which childhood maltreatment impacts suicidality, is not known. MicroRNAs are important transducers of environmental effects on gene expression products; this work will test the effects of both childhood maltreatment and an acute experimental stressor on brain microRNAs in humans using a novel method of isolating neural-derived plasma exosomal microRNAs from peripheral blood. By examining microRNAs as mediators of childhood maltreatment- induced suicidality, this study will identify potential molecular mechanisms by which childhood maltreatment can act as a risk factor for suicidality, and neural-derived exosomal microRNAs as novel biosignature of suicide risk in the context of childhood maltreatment that can be tested in longitudinal studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies will explore a novel mechanism of astrocytic modulation of synaptic plasticity involving norepinephrine (NE) and ATP. Since NE is known to play an important role in many pathophysiological disorders such as ADHD, depression, epilepsy, and Alzheimer’s disease, these studies may also give new insight into the role that astrocytes play in neurological disease. Illuminating the importance of this novel mechanism of astrocytic modulation of synaptic plasticity may reveal pathways suitable for pharmacological manipulation to treat diseases of the central nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of this CBI training program is to develop next generation leaders of chemical biologists who will tackle the most significant scientific questions, with particular focus on topics in molecular probe and drug discovery. This program leverages the unique research and educational environment at the University of Florida to provide graduate students from medicinal chemistry, chemistry, biochemistry, biology, biomedical sciences and chemical engineering knowledge, skills and career development opportunities to work together collaboratively in interdisciplinary teams. Students will be trained as experts on both chemistry and biology knowledge domains and can make an impact on health-related research needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need to increase the diversity of independent investigators both generally and in HIV-related behavioral health research in particular. Miami is an HIV epicenter, with new diagnoses disproportionately impacting underrepresented racial and ethnic minorities. The proposed (CHANGE; Culturally-focused HIV Advancements through the Next Generation for Equity) training program, tied to the University of Miami’s Center for HIV and Research in Mental Health (CHARM), will fill this gap by training underrepresented Black and Latinx predoctoral and post-doctoral behavioral scientists in research related to HIV and mental health disparities, aligned with the NIH NOT-OD-20-031 on diversity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed K99/R00 study will use a clinical nutrition intervention trial in rural Ethiopia to determine interactive effects of maternal prenatal stress and nutrition intervention on newborn weight-for-age and stress-sensitive child outcomes related to visual attention, memory, stress reactivity, and socio-emotional functioning at 36 months postpartum. We will also examine whether maternal and newborn telomere length serves as biomarkers of the biologic mechanism underling hypothesized associations. Insight from this project will cast light on the importance of antenatal intervention to reduce commonly co-occurring maternal prenatal stress and undernutrition among millions of women residing in low- resource settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. The proposed UC Davis "Training Program in Learning, Memory, and Plasticity (LaMP)" will allow us to continue to provide training across disciplines to bridge the gaps between the major levels of LaMP research— cognitive, systems, cellular/molecular—in order to promote our understanding of LaMP disorders and reduce their tremendous burden on families, society, and public health. Using this focused, innovative Training Program, we are producing a new generation of diverse scientists who truly think across levels and scales and who have the skills, drive, and motivation to work collaboratively to tackle the most important issues in LaMP in order to improve human health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is relevant to public health because it seeks to identify modifiable factors in very preterm infant growth, nutrition, social and environmental exposures, and illness to optimize long-term abilities and health outcomes. The established link between very preterm infant growth and neurodevelopmental outcomes likely represents a combination of nutrient intake, illness prevention, and social support that promotes growth and brain development. Up to 30% of very preterm infants continue to experience motor, learning, behavior problems, and/or cognitive impairment; identifying opportunities for positive interventions is critical to ensuring these infants have every opportunity for an optimal life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT: One of the main causes of death after massive radiation exposure is infection. In this project, we will study the role of a novel protein, extracellular cold-inducible RNA- binding protein (eCIRP), on the reduced removal of bacteria by macrophages after radiation exposure, determine the detailed mechanisms by which this occurs and, importantly, develop a new drug able to revert the eCIRP-induced macrophage defect, thereby attenuating radiation injury and infection. This project aims at establishing the importance of suppressing eCIRP to control infection after radiation injury and developing a new way to protect people from the harmful effects of massive radiation exposure alone or complicated by sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: DNA replication is the process whereby the genome is duplicated prior to segregation of the resulting sister chromatids during mitosis or meiosis. During mitotic exit or during G1 phase, a pre-Replicative Complex is assembled each at origin of DNA replication throughout the genome that renders each origin competent for subsequent initiation of DNA replication, including assembly of a pre-Initiation Complex. This project will examine how the initiation of DNA replication occurs and how it is regulated, including studies at the structural and single cell level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with voice disorders often suffer from heightened sensations of vocal effort and fatigue while speaking that are typically attributed to inefficient vocal function and behavior. The proposed project seeks to investigate a new index of ambulatory vocal efficiency that integrates estimates of subglottal pressure and vocal sound pressure level to monitor the vocal effort of patients being treated for phonotraumatic vocal cord lesions, non- phonotraumatic vocal hyperfunction, and unilateral vocal fold paralysis. The impact of this work is significant as the new index of ambulatory vocal efficiency will substantially improve the assessment and treatment of voice disorders by providing the capability to quantify a clinically salient vocal parameter in real-world situations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal presents pilot data showing that lipin1 is downregulated in skeletal muscle of patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, and that lipin1 overexpression enhances muscle membrane integrity, reduces muscle degeneration, and ameliorates muscle weakness in a mouse model of this disease. The proposed study aims to elucidate the molecular basis of how lipin1 overexpression attenuates the dystrophic pathology. This work is relevant to public health because it is expected to identify new therapeutic targets and effective treatments for Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is the most common and severe form of muscular dystrophy, as well as additional related muscular disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We will leverage the infrastructure from ongoing studies among people living with HIV (PLWH) enrolled in Medicaid to assess the relationship between HIV and COVID among beneficiaries in 27 states and Washington, DC, including all states and counties prioritized to end the HIV epidemic. We will also evaluate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the provision of HIV care across the continuum and care for health conditions. We will compare our findings by geographic location (state, urban/rural, local government area [LGA], smallest government region e.g. county, city, town, etc.), community level social determinants of health, and among sub-populations to help inform and target interventions to improve care for PLWH in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Innate immune signaling pathways including the RIG-I-like receptor (RLR), cGAS-STING and NLRP3 inflammasome pathways play crucial roles in the host response to pathogenic microbes. These pathways are potent inducers of inflammation when triggered and must be tightly regulated to avoid overexuberant inflammation and tissue damage. This proposal will investigate the mechanisms by which the selective autophagy receptor TAX1BP1 regulates innate immune signaling and immune homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social behaviors are essential for the mental and physical well-being of social species including humans; abnormalities in social behaviors are major symptoms in a host of mental disorders, such as autism spectrum disorders and psychopathy. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it studies the fundamental mechanisms that regulate an important form of social behavior. The proposed research could help reveal fundamental principles that are potentially applicable to the human brain, and could help guide investigation of disease mechanisms and development of effective treatments for human mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this K24 is to provide support for Dr. Ashare to spend an additional 25% of her time mentoring junior scientists in patient-oriented research on inflammatory lung disease, as well as additional time developing her own mentoring skills. This innovative and potentially paradigm shifting research in human subjects is important for public health because understanding the mechanisms underlying regional development and progression of inflammatory lung disease will have a critical impact on investigations of novel therapeutic interventions for lung diseases such CF. Furthermore, the proposed research is germane to the NIH’s mission focusing on discoveries related to human disease pathogenesis and translation of these studies to clinical medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Experiments described in this proposal will define how dietary and immune dependent changes in the nutritional landscape in the gut drive the pathogenesis of Clostridioides difficile infection. In addition, this research will reveal how C. difficile adapts to changes in nutrient levels during infection to outcompete members of the gut microbiota. These discoveries will pave the way for the development of therapeutics or nutritional countermeasures to prevent or treat C. difficile infection which is one of the most important threats to global public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The highly pathogenic influenza viruses pose considerable public health threats with high morbidity and mortality. Infections can range from asymptomatic to deadly with varying host and viral factors associated with heterogenous outcomes. The objective of the proposed research is to develop and validate quantitative computational models and virtual patient cohorts that identify immunologic drivers of severity, biomarkers that define inflammation and distinct outcomes, and determine how distinct levels of basal immunity impact facilitate patient outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding if a telehealth versus a clinic-based hearing care service delivery model can lead to improved hearing aid use and communicative function among older adults using hearing aids is important for guiding clinical care standards and policy decisions regarding hearing care coverage in the U.S. The goal of this proposal is to conduct a randomized trial of these two hearing care models in a follow-up study to the ongoing NIA-funded Aging and Cognitive Health Evaluation in Elders (ACHIEVE) study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative While there is widespread consensus that lesions to the human medial temporal lobes result in a profound loss of long-term verbal memory, there is now growing consensus in the field of cognitive neuroscience that the impairments following such lesions extend outside of this domain into perception, working memory, attention, language, and navigation. Yet how such deficits might arise cannot be accounted for by most contemporary models of medial temporal lobe function. Here, we propose to test a novel model that accounts for such representational impairments based on two dimensions: precision and binding. The expected outcomes of this grant are: 1) a more complete account of the patterns of cognitive deficits accompanying bilateral medial temporal lobe lesions, particularly those localized to the hippocampus (Aim 1), and, 2) more accurate modeling and prediction of the cognitive deficits accompanying unilateral temporal lobe resections to treat pharmacologically-intractable epilepsy (Aim 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative My lab discovered that the genetic code not only determines what information is within a gene but also how the message from that gene is read (how long it is read and how fast it is read). This becomes critical in understanding how all of these messages are coordinated by the cell to achieve higher order function. Cancer and viruses (such as H1N1 and SARS-coV-2) may also tap into these principles discovered by my lab, using the hidden information that is within the genetic code to take over cellular function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The small, ubiquitous and universal Ca-binding protein, calmodulin, either directly controls, or at minimum, modulates every functionality within the heart. This versatile protein is the only known exception to the central rule of biology - one gene one protein, since in all mammalian cells, an identical CaM protein is derived from three different genes, Calm1, 2 and 3. We are discovering that there are robust regulatory mechanisms within calmodulin's three unique mRNAs that dictate where and with which protein target they are translated locally within the cardiac myocyte.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is an aggressive blood cancer with a high mortality rate and dismal overall survival. A majority of AML patients die from complications arising from bone marrow failure which causes decreased production of blood forming cells. However, we lack fundamental knowledge regarding the mechanism driving this phenomenon. I aim to characterize the mechanisms underlying AML-induced bone marrow failure to identify novel avenues for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative PD/PI: Laura B. Duvall PhD Mosquitoes spread pathogens by biting humans to feed on their blood and using the protein from these meals to develop eggs and reproduce. This research project will characterize neuropeptide signaling pathways and anatomy that underlie the physiological changes that control blood-feeding and mating behaviors. These results will inform new strategies to prevent the spread of illnesses including Zika, dengue fever, and chikungunya by directly targeting the pathways that make these mosquitoes effective vectors for disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: More than a million persons in the United States live with HIV, and as this population ages it shows an earlier than expected and growing prevalence of physical frailty, which carries substantial risk of falls and fractures as well as individual and societal costs. This project combines the analysis of large datasets and prior HIV model outputs with a computer simulation model of lifetime and economic consequences of HIV and physical frailty. It will establish the value of diagnosis and treatment strategies for physical frailty in persons living with HIV and comorbidities, to help inform the decisions of physicians and policy makers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 20-40% of patients with acute neurological illness hospitalized in a Neuroscience Intensive Care Unit (NICU) and their informal caregivers experience clinically significant emotional distress which becomes chronic, and is associated with worse recovery trajectory and overall quality of life. The purpose of the present investigation is to test the efficacy of a brief (6 sessions) dyadic (patient and caregiver together) intervention to prevent chronic emotional distress. Through this study, we seek to solve the unmet need of preventing chronic emotional distress in NICU dyads through a feasible, acceptable and credible program, and ideally improve the recovery trajectory and dyads' overall quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Non-functioning kidney grafts after deceased-donor kidney transplantation remain a significant problem, with about one thousand grafts failing yearly and only 50% remain functional after ten years. The current tools we have to predict graft failure are limited in providing pathways for future intervention, therefore this project aims to identify if recipient protein markers involved in blood vessel stability are associated with future graft function in an effort to identify pathways amenable to intervention. The mission of this project aligns well with the overall mission of the NIDDK, as we aim to understand pathways that influence recipient graft outcomes to be able to enhance graft quality and improve overall recipient health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: This UNITE T32 training program at UNC Chapel Hill supports trainee development of those working at the interface of environmental biostatistics, environmental epidemiology and environmental health. The trainees develop critical thinking skills and learn how to use state-of-the-art methodologies to address urgent and critical needs in environmental health sciences as they arise. Our transdisciplinary approaches focus on: (1) cutting edge data science for environmental public health, (2) emerging contaminants due to changing climate and consumer products that threaten North Carolina and the world, and (3) environmental justice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric obesity is an epidemic that is disproportionately experienced by children from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, underscoring the need to identify novel, modifiable risk factors for obesity prevention and treatment, particularly for those at greater risk. Mounting evidence rooted in circadian science suggests that the timing and consistency with which children engage in sleep, eating and activity behaviors may represent novel targets for enhancing existing prevention and treatment approaches with potential for high public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall mission of the DARE Collaboratory is to harness the power of the immune system to control HIV in the absence of antiretroviral therapy (a “remission”) or eliminate it during therapy (which if successful could lead to a complete “cure”). To address our first goal – developing an effective remission strategy – we will in develop a combination regimen that enhances the ability of CD8+ T cells and other parts of the immune system to target SIV/HIV immediately after therapy is interrupted. To address or second goad – reservoir reduction and elimination – we will develop drugs that render infected cells more susceptible to immune-mediated clearance mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Food allergy affects 6-8% of children and ~3% of adults the general population. Food allergy is mediated by antigen crosslinking of IgE antibody bound to mast cells (MC), and is often associated with intestinal dysbiosis. IgE sensitization to food is not sufficient by itself to drive food anaphylaxis. Intestinal MC load, which controls intestinal permeability and systemic antigen absorption, is an important determinant. DOCK8 deficiency is characterized by recurrent infections, eczema and food allergy with a high incidence of food anaphylaxis As food allergy and anaphylaxis are cardinal features of DOCK8-deficient patients, DOCK8 deficiency constitutes a disease model for identifying mechanisms underlying food allergy. We will test the hypothesis that DOCK8 deficient mice, which show increased susceptibility to anaphylaxis caused by food ingestion, have dysregulated immunity that results in an abnormal intestinal microbiome, which results in an increased intestinal MC load and exaggerated susceptibility to ingested antigens. We will examine whether the principles learned from studying food allergy in Dock8 deficiency are applicable to patients with food allergy. The results obtained. They may suggest novel for food allergic patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative – Public Health Significance Interventions such as Couples HIV testing and counseling (CHTC), which address HIV-risk within primary relationships, are an essential component to a comprehensive national prevention strategy. Up to two-thirds of HIV infections among MSM occur within the context of primary partnerships, and these rates are highest among younger men who have sex with men (aged 18-29). Despite its promise, the current CHTC protocol is limited in two ways. First, CHTC does not incorporate a focus on drug use – a well-established correlate of HIV infection risk among YMSM specifically. Second, CHTC provides limited guidance for formal communication skills training in instances where partners have substantial communication deficits. Building upon pilot research funded by DA036419, the proposed project seeks to evaluate the efficacy of the We Test intervention – which includes two adjunct CHTC components: a substance use module (SUM) and an assertive communication training (CT) video. A total of 240 YMSM couples will be enrolled equally across sites in New York City and Detroit. Couples will be randomized in a factorial design to receive CHTC as usual; CHTC + SUM; CHTC + CT; or CHTC+SUM+CT. Follow-ups will occur at 3-, 6-, 9-, and 12-months post intervention. Analyses evaluate the efficacy of the intervention components to reduce drug use, drug related problems, and HIV transmission risk. Secondary outcomes include syphilis infection, PrEP uptake, and binge drinking as well as qualitative intervention feedback.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project, developed in partnership with Chicago Public Schools and the Boys & Girls Clubs of Chicago, is to develop a new, efficient approach for training and supporting elementary K-5 science teacher leaders well-versed in Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) pedagogy, leadership, coaching, and evaluation skills. This project, “ESTELE: Developing the Next Generation of Science Teacher Leaders,” uses an authentic. practicum-based training strategy where teacher leaders coach and support new-to-NGSS teachers working in a community-based youth summer camp. Through this approach, science teacher leaders are prepared for school-level NGSS coaching and leadership roles, novice NGSS teachers gain valuable NGSS pedagogical skills, and hundreds of disadvantaged youths receive high-quality health- and science-focused summer learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Both genetic and environmental risk factors play a part in the development of autism, yet despite being estimated to account for 41% of autism risk, we know very little about what environmental factors contribute to autism risk. Because social deficit is one of the 3 core symptoms of autism, I developed a high-throughput screening approach to systematically search for chemicals that inhibit the development of social behavior. This screen revealed topoisomerase II as a key regulator of the development of social behavior in zebrafish and mouse, which is investigated in further detail in this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spread of cancer cells into the spinal fluid, or leptomeningeal metastasis, is a cruel complication of cancer that results in rapid neurologic disability and death. We understand little about the mechanisms that allow cancer cells to grow with the spinal fluid. To remedy this, we propose a bench-to-bedside approach combining state-of- the-art analyses of clinical samples with rigorous, hypothesis-driven mouse modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorders and psychopathy are serious and costly mental health issues. Psychopathy is known to be associated with aberrant moral decision making and there is considerable interest in determining whether substance use disorders lead to impairments in these same cognitive processes. Recent large-scale research initiatives in forensic settings by our research team have begun to identify substance abuse and psychopathy- related disruption in the neural mechanisms involved in moral decision-making processes, and associations between these neural networks and future relapse and antisocial behavior. Here we extend our prior work (with incarcerated men) to examine these issues among incarcerated women in order to better understand sex differences. This project addresses the overall lack of neurocognitive research in criminal offenders with substance use disorders, thereby focusing on a major public health issue in an underserved and understudied population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are few proven interventions that support parenting and long-term recovery for pregnant and postpartum women with Opioid Use Disorders (OUD). Using a community-based participatory research approach, the feasibility and preliminary effects of using a customized evidence-based digital technology self-management recovery program for women with OUD during the pregnancy and postpartum period will be evaluated. The findings from the proposed research will support the development of a targeted and cost-effective digital intervention to improve mother and infant outcomes for this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reduced shoulder mobility caused by prolonged joint immobilization, trauma, or surgical procedures is painful and debilitating. Current pharmacological and surgical treatment options for patients suffering from shoulder arthrofibrosis, or “frozen shoulder,” are limited in scope and effectiveness, resulting in many patients never regaining full joint function. The sustained and localized delivery of the antifibrotic peptide hormone, relaxin-2, is described as a novel solution to treat the underlying causes of shoulder contracture and to restore joint range of motion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to develop a novel eye injection treatment for dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD). In dry AMD, vision loss occurs due to formation of abnormal deposits of fat and proteins under the retina (drusen) and atrophy of retinal tissue over time. There are no approved therapies for dry AMD. One major cause of AMD is damage to mitochondria, the energy factories within our cells. This project will develop a new drug designed to repair damaged mitochondria, which in turn, may slow disease worsening and improve vision in patients suffering from dry AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will characterize a chemokine receptor inhibitor therapy to mitigate radiation injury and inflammation with efficacy at 24 hours after radiation exposure. This proposal will also define the mechanism of action of the countermeasure which will provide data necessary for product licensure requirements according to the FDA Animal Rule. Successful completion of this project will lead to the development of this chemokine receptor inhibitor-based therapy as a new medical countermeasure to treat injuries resulting from a radiation or nuclear accident.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This MIRA application combines projects supported by R01s GM124434 and GM126033. The project employs genetic and genomics tools in Drosophila and human cells to determine how cell growth and growth factor signaling are regulated, and how they in turn regulate cell proliferation. This work will uncover genes and regulatory mechanisms relevant to a broad range of human diseases that involve dysregulated cell proliferation, including degenerative diseases, chronic inflammatory diseases, and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal will establish the extent to which retrieval constitutes a control-independent internal attention state. The results are expected to advance understanding of how the retrieval state may drive the processes and representations that support memory and cognition. In so doing, this proposal will provide a foundation for under- standing and identifying memory performance deﬁcits across the lifespan in healthy individuals and in patients suffering from cognitive impairments due to stroke or disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal, “Research Training in Biobehavioral Disturbances of Eating Disorders,” requests support for a three-year research fellowship program for post-doctoral MD and PhD scientists to train much needed future researchers specializing in eating disorders. Eating disorders are medically and psychiatrically serious illnesses in critical need of research into their underlying mechanisms and potential treatments. The training program outlined in this application describes a plan to successfully train clinical researchers in this specialized area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Exosomes and their cargo RNAs have been shown to play a role as novel signaling entities and may serve as a new class of markers in heart failure patients. In this proposal, we seek to validate and improve the performance of these RNA biomarkers, study how they regulate cellular processes important in progression of heart failure and develop new therapies to interrupt this disease. We expect our work will yield new insight into the biology of heart failure, develop clinically actionable markers and provide a platform for new types of therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Defects in chromosome segregation can give rise to cells with an incorrect number of chromosomes, also known as aneuploidy. Aneuploid cells are associated with cancer, birth defects, miscarriages and infertility. Thus, understanding how cells avoid defects in chromosome segregation can help prevent, develop diagnostics for and treat these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Decreasing suicide death is now a primary focus of NIMH efforts. Aggregated data across multiple large genetic studies yield heritability estimates of approximately 45%, yet research has been limited by a lack of molecular genetic data on suicide death. This project will leverage genome-wide and comprehensive health record data on suicide death to discover genetic risk factors, model genetic and clinical heterogeneity, and extend clinically relevant findings to independent cohorts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this project is to determine the effectiveness of transcarotid artery revascularization (TCAR) to prevent stroke in patients with carotid artery stenosis compared to carotid endarterectomy or transfemoral carotid artery stenting. With no randomized trial of TCAR to guide treatment decisions, this study will resolve important knowledge gaps surrounding how TCAR should be used in clinical practice. In addition, this work will serve as a project-based learning example allowing Dr. Columbo to fill critical conceptual knowledge gaps in his training as a comparative-effectiveness researcher, launching his career as an independent investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Specific errors, also referred to as mutations, in the genetic code of normal cells turns them into cancer. However, studying how these mutations cause a normal cell to become a cancer cell remains difficult. We have developed a new approach that enables one to study thousands of cancer mutations in a single experiment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hospitalizations for serious injection-related infections may motivate individuals to seek treatment with medications for opioid use disorder which reduce mortality and re-hospitalization in this population. However, the benefits of medications for opioid use disorder are not fully realized for individuals with serious injection- related infections due to limited treatment retention. This Career Development Award will use insights from public health treatment data and qualitative interviews to systematically adapt and evaluate a medication for opioid use disorder retention intervention, Recovery Management Checkups, for individuals with serious injection-related infections. Simeon Kimmel, MD, MA
